{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox criminal | name = George Stinney | image_name = George Stinney mugshot.jpg | image_size = | image_caption = Stinney's mug shot | birth_name = George Junius Stinney, Jr. | birth_date = {{Birth date|1929|10|21}} | birth_place = [[Pinewood, South Carolina]], United States | death_date = {{Death date and age|1944|6|16|1929|10|21}} | death_place = [[Columbia, South Carolina|Columbia]], [[South Carolina]], United States | conviction = [[First-degree murder]] (vacated) | conviction_penalty = Death by [[electric chair]] | conviction_status = {{Plainlist| * Executed (1944) * [[Vacated judgment|Conviction vacated]] (2014) }} }} '''George Junius Stinney Jr.''' (October 21, 1929 – June 16, 1944), was a 14 year old African-American convicted of murder as a result of a racially-biased and discriminatory trial in 1944 in his home town of [[Alcolu, South Carolina]]. He was the youngest person in the United States in the 20th-century to be sentenced to death and to be executed.{{cite news |last=Banner |first=Stuart |date=March 5, 2005 |title=When Killing a Juvenile Was Routine |url=https://www.nytimes.com/imagepages/2005/03/05/weekinreview/20050306_BANNER_CHART.html |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |archive-date=April 12, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160412063127/http://www.nytimes.com/imagepages/2005/03/05/weekinreview/20050306_BANNER_CHART.html |dead-url=no}} Stinney was convicted in less than 10 minutes, during a one-day trial, by an all-white jury{{cite news |last=Bever |first=Lindsey |date=December 18, 2014 |title=It took 10 minutes to convict 14-year-old George Stinney Jr. It took 70 years after his execution to exonerate him. |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2014/12/18/the-rush-job-conviction-of-14-year-old-george-stinney-exonerated-70-years-after-execution/ |publisher=[[Washington Post]]}} of the [[first-degree murder]] of two [[White people|white]] girls: 11-year-old Betty June Binnicker and 8-year-old Mary Emma Thames. After being arrested, Stinney was said to have confessed to the crime.{{Cite web |title=State Prison Protects Negro after Slaying |url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=888&dat=19440327&id=ldM0AAAAIBAJ&sjid=oE4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5724,7818032&hl=en |date=March 25, 1944 |agency=[[International News Service|INS]] |publisher = [[St. Petersburg Times]] |accessdate=October 18, 2015}}{{Cite web |title=Youth Admits Killing Girls |url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1499&dat=19440325&id=AfAZAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BCMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4356,3574612&hl=en |date=March 25, 1944 |agency=[[Associated Press|AP]] |publisher = [[The Milwaukee Journal]] |accessdate = October 18, 2015}} There was no written record of his confession apart from notes provided by an investigating deputy,{{Cite news |last = McVeigh |first = Karen |date=March 22, 2014 |title = George Stinney was executed at 14. Can his family now clear his name? |url = https://www.theguardian.com/theobserver/2014/mar/22/george-stinney-execution-verdict-innocent |newspaper = [[The Observer]] |archive-date= March 19, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160319042807/http://www.theguardian.com/theobserver/2014/mar/22/george-stinney-execution-verdict-innocent |dead-url=no}} and no transcript was recorded of the brief trial. He was denied appeal and executed by [[electric chair]]. Since Stinney's conviction and execution the question of his guilt, the validity of his reported confession, and the judicial process leading to his execution have been extensively criticized.{{cite news |last=Collins |first=Jeffrey |date=January 18, 2010 |title=SC crusaders look to right Jim Crow justice wrongs |url=http://www.goupstate.com/article/20100118/ARTICLES/100119732 |agency=AP |publisher=[[Spartanburg Herald-Journal]] |archive-date=May 29, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160529172647/http://www.goupstate.com/article/20100118/articles/100119732 |dead-url=no}} A group of lawyers and activists investigated the Stinney case on behalf of his family. In 2013 the family petitioned for a new trial. On December 17, 2014, his conviction was posthumously [[Vacated judgment|vacated]] 70 years after his execution, because the circuit court judge ruled that he had not been given a fair trial; he had no effective defense and his [[Sixth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Sixth Amendment]] rights had been violated.{{cite web |last=Turnage |first=Jeremy |date=December 17, 2014 |url=http://www.wistv.com/story/27651255/george-stinney-14-year-old-convicted-of-44-murder-exonerated |title=George Stinney, 14-year-old convicted of '44 murder, exonerated |publisher=[[WIS]] |archive-date=March 3, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303223031/http://www.wistv.com/story/27651255/george-stinney-14-year-old-convicted-of-44-murder-exonerated |dead-url=no}}{{cite news |last=McCloud |first=Harriet |date=December 17, 2014 |title=South Carolina judge tosses conviction of black teen executed in 1944 |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-south-carolina-idUSKBN0JV25320141217 |agency=[[Reuters]] |archive-date=December 22, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222110718/http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-south-carolina-idUSKBN0JV25320141217 |dead-url=no }} The judgment noted that while Stinney may in fact have committed the crime, the prosecution and trial were fundamentally flawed. Judge Mullen ruled that his confession was likely coerced and thus inadmissible. She also found that the execution of a 14-year-old constituted "cruel and unusual punishment." ==Case background== In 1944 George Junius Stinney, Jr. lived in [[Alcolu, South Carolina|Alcolu]], [[Clarendon County, South Carolina]]. The 14-year-old African-American boy lived with his father, George Stinney, Sr., mother Aime, brothers Charles, age 12, and John, age 17, and sisters Katherine, age 10, and Aime, age 7. George Sr. worked at the town's sawmill, and the family lived in housing provided by George Sr.'s employer. Alcolu was a small, working-class mill town, where white and black neighborhoods were separated by railroad tracks. The town was typical of small Southern towns of the time, with separate schools and churches for white and black residents, who rarely interacted. The bodies of Betty June Binnicker, age 11, and Mary Emma Thames, age 8, were found in a ditch on the black side of Alcolu on March 23, 1944. They had been beaten with an improvised weapon variously reported as a piece of blunt metal or a railroad spike. The girls were last seen riding their bicycles looking for flowers. As they passed the Stinney property, they asked young George Stinney and his sister, Aime, if they knew where to find "[[Passiflora incarnata|maypops]]", a local name for passionflowers. According to Aime, she was with George at the time of the murders. When the girls did not return home, search parties were organized. George's father was among the searchers. The bodies of the girls were found the next morning, on the black side of town, in a ditch filled with muddy water. According to an article reported by the wire services on March 24, 1944, and published widely, with the mistake of the boy's name preserved, the sheriff announced the arrest and said that "George Junius" had confessed and led officers to "a hidden piece of iron." Both girls had suffered [[Blunt trauma|blunt force trauma]] to the face and head.{{cite book |last=Jones |first=Mark R. |title=South Carolina Killers: Crimes of Passion |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5YdF1MePkfoC&pg=PA38 |accessdate=November 24, 2014 |year=2007 |publisher=[[The History Press]] |isbn=978-1-59629-395-3 |pages=38–42 |chapter=Chapter Five: Too Young to Die: The Execution of George Stinney, Jr. (1944)}} Reports differed as to what kind of weapon had been used. According to a report by the medical examiner, these wounds had been "inflicted by a blunt instrument with a round head, about the size of a hammer." Both girls' skulls were punctured. The girls had not been sexually assaulted and their hymens were intact. The medical examiner reported the genitalia of the older girl were slightly bruised.{{cite web|last=McLaughlin |first=Eliot C.|date=January 23, 2014 |title=New trial sought for George Stinney, executed at 14 |url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/01/21/us/george-stinney-hearing/ |website=[[CNN]] |archive-date=April 10, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160410224104/http://www.cnn.com/2014/01/21/us/george-stinney-hearing/ |dead-url=no}} {{cite news |last=Walker |first=Tim |date=January 22, 2014 |title=George Stinney: After 70 years, justice in sight for boy America sent to electric chair |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/after-70-years-justice-in-sight-for-boy-america-sent-to-electric-chair-9078460.html |website=[[The Independent]] |archive-date=March 5, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305021418/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/after-70-years-justice-in-sight-for-boy-america-sent-to-electric-chair-9078460.html |dead-url=no}} ==Investigation== George Stinney was arrested on suspicion of murdering the girls along with his older brother Johnny. Johnny was released, George was held and not allowed to see his parents until after his trial and conviction. According to a handwritten statement, the arresting officer was H.S. Newman, a Clarendon County deputy, who stated "I arrested a boy by the name of George Stinney. He then made a confession and told me where to find a piece of iron about 15 inches were [sic] he said he put it in a ditch about six feet from the bicycle." No confession statement signed by Stinney is known to exist. George was reported to have gotten into fights at school, including a fight where he scratched a girl with a knife. This assertion by Stinney's seventh-grade teacher, who was black, was disputed by Aime Stinney Ruffner when it was reported in 1995. A local white woman who remembered Stinney from childhood said Stinney had threatened to kill her and her friend the day before the murder, and that he was known as a bully.{{Cite web |last=Behre |first=Robert |date=January 17, 2014 |title=Family, friends of 1944 murder victim wary of reopening George Stinney’s death penalty case |url=http://www.postandcourier.com/article/20140117/PC1610/140119506 |website=[[The Post and Courier]] |archive-date=June 3, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160603111624/http://www.postandcourier.com/article/20140117/PC1610/140119506 |dead-url=no}} Following George's arrest, his father was fired from his job at the local sawmill, and the Stinney family had to immediately vacate the housing provided by Stinney Sr's employer. The family feared for their safety. His parents did not see George again before the trial. He had no support during his 81-day confinement and trial; he was kept at a jail in Columbia 50 miles from town because of the risk of lynching. Stinney was questioned alone, without his parents or an attorney. Although the [[Sixth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Sixth Amendment]] guarantees legal counsel, it was not until 1963 that ''[[Gideon v. Wainwright]]'' explicitly required representation through the course of criminal proceedings. ==Trial== The entire proceeding against Stinney, including jury selection, took one day. Stinney's court-appointed defense counsel was Charles Plowden, a tax commissioner campaigning for election to local political office. Plowden did not challenge the three police officers who testified that Stinney confessed to the two murders, despite this being the only evidence against him, and despite the prosecution's presentation of two different versions of Stinney's verbal confession. In one version Stinney was attacked by the girls after he tried to help one girl who had fallen in the ditch and he killed them in self defense. In the other version he had followed the girls, first attacking Mary Emma and then Betty June. There was no physical evidence linking him to the murders. There is no written record of Stinney's confession apart from Deputy Newman's statement. Stinney's trial had an [[all-white jury]]. More than 1,000 people crowded the courtroom but no blacks were allowed. Other than the testimony of the three police officers, at trial prosecutors called three witnesses: Reverend Francis Batson, who discovered the bodies of the two girls, and the two doctors who performed the post-mortem examination. Conflicting confessions were reported to have been offered by the prosecution. The court allowed discussion of the "possibility" of rape despite an absence of evidence in the medical examiner's report. Stinney's counsel did not call any witnesses, did not cross-examine witnesses and offered little or no defense. Trial presentation lasted two and a half hours. The jury took ten minutes to [[jury deliberation|deliberate]], after which they returned with a guilty verdict. The judge sentenced Stinney to death by the electric chair. There is no transcript of the trial. No appeal was filed. Stinney's family, churches and the [[NAACP]] appealed to Governor [[Olin D. Johnston]] for clemency, given the age of the boy. Others urged the governor to let the execution proceed, which he did. Johnston stated in a response to one appeal for clemency that "It may be interesting for you to know that Stinney killed the smaller girl to rape the larger one. Then he killed the larger girl and raped her dead body. Twenty minutes later he returned and attempted to rape her again, but her body was too cold. All of this he admitted himself." These assertions were not supported by the medical examiner's report. Between the time of Stinney's arrest and his execution, Stinney's parents were allowed to see him once, after the trial in the Columbia penitentiary. ==Execution== The execution of George Stinney was carried out at the [[Central Correctional Institution]] in [[Columbia, South Carolina|Columbia]] on June 16, 1944, at 7:30 p.m. Standing {{convert|5|feet|1|in|cm}} tall and weighing just over {{convert |90|lbs|kg |sigfig=1}},{{cite serial |people=Karen Callahan (Producer) |date=June 30, 2004 |series=[[Day to Day]] |title=George Stinney, Youngest Executed |url=http://www.soundportraits.org/on-air/youngest_executed/ |place=Passaic, NJ}} Stinney was so small compared to the usual adult prisoners that law officers had difficulty securing him to the frame holding the electrodes. The state's adult-sized face-mask did not fit him; as he was hit with the first 2,400 [[volt|V]] surge of electricity, the mask covering his face slipped off.{{cite book |last=James |first=Joy |date=2000 |title=States of Confinement: Policing, Detention and Prisons |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Tn_BF2ggwAUC |publisher=[[Palgrave Macmillan]] |isbn=0-312-21777-3}} Stinney was declared dead within four minutes of the initial electrocution. From the time of the murders until Stinney's execution, 83 days had passed. ==Reopening of case== In 2004, George Frierson, a local historian who grew up in Alcolu, started researching the case after reading a newspaper article about it. His work gained the attention of South Carolina lawyers Steve McKenzie and Matt Burgess. In addition, Ray Brown, attorney James Moon, and others contributed countless hours of research and review of historical documents, in finding witnesses and evidence to assist in exonerating young Stinney. Among those who aided the case were the [[Civil Rights and Restorative Justice Project]] (CRRJ) at [[Northeastern University School of Law]], who filed an ''amicus'' brief with the court in 2014.{{cite web |last=Barbato |first=Lauren |date=December 17, 2014 |title=The Youngest Person Executed In America, George Stinney Jr., Almost Certainly Wasn't Guilty |url=http://www.bustle.com/articles/54488-the-youngest-person-executed-in-america-george-stinney-jr-almost-certainly-wasnt-guilty |website=[[Bustle.com]]}} Frierson and the ''pro bono'' lawyers first sought relief through the Pardon and Parole Board of South Carolina. McKenzie and Burgess, along with lawyer Ray Chandler representing Stinney's family, filed a motion for a new trial on October 25, 2013.{{cite news |last= Braswell | first= Kristin | title= Film to Explore George Stinney, Jr. Execution | url= http://www.ebony.com/news-views/film-to-explore-george-stinney-jr-execution-405 | date=February 28, 2014 | work= [[Ebony (magazine)|Ebony]] |archive-date=March 4, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304131221/http://www.ebony.com/news-views/film-to-explore-george-stinney-jr-execution-405 |dead-url=no}} {{quote|If we can get the case re-opened, we can go to the judge and say, 'There wasn't any reason to convict this child. There was no evidence to present to the jury. There was no transcript. This case needs to be re-opened. This is an injustice that needs to be righted.' I'm pretty optimistic that if we can get the witnesses we need to come forward, we will be successful in court. We hopefully have a witness that's going to say — that's non-family, non-relative witness — who is going to be able to tie all this in and say that they were basically an alibi witness. They were there with Mr. Stinney and this did not occur.{{Cite news |last=Edwards |first=David |date=October 3, 2011 |url=http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2011/10/03/new-evidence-could-clear-14-year-old-executed-by-south-carolina/ |title=New evidence could clear 14-year-old executed by South Carolina |work=[[The Raw Story]] |archive-date=May 30, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160530003313/http://www.rawstory.com/2011/10/new-evidence-could-clear-14-year-old-executed-by-south-carolina/ |dead-url=no}} |Steve McKenzie}} George Frierson stated in interviews, "there has been a person that has been named as being the culprit, who is now deceased. And it was said by the family that there was a deathbed confession." Frierson said that the rumored culprit came from a well-known, prominent white family. A member, or members, of that family had served on the initial coroner's inquest jury, which had recommended that Stinney be prosecuted. In its ''amicus'' brief, the CRRJ said:
There is compelling evidence that George Stinney was innocent of the crimes for which he was executed in 1944. The prosecutor relied, almost exclusively, on one piece of evidence to obtain a conviction in this capital case: the unrecorded, unsigned “confession” of a 14-year-old child who was deprived of counsel and parental guidance, and whose defense lawyer shockingly failed to call exculpating witnesses or to preserve his right of appeal.
New evidence in the court hearing in January 2014 included testimony by Stinney's siblings that he was with them at the time of the murders. In addition, an affidavit was introduced from the "Reverend Francis Batson, who found the girls and pulled them from the water-filled ditch. In his statement he recalls there was not much blood in or around the ditch, suggesting that they may have been killed elsewhere and moved." Wilford "Johnny" Hunter, who was in prison with Stinney, "testified that the teenager told him he had been made to confess" and always maintained his innocence. Rather than approving a new trial, on December 17, 2014, [[circuit court]] Judge Carmen Mullen [[Vacated judgment|vacated]] Stinney's conviction. She ruled that he had not received a fair trial, as he was not effectively defended and his [[Sixth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Sixth Amendment]] right had been violated. The ruling was a rare use of the legal principle of ''[[coram nobis]]''. Judge Mullen ruled that his confession was likely coerced and thus [[Inadmissible Evidence|inadmissible]]. She also found that the execution of a 14-year-old constituted "cruel and unusual punishment." Mullen confined her judgment to the process of the prosecution, noting that Stinney "may well have committed this crime." With reference to the legal process Mullen wrote "No one can justify a 14-year-old child charged, tried, convicted and executed in some 80 days," concluding that "In essence, not much was done for this child when his life lay in the balance." Family members of both Betty Binnicker and Mary Thames expressed disappointment at the ruling. They said that, although they acknowledge his execution at the age of 14 is controversial, they never doubted his guilt. The niece of Betty Binnicker has said she and her family have extensively researched the case, and argues that "people who [just] read these articles in the newspaper don't know the truth." Binnicker's niece said that, in the early 1990s, a police officer who had arrested Stinney had contacted her and said: "Don't you ever believe that boy didn't kill your aunt."{{cite news |last=Gaskins |first=Nikki |date=March 1, 2014 |title=Goose Creek woman, others hope George Stinney murder conviction sticks |url=http://www.berkeleyobserver.com/2014/03/01/goose-creek-woman-others-hope-george-stinney-murder-conviction-sticks/ |newspaper=Berkeley Observer |archive-date=March 22, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160322113343/http://www.berkeleyobserver.com/2014/03/01/goose-creek-woman-others-hope-george-stinney-murder-conviction-sticks/ |dead-url=no}} These family members said that the claims of a deathbed confession from an individual confessing to the girls' murders have never been substantiated. The solicitor for the state of South Carolina, who argued for the state against [[exoneration]], was Ernest A. Finney III. He is the son of [[Ernest A. Finney, Jr.]], who was appointed as South Carolina's first African-American State Supreme Court justice since Reconstruction.{{cite news |last=Robertson |first=Campbell |date=December 18, 2014 |title=South Carolina Judge Vacates Conviction of George Stinney in 1944 Execution |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/18/us/judge-vacates-conviction-in-1944-execution.html |publisher=New York Times |archive-date=December 12, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151212132153/http://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/18/us/judge-vacates-conviction-in-1944-execution.html |dead-url=no}} == Books and films about Stinney's case == [[David Stout]] based his first novel ''Carolina Skeletons'' (1988) on this case. He was awarded the 1989 [[Edgar Allan Poe Award|Edgar Allan Poe Award for Best First Novel]].{{cite web| url= https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/16/books/edgar-awards-for-mysteries.html | date=May 16, 1989| title= Edgar Awards for mysteries|page=C18 | publisher=The New York Times |accessdate=February 28, 2010}} Stout suggests in the novel that Stinney, whom he renames Linus Bragg, was innocent. The plot revolves around a fictitious nephew of Stinney/Bragg, who unravels the truth about the case decades later. The novel was adapted as a 1991 television movie of the same name directed by John Erman, featuring [[Kenny Blank]] as Stinney/Bragg. [[Lou Gossett, Jr.]] played Stinney's/Bragg's younger brother James.{{cite news |last= O'Connor |first= John J. |date=September 30, 1991 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/30/news/review-television-reopening-the-wounds-of-an-old-murder-case.html | title=Reopening the wounds of an old murder case |page= C16 | work=The New York Times| accessdate= February 28, 2010}} As of February 2014, another movie about the Stinney case, ''83 Days'', was planned by Pleroma Studios, written and produced by Ray Brown with [[Charles Burnett (director)|Charles Burnett]] as director.{{cite news |last=Brinson |first=Ron |date=January 24, 2014 |title=George Stinney trial is a reminder of justice not served |url=http://www.postandcourier.com/article/20140124/PC1002/140129595 |newspaper= The Post and Courier |archive-date=June 3, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160603112156/http://www.postandcourier.com/article/20140124/PC1002/140129595 |dead-url=no}} ==See also== *[[List of people executed in South Carolina]] *[[List of wrongful convictions in the United States]] ==References== {{reflist |30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Stinney, George}} [[Category:1929 births]] [[Category:1944 deaths]] [[Category:American people convicted of murder]] [[Category:People from Clarendon County, South Carolina]] [[Category:20th-century executions of American people]] [[Category:20th-century executions by South Carolina]] [[Category:People executed by South Carolina by electric chair]] [[Category:Executed children]] [[Category:People executed for murder]] [[Category:Juvenile offenders executed by the United States]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by South Carolina]] [[Category:Wrongful convictions]] [[Category:Wrongful executions]] [[Category:Executed African-American people]] [[Category:History of South Carolina]] [[Category:People wrongfully convicted of murder]] [[Category:Executed people from South Carolina]] [[Category:Overturned convictions in the United States]]

{{BLP sources|date=September 2011}} '''George W. Sams Jr.''' (born c.1946) was a member of the [[Black Panther Party]] convicted in the 1969 murder of New York Panther [[Alex Rackley]], which resulted in the [[New Haven Black Panther trials]] of 1970.
Sams turned [[state's evidence]] in return for a reduced charge of [[second-degree murder]]. He testified that, acting under direct orders from national party leader [[Bobby Seale]], he arranged for the kidnapping of Rackley to Panther headquarters in New Haven, where Rackley was tortured for two days then transported to the marshlands of [[Middlefield, Connecticut]], where he was shot by [[Warren Kimbro]] and [[Lonnie McLucas]] on Sams' orders. According to author [[Hugh Pearson (journalist)|Hugh Pearson]], who wrote the book ''[[The Shadow of the Panther: Huey Newton and the Price of Black Power in America]]'': {{Quote|The Rackley case became one of the most controversial Panther cases of all, a prime example of the question of which illegal activities could be blamed on genuine party leaders, and which on agents-provocateurs or just plain deviants in the party. Seale was accused of ordering Rackley’s murder for being an alleged government agent, with the words, ‘Do away with him.’ Williams and others were accused of being present when Seale gave the command, George Sams accepting it, then he, Lonnie McLucas, and Warren Kimbro, the alleged triggermen, driving Rackley to a swamp to kill him. The case hinged largely on the questions of whether Seale actually did appear to give the command, and if so, how Seale’s command could be interpreted. The Panthers would insist that party member George Sams ordered the murder of Rackley on his own.}} Neither Kimbro nor McLucas corroborated Sams' testimony regarding Seale's involvement. The jury deadlocked on the charges against Seale and Black Panther leader [[Ericka Huggins]], and the charges against both were dropped. Members of the Black Panther party accused Sams of being an FBI informant.
==References== {{commons category}} * ''[http://www.edwardjayepstein.com/archived/panthers.htm Bobby Seale's Shadow]'' [[Gadfly Online]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=September 2015}} {{refimprove|date=September 2014}} [[File:George Ramsdale Witton-(1901).jpeg|thumb|300px|right|Lieutenant G.R. Witton, Bushveldt Carbineers (1901).]] '''George Ramsdale Witton''' (1874–1942) was a Lieutenant in the [[Bushveldt Carbineers]] in the [[Second Boer War|Boer War]] in [[South Africa]].
He was temporarily sentenced to death for murder after the shooting of nine Boer prisoners.<ref>Woolmore, pp. 142–144.</ref> He was subsequently reprieved by [[Herbert Kitchener, 1st Earl Kitchener|Kitchener]], although Lieutenants [[Peter Handcock]] and [[Harry Morant|Harry "Breaker" Morant]] who had been [[Court martial of Breaker Morant|court martialed]] with him were executed by a firing squad on 27 February 1902.
==Early life and involvement in the Boer War== Witton was born near [[Warrnambool]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], Australia, and was from a farming family; prior to his VIB enlistment, he was a gunner in the [[Royal Australian Artillery]]. He enlisted in the [[Victorian Imperial Bushmen]] for the [[Second Boer War|Boer War]], and was promoted from [[Corporal#Australia|Corporal]] to [[Squadron Quartermaster Sergeant#United Kingdom|Squadron Quartermaster-Sergeant]]. [[Major (United Kingdom)|Major]] Robert Lenehan enlisted him in the [[Bushveldt Carbineers]] with a commission as [[Lieutenant#Army ranks|Lieutenant]].
After the killing of a number of Boer prisoners, Witton was one of four officers charged by the [[British Army]] with murder, and was convicted.<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1301&dat=19020404&id=H-1hAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ypEDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6935,6526798&hl=en Sidney Morning Herald April 4, 1902 Witton wrote he had fired at a escaping Boer to keep him away, although later in "Scrapgoats of the Empire" He admitted that he had shot a escaping Boer prisoner who had tried to seize Witton's carbine]</ref> However, he strongly protested and secured a legal opinion from [[Isaac Isaacs]] [[Queen's Counsel|KC]], an Australian member of parliament, who recommended that he should petition [[Edward VII of the United Kingdom|HM the King]] for a pardon.<ref>[http://www.nla.gov.au/apps/doview/nla.aus-vn311069-p.pdf Opinion of the Hon. Isaac A. Isaacs K.C., M.P., re the case of Lieutenant Witton] at nla.gov.au, accessed 21 January 2012</ref> Kitchener commuted Witton's sentence to life imprisonment. After further protests, he was released on 11 August 1904, although not pardoned. He had been ill twice in prison in England, once from [[arsenic]] fumes in a metal shop and once from [[typhoid fever]]. He returned to Australia on 12 November 1904 embittered after three years in prison and wrote a book giving his version of the events involving Morant, Handcock and the BVC.
==''Scapegoats of the Empire'' book and later life== His book, ''Scapegoats of the Empire'' was originally published in 1907 by D. W. Paterson of [[Melbourne]], but was long unavailable. Prior to its reprint in 1982 by the Australian publishing house [[Angus & Robertson]], it is claimed that only seven copies of the book survived in various Australian state libraries and in the possession of Witton's family. Although unsubstantiated, it has long been claimed that the book was suppressed by the Australian government and most copies were destroyed;{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} another explanation is that most of the copies were destroyed by an accidental fire at the publisher's warehouse. The 1982 reprinting was inspired by the success of a film based on the book, entitled [[Breaker Morant (film)|''Breaker Morant'']].
Witton's main assertion, as indicated by the book's provocative title, is that he, Morant, and Handcock were made [[scapegoat]]s by the British authorities in [[South Africa]] — that they were made to take the blame for widespread British [[war crime]]s against the Boers, and that the trial and executions were carried out by the British for political reasons, partly to cover up a controversial and secret "no prisoners" policy promulgated by [[Horatio Kitchener, 1st Earl Kitchener|Lord Kitchener]], and partly to appease the Boer government over the killing of Boer prisoners, in order to facilitate a peace treaty; the [[Treaty of Vereeniging]] was signed on 31 May 1902.
Witton also claims that many of the accusations about them, which led to their arrest and trial, were made by disaffected members of their regiment whose rebellious behaviour had been suppressed by Morant and Handcock.
An embittered Witton did not rush to enlist in [[World War I]]. After former and future [[Prime Minister of Australia|Prime Minister]] [[Andrew Fisher]] pledged during the [[Australian federal election, 1914|1914 general election]] that Australia would defend Britain "[[Andrew Fisher#Third government 1914–15|to the last man and last shilling]]," Witton intimated that he would be that last man. He lived in [[Gippsland]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] and in [[Queensland]] where he was a dairy farmer. He married twice, but did not have any children. He had a heart attack while cranking his car engine, and died in a hospital on 14 August 1942. He was buried<ref>[https://online.brisbane.qld.gov.au/cemeteries/cemeteries_step3.jsp?mapdisplay=43325 Witton George Ramsdale] — Brisbane City Council Grave Location Search</ref> in [[Brisbane|Brisbane's]] [[Lutwyche Cemetery]] which, coincidentally, is located on the corner of Gympie and Kitchener Roads.
==2009 petitions for review of court martial == {{main|Pardon for Morant, Handcock and Witton}} In 2009, an Australian lawyer and naval reservist, Commander Jim Unkles, submitted personal [[petition]]s, requesting a review of the convictions for Morant, Handcock and Witton, to the [[The Crown]], in the form of: * [[Queen Elizabeth II]] personally, and; * the Australian government, in the form of the [[Australian House of Representatives]] Petitions Committee. The petitions committee considered Unkles' petition on 15 March 2010. He appeared before it, along with others including historian Craig Wilcox.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aph.gov.au/hansard/reps/commttee/R12891.pdf |title=Petition regarding the convictions of Morant, Handcock and Witton |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101017072314/http://www.aph.gov.au/hansard/reps/commttee/R12891.pdf |archivedate=17 October 2010 |df=dmy }}</ref> Committee member [[Alex Hawke]] MHR stated: "there is in my view serious and compelling evidence that some form of redress should be given, all these years later, to those men executed by the British".<ref>''Hansard'' "House of Representatives Grievance Debate", 15 March 2010.</ref> The then [[Attorney-General of Australia]], [[Robert McClelland (Australian politician)|Robert McLelland]] referred the petition to the UK government.
On behalf of the Crown, Unkles' petition was rejected by UK [[Secretary of State for Defence|Defence Secretary]] [[Liam Fox]], in November 2010.

{{Other uses|George Wright (disambiguation)}} {{Use British English|date=September 2011}} {{Infobox person | image_name = | name = George Edward Wright | other_names = José Luís Jorge dos Santos
Larry Burgess | image_size = | image_caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1943|3|29}} | birth_place = USA | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = USA, Portuguese | charge = [[Murder]], [[hijacking]], [[kidnapping]] | conviction_penalty = Up to 30 years in prison | conviction_status = Convicted, recaptured September 26, 2011 | occupation = | spouse = | children = }} '''George Edward Wright''' (born March 29, 1943){{cite web|title=INTERPOL Red Notice Listings From the United States |url=https://interpolnoticeremoval.com/tag/george-edward-wright/ |accessdate=April 6, 2011 }}{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} is a Portuguese citizen of American origin{{cite web|url=https://translate.google.com/translate?sl=pt&tl=en&js=n&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&layout=2&eotf=1&u=http%3A%2F%2Fsicnoticias.sapo.pt%2Fpais%2F2011%2F09%2F28%2Fforagido-george-wright-apanhado-em-portugal-atraves-de-chamada-telefonica | title=Foragido George Wright apanhado em Portugal através de chamada telefónica convicted kidnapper and murderer | publisher=SIC Noticias | date=September 26, 2011}} who, in 1961, graduated from [[Mary Bethune]] High School in [[Halifax, Virginia]].{{cite web|title=Awaiting Extradition U.S. Fugitive Is Far From His Hometown In Halifax|url=http://www.sovanow.com/index.php?/news/article/awaiting_extradition_u.s._fugitive_is_far_from_his_hometown_in_halifax/|publisher=News & Record|date=October 3, 2011}} Originally arrested and convicted for murder in 1962 and sentenced to up to 30 years in prison, George Wright escaped from prison in 1970 and hijacked a [[Delta Air Lines]] flight in 1972 with a number of accomplices. On September 26, 2011, he was arrested in Portugal.{{Cite news |title=U.S. Officials Reportedly Knew Fugitive Was in Africa |date=September 29, 2011 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |newspaper=[[Fox News]] |url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2011/09/29/us-officials-reportedly-knew-fugitive-was-in-africa/ }} The [[FBI]] requested Wright's [[extradition]] from Portugal to the United States, but was denied on the grounds that Wright is a Portuguese citizen.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-15778384 |title=George Wright 'wins extradition case in Portugal' |publisher=BBC.co.uk |date=November 17, 2011 |accessdate=November 17, 2011}} ==New Jersey offenses== ===Murder conviction=== On November 23, 1962, Friday night, the day after Thanksgiving, George Wright, then 19 and from [[East Orange, New Jersey]], and three accomplices: Walter McGhee of Sylvan Avenue in [[Asbury Park]], Elizabeth Roswell (McGhee’s live-in girlfriend), and Julio DeLeon of Munroe Avenue in Asbury Park; were involved in the commission of multiple armed robberies. The four suspects first robbed the Sands Motel in [[Englishtown, New Jersey|Englishtown]] of $200. They then made their way to the Collingswood Esso gasoline station on eastbound [[New Jersey Route 33|Route 33]] in [[Wall, New Jersey|Wall]]. At around 9:25 PM, during the second robbery, McGhee fatally wounded Walter Patterson, a 42-year-old [[World War II]] [[veteran]] and [[Bronze Star]] recipient who lived in [[Howell, New Jersey|Howell]]. Patterson was a father of two teenage daughters. Patterson, who earlier that evening had relieved his brother Harry C. Patterson Jr. and sent him home to have dinner with his family, was taken to [[Abram Fitkin#Raleigh Fitkin-Paul Morgan Memorial Hospital.2C New Jersey .281930.29|Fitkin Memorial Hospital]] in [[Neptune Township, New Jersey|Neptune]], where he died from the gunshot wound two days later. Wright, armed with a sawed-off [[.22]]-caliber rifle, and McGhee, armed with a [[.32 ACP|.32]]-caliber pistol, were both wearing women’s pantyhose over their faces when they assaulted Patterson. McGhee fired two shots during the robbery.{{cite web|last=Grant|first=Jason|title=Ambassador had no idea 41-year fugitive was escaped convict during encounters in Guinea-Bissau|url=http://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2011/09/ambassador_had_no_idea_41-year.html|publisher=The Star-Ledger|accessdate=September 29, 2011}} Patterson was shot once in the abdomen before the four got away with $70 in cash. Police later determined it was a shot from McGhee’s pistol that led to Patterson’s death.{{cite web|last=Webster|first=Charles|title=Fugitive's arrest brings relief to N.J. family 49 years after killing|url=http://www.mycentraljersey.com/article/C0/20111001/NJNEWS/310010034/|publisher=MyCentralJersey.com|accessdate=Oct 1, 2011}} The four were arrested two days later.{{cite web|last=Webster|first=Charles|title=Wall gas station attendant killer captured in Portugal after 41-year manhunt|url=http://www.app.com/article/20110927/NJNEWS/309270050|publisher=Asbury Park Press|accessdate=September 28, 2011}} On December 13, 1962, Wright was indicted on state charges along with his associates. McGhee, as the triggerman, was charged with Patterson’s murder and sentenced to a life prison term in February 1963, but was [[paroled]] in August 1977. Wright, as one of the holdup men, was also charged with murder. On February 15, 1963, Wright reportedly changed his [[plea]] from ''[[Not guilty (plea)|Innocent]]'' to ''[[Nolo contendere|No Defense]]'' to the charge of murder,In a process similar to what is called ''[[Alford plea]]''. in order to evade a jury trial that could have resulted in the death penalty. Wright was subsequently sentenced to 15 to 30 years’ [[incarceration]].{{cite web|title=International Fugitive Captured After More Than 40 Years|url=https://www.fbi.gov/newark/press-releases/2011/international-fugitive-captured-after-more-than-40-years|publisher=FBI Newark|accessdate=September 27, 2011}} ===Escape from prison=== On August 19, 1970, between 10 p.m. and 11 p.m., after serving over 7 years and 6 months of his sentence, Wright joined three inmates and "just walked out" between bed checks{{cite web|last=Fournier|first=Holly|title=Capture pulls Detroit hijacker from shadows|url=http://detnews.com/article/20111005/NATION/110050351/Capture-pulls-Detroit-hijacker-from-shadows|publisher=The Detroit News|accessdate=October 5, 2011}} from a state prison farm at Leesburg State Prison, now known as the [[Bayside State Prison]] in [[Leesburg, New Jersey]].{{cite web|title=US fugitive wants to serve time in Portugal|url=http://hosted2.ap.org/APDEFAULT/3d281c11a96b4ad082fe88aa0db04305/Article_2011-09-30-Hijacker-Fugitive-Captured/id-6fb25d5c30034d00ae5122cbce5e3da1|publisher=Associated Press|accessdate=Sep 30, 2011}} Wright escaped with his future hijacking accomplice, George Brown, who was serving a three to five-year sentence for a 1968 armed robbery conviction. Allegedly they stole the prison warden’s car to get away. They made their way to [[Detroit]], where they became affiliated with the [[Black Liberation Army]]. On August 26, 1970, federal complaints were issued in [[Atlantic City]], charging Brown and Wright with unlawful flight to avoid confinement.{{cite news|title=Escaped Murder Convict Among Skyjackers Of Jet|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2512&dat=19720803&id=RaNHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=N_8MAAAAIBAJ&pg=944,299273|publisher=The Morning Record|date=Aug 3, 1972}} ==Federal offenses== ===Hijacking and extortion=== On Monday [[July 1972#July 31.2C 1972 .28Monday.29|July 31, 1972]], Wright, then 29, together with:{{cite web|last=Newton |first=Michael |title=The Encyclopedia of Kidnappings (Facts on File Crime Library) |url=http://203.128.31.71/articles/0816044864.pdf |publisher=Facts On File, Inc. |year=2002 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425062736/http://203.128.31.71/articles/0816044864.pdf |archivedate=April 25, 2012 |df=mdy }}{{cite news|title=FBI Charges 5 - Escaped Convicts in Hijacking Plot|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1314&dat=19720803&id=j9kvAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Ye0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6757,843995|publisher=The Spokesman-Review|date=Aug 3, 1972}} * George Brown, then 28, of [[Elizabeth, NJ]], (alias Harry Singleton) with whom Wright escaped from prison * Joyce Brown (aka Tillerson), then 31, of [[Spartanburg, SC]], accompanied by her 2-year-old daughter * Melvin McNair, then 23, born in [[Greensboro, NC]] * Jean Carol Allen McNair, then 25, from [[Winston-Salem, NC]], accompanied by her 1-year-old daughter and 2-year-old son{{cite news|title=FBI Lists One Of Hijackers Fugitive Convicted Slayer|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1873&dat=19720803&id=EwkqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=stEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5747,413168|publisher=Daytona Beach Morning Journal|date=Aug 3, 1972}} boarded [[Delta Air Lines Flight 841]] in [[Detroit]]. The [[DC-8]] flight was bound for [[Miami]]. Wright was dressed allegedly as a priest and, using the alias the Rev. Larry Darnell Burgess, he smuggled a handgun aboard the flight in a hollowed-out Bible.[http://content.usatoday.com/communities/ondeadline/post/2011/09/portugal-nabs-nj-killerhijacker-on-the-run-since-1970/1 Portugal nabs N.J. killer/hijacker on the run since 1970], Michael Winter, ''USA Today'', September 27, 2011 One passenger described the apparent ringleader as a black male, about 30, wearing a black mohair suit which others described as a clerical outfit.{{cite news|title=Hijackers Order Jet to Algeria|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=iTxHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=zSwNAAAAIBAJ&pg=2636,8768&hl=en|publisher=The Palm Beach Post|date=Aug 1, 1972}} The pilot of the [[Aircraft hijacking|hijacked]] Detroit-Miami flight, Captain William Harold May, then 41 and a 20-year Delta employee, said Wright was the group's leader. The [[Aircraft hijacking|hijackers]], allegedly members of the [[Black Liberation Army]], seized the plane as it approached Miami, where they demanded that FBI agents (dressed only in bathing suits) deliver $1 million ransom to the plane; the FBI complied. The hijackers allowed the 86 hostage passengers to leave the plane in Miami, but kept the flight crew. They then ordered the plane to fly to [[Boston]], where they refueled and took on an international navigator. They then directed the plane to [[Algiers]], the capital of [[Algeria]], where they sought [[political asylum]] since that government had shown compassion towards those struggling for liberation. May told reporters that two of the hijackers smoked marijuana continuously during the flight, and commented, “They said they were revolutionaries, that America is a decadent society and they didn’t want to live here anymore.” Upon arrival in Algeria, Melvin McNair had parting words for his pilot: "We're famous," he said, "Send us a copy of your paper." On Wednesday August 2, 1972, federal complaints of air piracy charges were filed in Miami, naming the five accomplices as defendants.{{cite news|title=Hijackers Fled "Decadent America"|url=http://www.newspaperarchive.com/SiteMap/FreePdfPreview.aspx?img=115751502|publisher=Indiana Evening Gazette|date=Aug 3, 1972}}{{cite news|title=Cleaver Urges Algeria To Allow Ransom Be Kept|url=http://www.newspaperarchive.com/FreePdfViewer.aspx?img=50822025&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=3|publisher=Daily Messenger|date=Aug 3, 1972}} ====Asylum in Algeria==== Wright and his associates were briefly taken into custody but were released after a few days. Reportedly, Wright and his group were taken in by the American writer and prominent Black Panther [[Eldridge Cleaver]], whom Algeria's sympathetic Socialist government allowed to open an office. Cleaver wrote an open letter to the then Algerian President, [[Houari Boumediene]], in part:{{cite web|title=Cleaver Calls on Algerian President To Keep Black Skyjackers' $1 Million|url=http://www.itsabouttimebpp.com/underground_news/pdf/Jet_Articles_About_Party_6.pdf|date=Aug 7, 1972}} :''In humbleness and all sincerity, I think it would be consistent with the Algerian tradition of struggle and revolution to continue welcoming American revolutionaries ... whether they come to your shores or your airfields, penniless or with millions of dollars. ...'' :''To carry out our struggle for the liberation of our people, we must have money. Without the money to finance and organize the struggle, there will be no freedom.'' This hijacking represented the final test of the Third World nation's commitment to supporting some contingents of the African American freedom movement.{{cite web|last=Meghelli|first=Samir|title=From the Algiers Motel to Algiers, Algeria: Black Power in Transnational Perspective, 1962–78|url=http://aha.confex.com/aha/2010/webprogram/Paper3791.html|publisher=Columbia University|year=2010}} At the request of the U.S. government, the Algerian government confiscated and returned{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,910394,00.html|title=Algeria: Panthers on Ice|publisher=Time Magazine |date= September 4, 1972}} the $1 million in ransom money to the U.S. After the hijackers' calls to have the ransom money restored to them were ignored by the Algerian government, Wright and his associates disappeared. Allegedly in early 1973, the group traveled by ship to France and lived and worked there with new identities.{{cite news|last=Heiser|first=Jürgen|title=Nach 41 Jahren in Portugal verhaftet: Der frühere Black-Panther-Aktivist George Wright kämpft gegen seine Auslieferung in die USA|url=http://www.ag-friedensforschung.de/regionen/USA/wright2.html|publisher=AG Friedensforschung|date=October 6, 2011}} ====Apprehension and refused extradition of accomplices==== On May 26, 1976, Wright’s four associates were located in [[Paris, France|Paris]] and arrested by the French National Police for carrying false U.S. passports. Facing extradition to the United States, the four issued an appeal to the French people on October 11, 1976, claiming that while they were “ready to face the consequences of our act,” they could not expect a fair trial in America and “would be condemned to spend the rest of our days in infernal prisons.” French authorities declined the American extradition request in November 1976, holding the four defendants in the [[Fleury-Mérogis Prison|Fleury-Mérogis prison]], awaiting trial on hijacking charges. On November 24, 1978, the ''Fleury 4'' were convicted by a French court for the hijacking. All received five-year sentences, but two years were suspended from the women's terms. In the United States, they would have faced a minimum of 20 years.{{cite web|url=http://forum.davidicke.com/showthread.php?t=146174&page=7|title=Persecution or Prosecution?|publisher=David Icke's Official Forums}}{{cite news|title=Black Militants Get Prison Terms In Hijacking Case|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1876&dat=19781125&id=IIYsAAAAIBAJ&sjid=rs0EAAAAIBAJ&pg=2878,5736617|publisher=Spartanburg Herald-Journal|date=November 25, 1978}} The jury had found them guilty but noted "extenuating circumstances".https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1876&dat=19781125&id=IIYsAAAAIBAJ&sjid=rs0EAAAAIBAJ&pg=2878,5736617 George Brown and Melvin McNair were released in 1981. In 2012, a documentary titled ''Melvin & Jean: An American Story''http://melvinandjean.com was made by director Maia Wechsler.http://www.imdb.com/name/nm1372421/ IMDB bio Melvin McNair and his wife, Jean, work at an orphanage in the French town of [[Caen]], where reportedly they have turned their lives around completely.{{cite news|title=Retired Triad pilot recalls 1972 hijacking of airliner|url=http://www.news-record.com/content/2011/09/29/article/retired_triad_pilot_recalls_1972_hijacking_of_airliner|publisher=Associated Press|date=September 29, 2011}} McNair is known for coaching American baseball, teaching youth the art and strategy of the sport. In 2010, a documentary titled ''Nobody Knows My Name''http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1693798/ IMDB page was made about the hijacking. According to Mikhael Ganouna, producer of the film, Wright's hijacking accomplice, George Brown, lives in Paris but isn't worried about being extradited because he has already served his sentence.{{cite news|title=US officials knew fugitive in Africa|url=http://topnews360.tmcnet.com/topics/associated-press/articles/2011/10/01/224548-ap-exclusive-us-officials-knew-fugitive-africa.htm|publisher=Associated Press|date=October 1, 2011}} ====Extradition in a similar preluding hijacking==== The [[Delta Air Lines Flight 841|Flight 841]] hijacking was a [[copycat crime|copycat]] of a similar incident two months earlier, involving the hijacking of [[Western Airlines Flight 701]] from [[Los Angeles]] to [[Seattle]] on June 3, 1972 by [[Willie Roger Holder]], a black Vietnam veteran, and [[Catherine Marie Kerkow]], his white girlfriend. The hijackers claimed they had a bomb in an attache case and demanded $500,000. After allowing all 97 passengers to get off in San Francisco, they flew to Algeria where they were granted political asylum. The Algerian government confiscated and returned $488,000 of the ransom money to US officials. On January 25, 1975, the two hijackers, carrying passports under the names Leavy Forte and Janice Ann Forte, were arrested on illegal entry charges by French police. On April 15, 1975, a French court refused a US extradition request for the pair on grounds the hijacking was a political act. In July 1986, French authorities moved to deport Holder to the US after he completed his sentence for 1984 assault charges. Kerkow went missing, was never extradited, and her whereabouts and status remain unknown.{{cite news|title=Hijack suspects seized in Paris|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2206&dat=19750127&id=_EE0AAAAIBAJ&sjid=x-sFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6839,3016098|publisher=The Miami News|date=Jan 27, 1975}}{{cite news|title=Hijack Suspects Arrested|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=TIZPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=iQUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6061,4443636&hl=en|publisher=Ocala Star-Banner|date=Jan 26, 1975}}{{cite news|title=Skyjacker Wants To Return Home|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1992&dat=19770507&id=4jdcAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vFUNAAAAIBAJ&pg=6100,832107|publisher=Merced Sun-Star|date=May 7, 1977}}{{cite news|title=France hands over suspect in 1972 hijacking|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=336&dat=19860727&id=-xUpAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QYQDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2951,4392526|publisher=The Deseret News|date=Jul 27, 1986}} ==International fugitive captured== After the [[arrest|apprehension]] of his four accomplices, Wright remained the lone hijacker at large. The elusive [[fugitive]] is known to have made his way to France, [[Guinea-Bissau]] (a former Portuguese colony) and finally to Portugal. While living in Guinea-Bissau in the 1980s, Wright allegedly used his real name and worked as logistics manager of the Belgium-based nonprofit ''[http://www.ilesdepaix.org/ Iles de Paix]''.{{cite news|title=Fugitive hijacker George Wright 'socialised with US envoy in Africa'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/sep/30/george-wright-socialised-us-envoy-africa?newsfeed=true|website=guardian.co.uk|publisher=Guardian|date=September 30, 2011|location=London}}{{cite web|title=US fugitive lived openly in Africa|url=http://topnews360.tmcnet.com/topics/associated-press/articles/2011/10/02/224610-ap-exclusive-us-fugitive-lived-openly-africa.htm|publisher=Associated Press|date=October 2, 2011}} ===Apprehension=== On September 26, 2011, Wright was arrested in [[Mem Martins]], Portugal[https://maps.google.com/?ll=38.79385,-9.463393&spn=0.000615,0.0012&t=h&z=20&vpsrc=6%20%20Location%20of%20Wright's%20final%20capture%20in%20Portugal Location of Wright's final capture in Portugal] after 41 years on the run, as the result of a combined task force that introduced cold-case evidence from [[New Jersey]]. The task force matched Wright's fingerprints from the New Jersey prison with the fingerprints on the [[Identity document|ID card]] issued by the Portuguese government. The United States sought his extradition, with the possibility that he will finish the remaining 22 years of his sentence.{{cite news|author=Associated Press |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/sep/28/george-wright-hijacker-caught-portugal |title=George Wright, fugitive US hijacker, caught in Portugal after 40 years | World news | guardian.co.uk |publisher=Guardian |date= September 28, 2011|accessdate=September 28, 2011 |location=London}}{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-15085289|title=US killer George Wright held in Portugal after 40 years|publisher=BBC News |date= September 27, 2011}} However, the request was denied on the grounds that Wright is a Portuguese citizen.{{cite news|newspaper=New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/02/nyregion/george-wright-fugitive-us-killer-avoids-extradition-from-portugal.html|title=Deadline Past, Portugal Says It Won't Send Killer to U.S. | first=James|last=Barron|date=March 1, 2012}} ===Life in Portugal=== Wright, who lived under the name of José Luís Jorge dos Santos,{{cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/news/world/story/2011-09-28/fugitive-hijacker-arrested-portugal/50582770/1 |title=Longtime fugitive U.S. hijacker caught in Portugal |publisher=Usatoday.com |date=August 19, 1970 |accessdate=September 28, 2011}} had no known occupation, but allegedly at one point owned a [[BBQ]] chicken [[restaurant]], sold items at a stall along a popular tourist beach, worked as a [[Bouncer (doorman)|bouncer]] at a local bar and, similar to Melvin McNair, coached youth in American basketball. He married a Portuguese-English [[translator]] who was 13 years younger and, together, the couple had two children. His neighbors knew his first name was George, but did not know his history, assuming he was African, not American.{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/ap-exclusive-us-fugitive-hid-portugal-hamlet-112910927.html |title=AP Exclusive: US fugitive hid in Portugal hamlet - Yahoo! News |publisher=News.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=September 28, 2011}} ==References== {{reflist|3}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2011}} ==See also== *[[Delta Air Lines Flight 841]] * [[Aircraft hijacking]] * [[List of aircraft hijackings]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Wright, George}} [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:African-American people]] [[Category:American emigrants to Portugal]] [[Category:American escapees]] [[Category:American robbers]] [[Category:American people convicted of murder]] [[Category:Black Liberation Army]] [[Category:Date of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Escapees from New Jersey detention]] [[Category:Fugitives wanted by the United States]] [[Category:Hijackers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by New Jersey]] [[Category:People from Detroit]] [[Category:People from Halifax County, Virginia]]

'''George Ronald York''' (February 6, 1943 – June 22, 1965) and '''James Douglas Latham''' (April 21, 1942 – June 22, 1965) were an American [[spree killer]] team who are the most recent individuals [[Capital punishment|executed]] by the U.S. state of [[Kansas]].
==Killing spree== In late 1959, York and Latham met at [[Fort Hood]], [[Texas]], where both were [[private (rank)|privates]] in the [[United States Army]]. Latham had come to Fort Hood from [[Fort Carson, Colorado]], where he had undergone basic training between May and July 1959. In May 1961 York and Latham went [[AWOL]] and decided to travel to York's hometown of [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]], [[Florida]]. On May 26, they encountered Edward J. Guidroz in [[Mix, Louisiana|Mix]], [[Louisiana]]. York and Latham badly beat him and stole his truck. On May 29, they met Althea Ottavio and Patricia Hewitt, visitors from [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], in Jacksonville. According to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, York and Latham strangled both women, stealing their money and dumping their car in a ditch.
On June 6, York and Latham attempted to rob a man in a Cadillac near [[Aiken, South Carolina|Aiken]], [[South Carolina]], but the shots they fired at him missed and their would-be victim escaped. On June 7, York and Latham murdered John Whittaker in [[Tullahoma, Tennessee|Tullahoma]], [[Tennessee]]. They took Whittaker's car and abandoned the first truck they had stolen. On June 8 they abandoned Whittaker's car near [[Troy, Illinois|Troy]], [[Illinois]], and hitched a ride from a passerby named Albert Reed. They murdered Reed, dumped his body in a creek, and commandeered Reed's car. Several miles outside of [[Edwardsville, Illinois|Edwardsville]], Illinois, York and Latham killed gas station owner Martin Drenovac and stole gas and money from the station. York and Latham continued their cross-country killing spree in [[Wallace, Kansas|Wallace]], [[Kansas]], on June 9, where they robbed and killed 62-year-old Otto Ziegler; and near [[Craig, Colorado|Craig]], [[Colorado]], on June 10, they killed 18-year-old motel maid Rachel Moyer.
==Arrest and confession== Later on June 10, 1961, York and Latham were arrested in [[Tooele County, Utah]] for violating the federal [[National Motor Vehicle Theft Act]], which prohibited transportation of a stolen vehicle across state lines within the United States. On June 11, York and Latham bragged to investigators that they had killed eight or nine people since they left Fort Hood. Police later learned that nine people were attacked by York and Latham, but two had survived. York and Latham claimed that being placed in a mixed-race unit in the army led to their desire to desert.
Execution loomed over the pair in a number of different states; had they been tried by [[Florida]], [[Illinois]] or [[Tennessee]], they would have most likely been [[electric chair|electrocuted]]. Had they been tried by [[Colorado]] or [[Missouri]], they would have most likely been [[gas chamber|gassed]]. Ultimately, they were tried by [[Kansas]], where hanging was the prescribed method of execution.
==Trial and imprisonment== York and Latham were tried first in Kansas for the killing of Ziegler. They were convicted by a jury and sentenced to death on November 8, 1961.<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=IToRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YOkDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6785,1275227&dq= "2 GI's Who Boasted Killing 7 To Hang for Killing One Man"], ''[[Eugene Register-Guard]]'', 1961-11-08.</ref> While on [[death row]] in Kansas, York and Latham associated with [[Richard Hickock]] and [[Perry Smith (murderer)|Perry Smith]], the subjects of [[Truman Capote]]'s book ''[[In Cold Blood]]''. York and Latham's crimes are described in Capote's book, and they are portrayed in the work as flippant, snide, and lacking any degree of remorse.
==Executions== York and Latham were executed by [[hanging]] at [[Lansing Correctional Facility]] on June 22, 1965.<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4k4cAAAAIBAJ&sjid=l1EEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4934,3399879&dq=george+york+executed&hl=en "Killers executed in Kansas"], ''[[The Dispatch (Lexington)|The Dispatch]]'', 1965-06-22.</ref><ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=o-VLAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LosDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7480,7583185&dq=george+york+mauriceville&hl=en "Killers Repent Before Execution"], ''[[The Free Lance-Star]]'', 1965-06-23.</ref> Since their execution, no one has been put to death by the state of Kansas, though a number of prisoners have been sentenced to death. York and Latham were also the last persons executed by hanging in the United States until 1993, when the state of [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]] hanged [[Westley Allan Dodd]].<ref>Timothy Egan, [https://www.nytimes.com/1993/01/06/us/for-first-time-since-65-a-state-uses-its-gallows.html "For First Time Since '65, A State Uses Its Gallows"], ''[[New York Times]]'', 6 January 1993.</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== *Truman Capote (1966). ''[[In Cold Blood]]'' (New York: Vintage Books) *Truman Capote, [http://www.newyorker.com/archive/1965/10/16/1965_10_16_062_TNY_CARDS_000281542 "In Cold Blood: The Corner (Part IV)"], ''[[The New Yorker|New Yorker]]'', 16 October 1965, p. 62. *"Two Hanged in Kansas After Slaying 7 Persons", ''[[New York Times]]'', 23 June 1965, p. 21 *[https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0912FD3A5B147A93C0A8178DD85F458685F9 2 Soldiers tell of murdering 7], ''[[The New York Times]]'', 12 June 1961, p. 19 *[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=eKQRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vecDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5568,1855104&dq= Murder trail left by youths, police claim], ''[[The Age]]'', 13 June 1961, p. 8
==External links== *[http://www.truecrimelibrary.com/crime_series_show.php?id=686&series_number=13 True Crime Library: James Latham and George York] *[http://skcentral.com/articles.php?article_id=323 Serial Killer Central: George York and James Latham]{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} *{{Find a Grave|31125001|George Ronald York}} *{{Find a Grave|21687042|James Douglas Latham}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} [[File:Georges Couthon by François Bonneville.png|thumb|Georges Auguste Couthon by Bonneville]] [[File:Couthon signature, French politician during the French Revolution.jpg|thumb|Signature]] '''Georges Auguste Couthon''' (22 December 1755 – 28 July 1794) was a French politician and lawyer known for his service as a deputy in the [[Legislative Assembly (France)|Legislative Assembly]] during the [[French Revolution]]. Couthon was elected to the [[Committee of Public Safety]] on 30 May 1793 and served as a close associate of [[Maximilien Robespierre]] and [[Louis Antoine de Saint-Just]] until his arrest and execution in 1794 during the period of the [[Reign of Terror]]. Couthon played an important role in the development of the [[Law of 22 Prairial]], which was responsible for a sharp increase in the number of executions of accused counter-revolutionaries.
== Background == Couthon was born on 22 December 1755 in [[Orcet]] in the province of [[Auvergne]]. His father was a notary, his mother the daughter of a shopkeeper. Couthon, like generations of his family before him, was a member of the lower bourgeoisie. Following in his father’s footsteps, Couthon became a notary. The skills he acquired enabled him to serve on the Provincial Assembly of Auvergne in 1787, his first experience of politics.<ref>Geoffrey Brunn, "The Evolution of a Terrorist: Georges Auguste Couthon." ''The Journal of Modern History'' 2, no. 3 (September 1930): 410, {{JSTOR|1898818}}</ref> He was well-regarded by others as an honest, well-mannered individual.<ref>R.R. Palmer, ''Twelve Who Ruled: The Year of the Terror in the French Revolution'' (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press, 1941), 13</ref>
As the Revolution grew nearer, Couthon started to become disabled due to advancing paralysis in both legs. While doctors diagnosed Couthon with [[meningitis]] in 1792, Couthon blamed his paralysis on the frequent sexual experiences of his youth; although he began treating his condition with mineral baths, he grew so weak by 1793 that he was confined to a [[wheelchair]]<ref>Palmer, ''Twelve Who Ruled'', 13-14</ref> driven by hand cranks via gears.<ref>The wheelchair is still preserved in the [[Carnavalet Museum]].<!-- The museum dates it c.1780; was he using it at times well before 1793, then? --> See {{cite web|url=http://www.carnavalet.paris.fr/fr/collections/fauteuil-de-georges-couthon|title=Fauteuil de Georges Couthon|accessdate=2013-07-05}}</ref> His political aspirations took him away from Orcet and to Paris, where he joined the [[Freemason]]s in 1790 in [[Clermont-Ferrand|Clermont]]. While in Clermont, he became a fixture at its literary society, where he earned acclaim for his discussion on the topic of "Patience."<ref>Palmer, ''Twelve Who Ruled'', 13</ref> In 1791, Couthon became one of the deputies of the Legislative Assembly, representing [[Puy-de-Dôme]].<ref>Brunn, "The Evolution of a Terrorist," 411.</ref>
== Deputy == [[Image:Couthon1.png|thumb|left|Georges Auguste Couthon]] In 1791, Couthon traveled to Paris to fulfill his duty as a deputy in the Legislative Assembly. He then joined the growing [[Jacobin Club]] of Paris. He [[Left-wing politics#History of the term|chose to sit on the Left]] at the first meeting of the Assembly, but soon decided against associating himself with such radicals as he feared they were "shocking the majority."<ref>Bruun, “The Evolution of a Terrorist,” 416.</ref> He was a very proficient speaker, and there is evidence that he exploited his condition as a [[paraplegic]] in order to gain the ear of the Assembly on issues he found important.<ref>Bruun, "The Evolution of a Terrorist," 413.</ref>
In September 1792, Couthon was elected to the [[National Convention]]. During a visit to [[Nord (département)|Flanders]], where he sought treatment for his health, he met and befriended [[Charles François Dumouriez]], later writing praises of him to the Assembly, referring to him as "a man essential to us."<ref>Brunn, "The Evolution of a Terrorist," 420.</ref> His relationship with Dumouriez caused Couthon to consider joining the [[Girondist]] faction of the Assembly briefly, but after the Girondist electors of the Committee of the Constitution refused Couthon a seat on the Committee in October 1792, he ultimately committed himself to [[the Montagnards]] and the inner group formed around [[Maximilien Robespierre]] - a man with whom he shared many opinions, especially on religious issues such as revolutionary dechristianization (to which he was opposed- ''see [[Cult of the Supreme Being]]'')<ref>Bruun, "The Evolution of a Terrorist," 422-423.</ref> Couthon became an enthusiastic supporter of the Montagnards and often echoed their opinions. At the [[Trial of Louis XVI]] in December 1792, he argued loudly against the Girondist request for a referendum. He would go on to vote for the [[death sentence]] without [[appeal]].<ref>Bruun, "The Evolution of a Terrorist," 427-428</ref> On 30 May 1793, Couthon was elected to the [[Committee of Public Safety]], where he would work closely with Robespierre and Saint-Just in the planning of policy strategy and policing personnel.<ref>Colin Jones, ''The Longman Companion to the French Revolution'' (London: Longman Publishing Group, 1990), 90-91</ref> Three days after rising to this position, Couthon was the first to demand the arrest of proscribed [[Girondist]]s.<ref>David Andress, ''The Terror: The Merciless War for Freedom in Revolutionary France'' (New York: Farrar, Straus and Giroux, 2005), 177</ref>
== Lyon == Growing unrest had been occurring in [[Lyon]] in late February and early May. By 5 July 1793, the National Convention determined the city of Lyon to be “in a state of rebellion”, and by September, the Committee of Public Safety decided to send representatives to Lyon to end the rebellion.<ref>David L. Longfellow, "Silk Weavers and the Social Struggle in Lyon during the French Revolution, 1789-94," ''French Historical Studies'' 12, no. 1 (Spring, 1981): 22, {{JSTOR|286305}}</ref> Couthon would be the representative that Lyon would surrender to on 9 October 1793. He was suspicious of the unrest in Lyon upon his arrival, and would not allow the [[Jacobins]] of the local administration to meet with one another, fearing an uprising.<ref>Longfellow, "Silk Weavers," 23</ref>
On 12 October 1793, the Committee of Public Safety passed a decree that they believed would make an example of Lyon. The decree specified that the city itself was to be destroyed. Following the decree, Couthon established special courts that would supervise the demolition of the richest homes in Lyon, leaving the homes of the poor untouched.<ref>William Doyle, ''The Oxford History of the French Revolution'' (New York: Oxford University Press, 1989), 253-254.</ref> In addition to the demolition of the city, the decree dictated that the rebels and the traitors were to be executed. Couthon had difficulty accepting the destruction of Lyon and proceeded slowly with his orders. Eventually, he would find that he could not stomach the task at hand, and by the end of October, he requested the National Convention to send a replacement.<ref>Mansfield, Paul. "The Repression of Lyon 1793-4: Origins, Responsibility and Significance." French History, 1988: 74-101.</ref> [[First French Republic|Republican]] atrocities in Lyon began after Couthon was replaced on 3 November 1793 by [[Jean Marie Collot d'Herbois]], who would go on to condemn 1,880 Lyonnais by April 1794.<ref>Doyle, ''The Oxford History of the French Revolution'', 254</ref>
== Law of 22 Prairial ==
Following his departure from Lyon, Couthon returned to Paris, and on 21 December, he was elected president of the Convention. He contributed to the prosecution of the [[Hébertists]] and continued serving on the Committee of Public Safety for the next several months. On 10 June 1794 (22 Prairial Year II on the [[French Republican Calendar]]), Couthon drafted the [[Law of 22 Prairial]] with the aid of Robespierre. On the pretext of shortening proceedings, the law deprived the accused of the aid of counsel and of witnesses for their defense in the case of trials before the [[Revolutionary Tribunal]].<ref>"The Law of 22 Prairial Year II (10 June 1794)," George Mason University, http://chnm.gmu.edu/revolution/d/439/ (23 January 2012)</ref> The Revolutionary Tribunals were charged with quick verdicts of innocence or death for the accused brought before them.
Couthon proposed the law without consulting the rest of the Committee of Public Safety, as both Couthon and Robespierre expected that the Committee would not be receptive to it.<ref>Doyle, ''The Oxford History of the French Revolution'', 277.</ref> The Convention raised objections to the measure, but Couthon justified the measure by arguing that the political crimes oversaw by the Revolutionary Tribunals were considerably worse than common crimes because "the existence of free society is threatened." Couthon also famously justified the deprivation of the right to a counsel by declaring that ''the guilty have no right for a counsel and the innocents do not need any''.<ref>''Les coupables n'y ont pas droit et les innocents n'en ont pas besoin'' cited from [http://www.assemblee-nationale.fr/13/cr-miqm/07-08/c0708006.asp Compte Rendu Mission d’information sur les questions mémorielles] of the French National Assembly.</ref>
Robespierre assisted Couthon in his arguments by subtly implying that any member of the Convention who objected to the new bill should fear being exposed as a traitor to the republic.<ref>Simon Schama, ''Citizens: A Chronicle of the French Revolution'' (New York: Vintage Books, 1989), 836-837.</ref> Both Couthon and Robespierre would be seen as dictators due to their vehement defense of the Law of 22 Prairial, and popular opinion would turn against them in the coming weeks.
The law passed, and the rate of executions promptly rose. In Paris alone, compared to an average of 5 executions that was the norm two months earlier (Germinal), 17 executions would take place daily during Prairial, with 26 occurring daily during the following month of Messidor.<ref>Schama, ''Citizens'', 837.</ref> Between the passing of the Law of 22 Prairial (10 June 1794) and the end of July 1794, 1,515 executions took place at the [[Place de la Revolution]], more than half of the final total of 2,639 executions that occurred between March 1793 and August 1794.<ref>Doyle, ''The Oxford History of the French Revolution'', 275.</ref>
== Thermidor ==
During the crisis preceding the [[Thermidorian Reaction]], Couthon showed considerable courage, giving up a journey to Auvergne in order, as he wrote, that he might either die or triumph with Robespierre and liberty. Robespierre had disappeared from the political arena for an entire month because of a supposed nervous breakdown, and therefore did not realize that the situation in the Convention had changed. His last speech seemed to indicate that another purge of the Convention was necessary, though he refused to name names. In a panic of self-preservation, the Convention called for the arrest of Robespierre and his affiliates, including Couthon, Saint-Just and Robespierre's own brother, [[Augustin Robespierre]].<ref>Jones, Colin. The Longman Companion to the French Revolution. London: Longman Publishing Group, 1990.</ref> Couthon was [[guillotine]]d on 10 [[Thermidor]] alongside Robespierre, although it took the executioner fifteen minutes (amidst Couthon's screams of pain) to arrange him on the board correctly due to his paralysis.<ref>Lenotre, G. Romances of the French Revolution. Translated by George Frederic William Lees. New York: William Heinemann: 1909.</ref>
== Legacy == [[File:David d'Angers - Couthon.jpg|thumb|Bust of Georges Couthon by [[David d'Angers]] (1844).]] Couthon, during the course of the French Revolution, had transitioned from an undecided young deputy to a strongly committed law maker. Aside from his actions in Lyon, it is perhaps the creation of the Law of 22 Prairial, and the number of individuals who would be executed due to the law, that has become his lasting legacy. Following the acceptance of Couthon’s new decree, executions increased from 134 people in early 1794 to 1,376 people between the months of June and July in 1794. The Law of 22 Prairial also allowed tribunals to target noblemen and members of the clergy with reckless abandon, as the accused no longer could call character witnesses on their behalf. Of the victims executed during June and July 1794, 38 percent were of noble descent and 26 represented the clergy. More than half of the victims came from the wealthier parts of the bourgeoisie. Couthon's lawmaking not only greatly increased the rate of executions across France, but also brought the Terror away from mere counter-revolutionary acts and closer to social discrimination than ever before.<ref>Doyle, ''The Oxford Dictionary of the French Revolution'', 275</ref>
