{{Infobox person |name=Gregory Scarpa, Sr. |image=Scarpaa.jpg |caption= |birth_date= {{birth date|1928|5|8}} |birth_place= [[Brooklyn, New York]], United States |death_date={{death date and age|1994|6|4|1928|5|8}} |death_place= [[Rochester, Minnesota]], United States }}
'''Gregory Scarpa, Sr.''' (May 8, 1928 – June 4, 1994) nicknamed '''The Grim Reaper''' and also '''The Mad Hatter''', was an American [[Caporegime|capo]] and [[hitman]] for the [[Colombo crime family]] and an informant for the [[FBI]]. During the 1970s and 80s, Scarpa was the chief enforcer and a veteran [[hitman]] for Colombo boss [[Carmine Persico]]. Scarpa was responsible for committing three murders in 1991 and is suspected to have committed a minimum of 80 murders from the early 1950s through 1992. Scarpa is believed by the [[FBI]] to have murdered 100 to 120 people.
==Biography== Scarpa was born to first-generation immigrants, Salvatore and Mary, from the impoverished village of Lorenzaga of [[Motta di Livenza]] near [[Venice]], [[Italy]]. Scarpa was the older brother of Colombo mobster Salvatore Scarpa, who may have introduced Scarpa to the Colombo family. <ref name=mafia1>{{cite web|title=GREG SCARPA SNR. Part 1|url=http://realdealmafia.com/scarpa.html|work=Mafia-International.com|accessdate=3 October 2011}}</ref>
In the 1950s, Scarpa married Connie Forrest; she and Scarpa had one daughter and three sons, including Gregory Scarpa Jr. Greg Jr., who would follow his father into the Colombo family, eventually becoming a capo. Scarpa and Forrest separated in 1973.<ref name="Gman"/> Scarpa also maintained a 30-year relationship with girlfriend Linda Schiro that resulted in two children, Joseph and Linda.<ref>[http://wcbstv.com/local/schiro.trial.blog.2.458343.html "Squeeze Puts Squeeze On G-Man"] by Pablo Guzman WCBS</ref> Scarpa reportedly joined the Colombo family during the 1950s.
Scarpa was a stylish dresser who routinely carried $5,000 in [[wikt:pocket money|pocket money]] for purchases and bribes. Scarpa had use of an apartment on Manhattan's [[Sutton Place, Manhattan|Sutton Place]] and owned homes in [[Singer Island, Florida]], [[Staten Island]], [[Brooklyn]] and [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]]. His power, guile and brutality earned him the nickname "[[the Grim Reaper]]" and helped him escape prosecution for many years. Schiro later said that Scarpa would sometimes leave the numbers "666", the biblical [[Number of the Beast]], on his victims' [[pager]]s.<ref name=Schiro>{{cite news|last=Dunleavy|first=Steve|title=I LOVED A 'CUTE' KILLER MOLL TELLS OF BRUTAL SCARPA'S 'SENSITIVE' SIDE|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/loved_cute_killer_ihh3acPlYx2lPXzbQtWiGO|accessdate=19 October 2011|newspaper=New York Post|date=November 5, 2007}}</ref>
A career criminal, Scarpa eventually became a [[caporegime]] in the Colombo crime family, as well as the proprietor of the Wimpy Boys Social Club. Scarpa was involved in [[illegal gambling]], [[loansharking]], [[extortion]], [[Truck hijacking|hijacking]], counterfeit credit cards, assault, stock and bond thefts, narcotics and murder. Many of the highest-ranking members of the Colombo crime family today were members of Scarpa's crew.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/21/nyregion/21agent.html?_r=1&oref=slogin "The Mafia, an F.B.I. Agent and Murder: Mr. Scorsese, Your Next Film Awaits"] by Michael Brick ''New York Times''</ref> In March 1962, Scarpa was arrested for armed robbery. To avoid prosecution, Scarpa agreed to work as an undercover informant for the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI), beginning a 30-year relationship with the agency.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/30/nyregion/the-mob-and-angela-clemente.html?pagewanted=3&_r=0&hp&pagewanted=all | work=The New York Times | first=Alan | last=Feuer | title=The Mob and Angela Clemente | date=29 June 2013}}</ref><ref name="greg">[http://www.lacndb.com/php/Info.php?name=Greg%20Scarpa "Greg Scarpa"] La Cosa Nostra Database (LACNDB)</ref>{{Better source|reason=Per discussion at WP:RSN, www.lacndb.com is an anonymous, self-published website that is considered not to be a reliable source.|date=April 2013}}
===Mississippi civil rights workers=== {{main|Mississippi civil rights worker murders}} In the summer of 1964, according to Schiro and other sources, FBI field agents in [[Mississippi]] <ref>{{cite web|title=Mob moll says Mafiosi helped FBI |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20071029/ap_on_re_us/mob_fbi_agent|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071101052123/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20071029/ap_on_re_us/mob_fbi_agent|publisher=[[Yahoo!]]|date=October 29, 2007|archivedate=November 1, 2007}}</ref> recruited Scarpa to come to Mississippi to help them find missing civil rights workers [[Andrew Goodman]], [[James Chaney]], and [[Michael Schwerner]]. The FBI was convinced the three men had been murdered, but could not find their bodies. The agents thought that Scarpa, using illegal interrogation techniques not available to agents, might succeed at gaining this information from suspects. Once Scarpa arrived in Mississippi, local FBI agents allegedly provided him with a gun and money to pay for information. Scarpa and an FBI agent allegedly [[Pistol-whipping|pistol-whipped]] and kidnapped [[Lawrence Byrd]], a TV salesman and secret [[Ku Klux Klan|Klansman]], from his store in [[Laurel, Mississippi|Laurel]] and took him to [[Camp Shelby]], a local Army base. At Shelby, Scarpa severely beat Byrd and stuck a gun barrel down his throat. The terrified Byrd finally revealed to Scarpa the location of the civil rights workers' bodies.<ref name="Gman"/><ref>[http://www.abcnews.go.com/TheLaw/story?id=3792328&page=1 "Mob Solved 'Mississippi Burning' Murders?"] ABC News</ref>
The FBI has never officially confirmed the Scarpa story. In addition, the story contradicts evidence from investigative journalist [[Jerry Mitchell (investigative reporter)|Jerry Mitchell]] and Illinois high school teacher Barry Bradford, who claimed that Mississippi [[Mississippi Highway Patrol|highway patrolman]] Maynard King provided the grave locations to FBI agent [[Joseph Sullivan (FBI)|Joseph Sullivan]] after obtaining the information from an anonymous third party.{{Citation needed|date=August 2013}}
In January 1966, Scarpa allegedly helped the FBI a second time in Mississippi on the murder case of [[Vernon Dahmer]], killed in a fire set by the Klan. After this second trip, Scarpa and the FBI had a sharp disagreement about his reward for these services. The FBI then dropped Scarpa as a confidential informant. <ref name=mafia2>{{cite web|title=GREG SCARPA SNR. Part Two|url=http://realdealmafia.com/scarpa2.html|work=Mafia-International.com|accessdate=3 October 2011}}</ref>
===FBI informant=== In 1980, FBI agent [[Lindley DeVecchio]] became Scarpa's contact and handler, and restarted his relationship with the FBI. Scarpa had refused contact with the FBI for the previous five years, but DeVecchio persuaded him to cooperate again. Gregory Jr., Linda Schiro, and federal prosecutors later claimed that Scarpa had numerous illegal dealings with DeVecchio. Scarpa allegedly provided DeVecchio with cash, jewelry and other gifts along with information of questionable value on the Colombos. In return, DeVecchio allegedly protected Scarpa from arrest and provided him with information about his enemies during the Third Colombo war.<ref name="mob war">{{cite web|last=de Szigethy|first=J.R|title=MOB WAR! Part II Anatomy of a Frame-up|work=AmericanMafia.com|accessdate=19 October 2011}}</ref>
Over the years, the FBI reportedly paid Scarpa $158,000 for his services. According to mob associates, Scarpa would joke about "Girlfriend", a female friend in law enforcement who gave him information. For ten years, DeVecchio met alone with Scarpa, often at an apartment or hotel room provided by the FBI.<ref name="Gman"/> DeVecchio was a frequent dinner guest at Scarpa's house and on one occasion received a hard-to-find [[Cabbage Patch doll]] from Scarpa as a gift. Some of DeVecchio's fellow agents were disturbed by DeVecchio's closeness to Scarpa, and were soon reporting it to their FBI superiors.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=y-ICAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA46&lpg=PA46&dq=Scarpa+Mississippi&source=bl&ots=X-SINhl5kd&sig=z14bTZP1Tmx9Kfc7bHrvn-jbBSs&hl=en&ei=fNOsTN6RJoLknAfPtuDhDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CDQQ6AEwCDgK#v=onepage&q=Scarpa%20Mississippi&f=false "Who Handled Who"] by John Connolly New York Magazine December 2, 1996 (Google Books)</ref>
In 1985, federal prosecutors indicted Scarpa for running a major [[credit card]] scam. After Scarpa pleaded guilty, prosecutors asked the court to give him a sizable fine and a prison sentence. However, DeVecchio submitted a memo to the judge that listed all of Scarpa's contributions to the FBI. The judge finally sentenced Scarpa to five years [[probation]] with no prison time and a $10,000 fine. Colombo family members were so surprised by Scarpa's light sentence that some started wondering if he was working for the government.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=uQ6HaTCDOoAC&pg=PA115&lpg=PA115&dq=scarpa+Sr.+1985&source=bl&ots=fpw_HXXJpg&sig=rEcZbIIaAghmnR9l9ZLKBM9IYWY&hl=en&ei=0RCuTOnTN4H6lwfSw4GRAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CCUQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=scarpa%20Sr.%201985&f=false "Mafia Son: The Scarpa Mob Family, the FBI, and a Story of Betrayal"] By Sandra Harmon pp. 115–116 (Google Books)</ref>
===HIV Infection=== In 1986, Scarpa was diagnosed with [[HIV]]. After having emergency [[peptic ulcer|ulcer]] surgery at Victory Memorial Hospital in Brooklyn in 1986, Scarpa received several [[blood donation]]s from family members and associates. Scarpa had refused blood from the hospital [[blood bank]] because he feared that the blood might have come from [[African-American]]s, whom he despised.<ref name=mafia3>{{cite web|title=GREG SCARPA SNR. Part Three|url=http://realdealmafia.com/scarpa3.html|work=Mafia-International.com|accessdate=3 October 2011}}</ref> Scarpa eventually got blood from mobster Paul Mele, a [[body builder]] who was abusing [[steroids]]. Mele had contracted [[HIV]] from a dirty needle and transmitted it to Scarpa in the [[blood transfusion]].
Surgeons at [[Mount Sinai Hospital, New York|Mount Sinai Hospital]] in Manhattan eventually removed Scarpa's stomach. On August 30, 1992, Scarpa received a $300,000 settlement in civil court from his first surgeon and Victory Hospital for [[negligence]].<ref name=settlement>{{cite news|last=Tabor|first=Mary B. W.|title=Settlement in Lawsuit on H.I.V.-Tainted Blood|accessdate=25 November 2011|newspaper=New York Times|date=August 30, 1992}}</ref> As Scarpa's illness progressed to [[AIDS]], he and his relatives told everyone that he was suffering from [[cancer]].<ref name="Gman"/>
===Assassination attempt and retaliation=== In 1991, supporters of Colombo rebel [[Victor Orena]] attempted to kill Scarpa. Earlier in 1991, a struggle between imprisoned Colombo boss [[Carmine Persico]] and acting boss [[Victor Orena]] broke into violence. Persico's loyalists had unsuccessfully attempted to kill Orena at his Brooklyn home. In retaliation, Orena decided to murder Scarpa, one of Persico's strongest supporters. On November 18, 1991, Scarpa was driving his own vehicle followed behind by his daughter and grandson in Brooklyn when he was stopped by two cars. [[Hitmen]] ran from their vehicles with guns drawn and converged on Scarpa's car. But Scarpa managed to drive away from the ambush, crashing into anything that got in his way. A few bystanders were injured, but Scarpa and his relatives escaped unharmed.<ref name=junion>{{cite web|last=Bruno|first=Anthony|title=The Colombo Family: Junior's WAr|url=http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/gangsters_outlaws/family_epics/colombo/7.html|work=TruTV Crime Library|accessdate=19 October 2011}}</ref>
During the seven-month conflict between Persico and Orena, Scarpa served as Persico's military commander. Although weakened by illness, Scarpa constantly cruised along Avenue U in Brooklyn, looking for Orena supporters in social clubs and bars. Incensed by the murder attempt with his family, Scarpa was especially watchful for Orena loyalist [[William Cutolo]], who had organized it.<ref name=mafia3 /> Over the next few weeks, Scarpa and his associates killed Genovese crime family mobster [[Thomas Amato]] (a mistake) and Orena loyalists [[Rosario Nastasa]], [[Vincent Fusaro]], and [[James Malpiso]]. Scarpa allegedly shot Fursaro as he was hanging Christmas lights on his house.<ref name="Gman">[http://www.newyorker.com/archive/1996/12/16/1996_12_16_068_TNY_CARDS_000377271#ixzz11hUOGYMy "The G-man and the Hit Man"] by Fredric Danne ''New Yorker Magazine'' December 16, 1996</ref><ref name=mafia3 />
===Prison and death=== In 1992, Scarpa's AIDS lawsuit was settled with $300,000 in cash payments to his family.<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CEFDC1731F933A0575BC0A964958260&sec=&spon= "Settlement in Lawsuit on H.I.V.-Tainted Blood"] Mary B.W. Tabor New York Times</ref> In 1992, while appearing at a New York civil courtroom for his medical lawsuit, Scarpa was arrested for violating state firearms laws. Soon after, Scarpa was indicted on federal racketeering charges involving three murders.
On December 29, 1992, while under [[house arrest]] with an [[electronic monitoring]] device, Scarpa lost an eye in a shootout with other mobsters. Two [[Lucchese crime family]] mobsters, [[Michael DeRosa]] and [[Ronald Moran]], had threatened Joey Scarpa, Gregory's son, over a drug deal. Climbing out of bed, Gregory Scarpa drove with Joey to DeRosa's house and shot DeRosa twice. Moran fired back and hit Scarpa in the eye. Back at his house, Scarpa allegedly poured some [[Scotch Whisky]] into his wound, assured the authorities everything was fine, and later went to the hospital. Prosecutors revoked Scarpa's house arrest and sent him to jail.<ref name=mafia4 />
By 1993, Scarpa was blind in one eye, [[Emaciation|emaciated]] and in poor health. On May 6, 1993, Scarpa pleaded guilty to three murders and conspiracy to murder several others.<ref name="Gman"/><ref>[http://www.justice.gov/oig/special/0509/chapter3.htm "Special Report: Chapter Three: The Attorney General's Guidelines Regarding the Use of Confidential Informants"] Office of the Inspector General U.S. Department of Justice September 2005</ref> On December 15, 1993, Scarpa was sentenced to life in federal prison. This sentence was later reduced to ten years due to Scarpa's poor health<ref name=mafia4>{{cite web|title=GREG SCARPA SNR. Part 4|url=http://realdealmafia.com/scarpa4.html|work=Mafia-International.com|accessdate=3 October 2011}}</ref> On June 4, 1994, Gregory Scarpa Sr. died in the [[Federal Medical Center, Rochester|Federal Medical Center]] (FMC) for prisoners in [[Rochester, Minnesota]] from [[AIDS]]-related complications.<ref name="scarpa obit">{{cite web|title=Gregory Scarpa, Sr.|url=http://www.nndb.com/people/434/000024362/|work=NNDB|accessdate=17 October 2011}}</ref>
===Aftermath=== Scarpa's status as an informer was only revealed in 1995, during a racketeering and murder trial of seven members of the Orena faction. At that time, former Colombo family [[consigliere]] [[Carmine Sessa]], now a government witness, told prosecutors about DeVecchio's unusual and corrupt relationship with Scarpa.<ref name=canary>{{cite news|last=FRANCESCANI|first=CHRISTOPHER|title=MURDEROUS MOB CANARY SPRUNG|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/murderous_mob_canary_sprung_6jUvw4SDKcImtpGIiKDZiO|accessdate=3 October 2011|newspaper=New York Post|date=September 29, 2000}}</ref> Eventually, prosecutors were forced to reveal that DeVecchio might have revealed confidential information, including information about former Colombo wiseguys who had turned informer, to Scarpa. Ultimately, 19 Orena supporters had murder charges thrown out or murder convictions reversed after their attorneys contended DeVecchio's collaboration with Scarpa tainted the evidence against them. The attorneys argued that DeVecchio gave Scarpa information he used to kill members of the Orena faction, thus making any killings committed by their clients acts of self-defense.<ref name="Raab">Raab, Selwyn. ''The Five Families: The Rise, Decline & Resurgence of America's Most Powerful Mafia Empire''. New York: St. Martins Press, 2005.</ref>
On March 30, 2006, DeVecchio, who was forced to retire from the FBI in 1996, was indicted on charges of complicity with Scarpa and other Colombo mobsters in four murders during the 1980s and 1990s.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2006/03/30/nyregion/31mobcnd.html?scp=34&sq=%22Gregory%20Scarpa%20Sr%22&st=cse "Ex-F.B.I. Agent Accused of Role in Four Organized Crime Killings"] By JOHN HOLUSHA and WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM New York Times March 30, 2006</ref> The government case rested on the testimony of Linda Schiro, who was soon discredited as a witness after Tom Robbins of ''[[The Village Voice]]'' revealed that Schiro had granted an interview to Robbins and [[Jerry Capeci]] a decade earlier and denied DeVecchio had ever been involved.<ref>Robbins, Tom. [http://www.villagevoice.com/2007-10-23/news/tall-tales-of-a-mafia-mistress Tall Tales of a Mafia Mistress]. [[The Village Voice]], 2007-10-23.</ref> On November 1, 2007, the judge dismissed all charges against DeVecchio at the request of prosecutors.<ref> [[Michael Brick|Brick, Michael]]; O'Connor, Anahad. [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/01/nyregion/01cnd-devecchio.html?scp=5&sq=Scarpa%20DeVecchio%20dismissal&st=cse "Charges Dropped in F.B.I. Murder Case"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. November 1, 2007.</ref>

'''Gregory Scott Johnson''' (February 18, 1965 – May 25, 2005 at the [[List of Indiana state prisons|Indiana State Prison]] in [[Michigan City, Indiana]]) was [[Execution (legal)|legally executed]] for beating and stomping 82-year-old Ruby Hutslar to death in [[Anderson, Indiana]] on June 23, 1985. He then [[arson|set her house on fire]] in an attempt to conceal his crime.
Johnson sought a [[Pardon#Related concepts|reprieve]], asserting that he wanted to [[Organ donation|donate]] a portion of his [[liver]] to his ailing sister, 48-year-old Deborah Otis, who was suffering from non-alcoholic [[cirrhosis]] of the liver and was in need of a [[liver transplantation|transplant]]. His reprieve was denied because most doctors believe that it is [[Ethics|unethical]] to [[harvest organs]] after death by [[lethal injection]], and because Johnson was not a suitable donor himself. Another possibility – though not in [[Indiana]], where all organ recipients (except [[kidney]] recipients) are chosen by state law according to their places on a waiting list, on which list Johnson's sister herself did not appear – would have been a living partial organ donation prior to execution. The case for delaying execution probably was not helped by the fact that Johnson was infected with [[Hepatitis B]] himself, and that his liver was too large to be suitable for his sister. Patients in Indiana generally receive a liver after at least twenty days on a waiting list.
In a statement before his death, Johnson criticized the [[Parole Board]] for declining his request.
==References== *''Johnson v. State of Indiana'', 584 N.E.2d 1092 *[http://www.clarkprosecutor.org/html/death/US/johnson970.htm Gregory Scott Johnson] *[http://markgribben.com/?p=47 Gregory Scott Johnson: Bargaining for Clemency]

'''Greta Bösel''' (née '''Mueller''') (9 May 1908 – 3 May 1947) was a trained [[nurse]]. Born in [[Elberfeld|Wuppertal-Elberfeld]], [[Germany]], she became a camp guard at [[Ravensbrück concentration camp|Ravensbrück]] in August 1944.<ref name="Schäfer2002" />
Her rank at the camp was ''Arbeitseinsatzführerin'' (Work Input Overseer). In November 1944, Bösel was supposed to have been one of the staff members to select prisoners for the [[gas chamber]], or for transfer to [[Uckermark concentration camp|Uckermark]].<ref name="BazylerTuerkheimer2015">{{cite book|author1=Michael J. Bazyler|author2=Frank M. Tuerkheimer|title=Forgotten Trials of the Holocaust|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BMtRCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA128|date=1 December 2015|publisher=NYU Press|isbn=978-1-4798-9924-1|pages=141}}</ref> She is known to have told another SS guard "If they [prisoners] cannot work, let them rot."<ref name="Schäfer2002">{{cite book|author=Silke Schäfer|title=Zum Selbstverständnis von Frauen im Konzentrationslager. Das Lager Ravensbrück.|url=https://depositonce.tu-berlin.de/bitstream/11303/825/1/Dokument_35.pdf|publisher=TU Berlin|pages=266}}</ref>
After the death march of prisoners out of [[Ravensbrück concentration camp|Ravensbrück]] following the impending liberation by the [[Red Army]] of [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] troops, Bösel fled the camp with her husband. She was later caught and arrested by British troops.
Bösel, along with other female guards including [[Dorothea Binz]], stood accused at the first [[Hamburg Ravensbrück Trials|Ravensbrück Trial]], which took place between December 1946 and February 1947 in [[Hamburg]], Germany. The court found her guilty of maltreatment, murder and taking part in the "selections". She was executed for her crimes at 9:55 am<ref name="Schäfer2002" /> on 3 May 1947, 24 minutes after [[Elisabeth Marschall]],<ref name="Schäfer2002" /> by [[Albert Pierrepoint]] in [[Hameln]] prison.

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{no footnotes|date=January 2013}} [[Image:Kotoshikhin autograph.gif|frame|right|Manuscript of Kotoshikhin's book]] '''Grigory Karpovich Kotoshikhin''' (''Григорий Карпович Котошихин'' in Russian) ([[Circa|c.]] 1630 – November 1667) was a [[Russian people|Russian]] diplomat, [[podyachy]] of the [[Posolsky Prikaz]], and writer.
In 1658–61, Grigory Kotoshikhin was one of those sent on a [[diplomatic mission]] to negotiate the [[Treaty of Valiesar]] and [[Treaty of Kardis]] with [[Sweden]]. In the spring of 1664, he was dispatched to see Prince [[Yakov Cherkassky]] and take charge of his army's clerical work. In August, however, Grigory Kotoshikhin [[Defector|defected]] to the [[Lithuanians]] and moved to [[Silesia]]. After that, he went to [[Stockholm]] via [[Narva]] and was admitted to the Swedish service. Kotoshikhin converted from Orthodoxy to Lutheran Protestantism and adopted the name Ivan-Alexander Selitsky. In the fall of 1667, he was executed at [[Stockholm]] for killing, while drunk, the owner of the house where he had been living.
Grigory Kotoshikhin authored a work called ''On Russia during the Reign of [[Alexis I of Russia|Alexey Mikhailovich]]'' (first published in 1840), which represents a valuable source of history of the mid-17th century [[Tsardom of Russia]]. Kotoshikhin's historical account is quite detailed and correct, and most of the information in his book is confirmed by other sources of the 17th century. One has to consider the fact, however, that Kotoshikhin wrote his work at the request of the Swedish government and that some of his opinions on Russian 17th-century realities are [[bias]]ed.
== External links == * [http://www.shsu.edu/~his_ncp/Kotosh.html Grigori Kotoshikhin on the Education of the Princes and on the Private Life of the Boyars] – in English * [http://teacher.syktsu.ru/06/06_dokum/kotoshikhin/kotoshikhin.htm On Russia during the reign of Alexey Mikhailovich] – full online text in Russian *[https://books.google.com/books?vid=OCLC21573343&id=WaQKAAAAIAAJ&pg=PP9&lpg=PP9&dq=kotoshikhin Facsimile of above book] on Google Print.

(as the chairman of [[Verkhovna Rada]]) |office2 = Candidate member of the [[13th Politburo of the All-Union Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|13th]], [[14th Politburo of the All-Union Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|14th]], [[15th Politburo of the All-Union Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|15th]], [[16th Politburo of the All-Union Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|16th]], [[17th Politburo of the All-Union Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|17th]], [[18th Politburo of the All-Union Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|18th]] [[Politburo of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Politburo]] |term_start2 = 1 January 1926 |term_end2 = 22 March 1939 | birth_date = {{Birth date|1878|2|3|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Pechenihy Raion|Pechenihy]],{{cite web|url=http://who-is-who.com.ua/bookmaket/dnepropetrovsk/9/109.html|script-title=uk:Петровський Григорій Іванович (1878-1958)|trans-title=Petrovskyi Hryhoriy Ivanovych (1878-1958)|language=uk|publisher=Ukrainian Publishing Portal|date=2005|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091022043737/http://who-is-who.com.ua/bookmaket/dnepropetrovsk/9/109.html|archivedate=22 October 2009}} [[Kharkov Governorate]], [[Russian Empire]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1958|1|9|1878|2|4|df=y}} | death_place = [[Moscow]], [[Soviet Union]] | awards = [[Order of Lenin]] (2)
[[Order of the Red Banner]]
[[Order of the Red Banner of Labour]] (3) | party = [[Communist Party of Soviet Union|KPSS]] | otherparty = [[Communist Party (Bolshevik) of Ukraine|KP(b)U]] | alma_mater = elementary | spouse = | children = | signature = Grigoriy Petrovskiy Signature 1936.png }} [[File:Petrovskiy Grigoriy.jpg|200px|thumb|Grigory Petrovsky, 1917]] '''Grigory Ivanovich Petrovsky''' ({{lang-ru|Григо́рий Ива́нович Петро́вский}}, {{lang-uk|Григорій Іванович Петровський}} ''Hryhoriy Ivanovych Petrovsky'') (3 February 1878 - 9 January 1958) was a prominent Soviet communist. He participated in signing the [[Treaty on the Creation of the USSR]] and the [[Treaty of Brest-Litovsk]]. Petrovsky was one of the officials responsible for implementing [[Soviet collectivization|collectivization]]{{cite news|author=Rostyslav Khotin |url=http://www.unian.info/politics/294191-ukraine-tears-down-controversial-statue.html |title=Ukraine tears down controversial statue |publisher=UNIAN News |agency=BBC |date=27 November 2009 |accessdate=26 February 2016}}{{cite news|author=Ignacio Villarreal |url=http://artdaily.com/news/84748/Statue-of-controversial-Bolshevik-leader-Grigory-Petrovsky-toppled-in-Ukraine-#.Vs-rXNB23Ss |title=Statue of controversial Bolshevik leader Grigory Petrovsky toppled in Ukraine |publisher=Artdaily.com |agency=AFP |date=31 January 2016 |accessdate=26 February 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/6d623e32-f4bc-11e4-8a42-00144feab7de.html#slide0|title=Ukraine's Soviet past|publisher=FT.com|date=8 May 2015|accessdate=26 February 2016|subscription=true}} and for the subsequent [[Holodomor|Ukrainian famine of 1932-33]]. ==Biography== ===Early years=== Petrovsky was born in a village of [[Pechenihy Raion|Pechenihy]] in [[Kharkov Governorate]] on 3 February (Old Style - 22 January) 1878, in the family of a craftsman (some sources claim - son of tailor and laundrywoman). Grigory's father died when he was three. Petrovsky had two siblings. After finishing two classes of school at the Kharkiv Theological Seminary in 1889, Petrovsky was dismissed for not being able to pay for his tuition. Being 11 years old he left education for a job in the city working for a [[locomotive depot]]. In 1893 at age of 15 he arrived to Yekaterinoslav ([[Dnipropetrovsk]]) where he found a job at the Bryansk Metallurgical Factory (today - Petrovsky Factory). In 1895 Petrovsky joined the revolutionary movement and in 1897 enrolled in the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] (RSDRP) and joined the "Union in the fight for the liberation of the worker's class" as well as the Yekaterinslav committee of RSDRP. At this period of time he actively participated in the political agitation for the [[Bolsheviks]] from [[Mykolaiv]] to [[Mariupol]], from [[Donets basin]] to Kharkiv, for which he was arrested in 1900 and 1903. During the [[1905 Russian Revolution|Russian Revolution of 1905]] Petrovsky became one of the organizers and leaders of the Yekaterinoslav City Council of Worker's Deputies and the local Battle Strike Committee. However, he soon was forced to flee and for a brief period of time emigrated to [[Germany]]. In 1907 he returned to [[Mariupol]] where he worked as a [[turning]] specialist and continued his revolutionary activity at the factory "Russian Providence" (today - part of [[Ilyich Steel & Iron Works]]). ===Parliament and revolution=== In 1912 Petrovsky was elected a deputy to the Russian 4th [[State Duma of the Russian Empire|State Duma]] as a representative of workers of the [[Yekaterinoslav Governorate]] for [[Bolshevik]] faction. During this time he also was a chief editor of ''[[Pravda]]''. In January 1913 Petrovsky was included into the [[Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Central Committee of RSDRP]]. It is known that in the Duma he spoke on 32 occasions, while the text of his 21st speech was prepared personally by [[Vladimir Lenin]]. In his speeches Petrovsky was addressing the issues related to improving working conditions and life of miners and workers of [[Donets basin]]. With the start of [[World War I]] in November 1914 he was arrested along with the other six Bolshevik members of the parliament and in February 1915 was sentenced to a lifetime exile in [[Turukhansky Krai]] (today - the northern part of [[Krasnoyarsk Krai]]). After the Bolshevik seizure of power Petrovsky was appointed People's Commissar for the Interior Affairs between 30 November 1917 and 1 March 1919.{{cite web|url=http://www.elisanet.fi/daglarsson/dokumentit/sov.htm#LENIN|title=Government of the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic 1917-1923: Lenin|work=elisanet.fi/daglarsson|date=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716153010/http://www.elisanet.fi/daglarsson/dokumentit/sov.htm#LENIN|archivedate=16 July 2011}} In this post he oversaw the activities of the [[Cheka]] and was one of the advocates of the [[Red Terror]], he wrote in his order "A huge number of hostages has to be taken to the bourgeoisie, in cases of resistance these hostages have to be shot in masses(....) No hesitation in the application of the terror"Jacques Baynac, La terreur sous Lénine, 1975 He was a member of the Russian delegation during signing the [[Treaty of Brest-Litovsk]] in 1917. On 30 December 1922 he became the representative of [[Ukraine SSR]] in the [[USSR Central Executive Committee]] after signing the decree for the creation of the [[Soviet Union]]. According to the [[BBC]], "Petrovsky saw himself as an internationalist, and rejected [[Ukrainian nationalism]]". He was co-chairman of the USSR Central Executive Committee until 12 January 1938, when he was elected deputy chairman of the [[Presidium of the Supreme Soviet|presidium]] of the [[Supreme Soviet of the USSR]]. ===Survivor of the Great Terror=== He was not purged during the [[Great Purge|Great Terror]], but he was shocked and saddened by the executions of close friends such as [[Stanislav Kosior]], [[Vlas Chubar]] and [[Sukhomlin]].{{cite book|author=Roy Aleksandrovich Medvedev|title=Let history judge: the origins and consequences of Stalinism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ol1pAAAAMAAJ|year=1971|publisher=Knopf|isbn=978-0-394-44645-5}} Soon after the USSR celebrated its sixteenth birthday, he was interrogated by [[Joseph Stalin]], who told him, "We shoot people like you but you will be spared" and then was excluded from the Communist Party and deprived of his [[dacha]]s and apartments. After a year without a job, in 1940 he was made the director of the [[Revolution Museum of the USSR]] in [[Moscow]] and never returned to politics. During the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Second World War]], after the death of his son Leonid,{{cite web|author=Steen Ammentorp|url=http://www.generals.dk/general/Petrovskii/Leonid_Grigorevich/Soviet_Union.html|title=Biography of Lieutenant-General Leonid Grigorevich Petrovskii - Soviet Union|publisher=generals.dk|date=|accessdate=26 February 2016}} he asked Stalin in a letter to release his imprisoned son Peter, but he was subsequently shot. Petrovsky died in 1958. Petrovsky's body is interred near the [[Kremlin wall]] in Moscow.{{cite news|author=Rostyslav Khotin|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8380433.stm|title=Ukraine tears down controversial statue|agency=[[BBC News]]|date=27 November 2009|accessdate=27 February 2016}} ==Legacy== The city [[Dnipropetrovsk]] (originally named Yekaterinoslav) was named after Petrovsky from 1926 until 2016.{{cite book|author=Gary Kern|title=The Kravchenko Case: One Man's War on Stalin|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=leloAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA191|accessdate=27 February 2016|year=2007|publisher=Enigma Books|isbn=978-1-929631-73-5|page=191}} On 20 May 2016 the city was renamed "Dnipro".{{cite web|url=http://uatoday.tv/society/dnipropetrovsk-renamed-as-dnipro-651161.html|title=UNIAN News. Latest news of Ukraine and world|publisher=}} Some [[Ukrainians]] believed that the city should have been renamed after Ukraine gained independence in 1991. The city was eventually renamed to comply with [[decommunization in Ukraine|2015 decommunization laws]].[http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2015/05/15/7068057/ Poroshenko signed the laws about decomunization]. [[Ukrayinska Pravda]]. 15 May 2015
[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/265988.html Poroshenko signs laws on denouncing Communist, Nazi regimes], [[Interfax-Ukraine]]. 15 May 20
[http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-32267075 Goodbye, Lenin: Ukraine moves to ban communist symbols], [[BBC News]] (14 April 2015) A statue of Petrovsky in [[Kiev]] (the capital of [[Ukraine]]) was demolished in late November 2009, just days before the annual Ukrainian commemorating of the victims of the [[Holodomor]]. [[President of Ukraine]] [[Viktor Yushchenko]] had issued a decree ordering the removal of monuments to Soviet leaders, "in memory of the victims of the Holodomor". Ukrainian historians' consensus considers Petrovsky one of the main executors of Stalin's policies in Ukraine. Other historians, like [[Vasyl Marochko]], a member of an official commission that investigated the Holodomor, say that when Petrovsky realised the extent of the famine, he pleaded twice with Stalin to provide Ukrainians with more food but this request went unheeded. ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscatinline}} * {{ru icon}} [http://www.az-libr.ru/Persons/000/Src/0000/7876c958.shtml Biography] {{Soviet Ukraine Government (before 1938)}} {{Presidents of Ukraine}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Petrovsky, Grigory}} [[Category:1878 births]] [[Category:1958 deaths]] [[Category:People from Pechenihy Raion]] [[Category:People from Kharkov Governorate]] [[Category:Old Bolsheviks]] [[Category:Russian Social Democratic Labour Party members]] [[Category:Politburo of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union candidate members]] [[Category:Communist Party of Ukraine (Soviet Union) politicians]] [[Category:20th-century Ukrainian politicians]] [[Category:Heads of state of the Soviet Union]] [[Category:People's Commissars and Ministers of the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Members of the State Duma (Russian Empire)]] [[Category:Russian Constituent Assembly members]] [[Category:Chairmen of the Central Executive Committee of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] [[Category:Holodomor perpetrators]] [[Category:Soviet leaders of Ukraine]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Lenin]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the Red Banner]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the Red Banner of Labour]] [[Category:Burials at the Kremlin Wall Necropolis]] [[Category:Treaty of Brest-Litovsk]]

'''Grigory Leontyevich Valuyev''', also spelt as '''Voluyev''' ({{lang-ru|Григорий Леонтьевич Валуев}}) (? – after 1623), was a [[Russia]]n [[voyevoda]], the older of the two sons of [[Leontiy Valuyev]].
==Life== Grigory Valuyev (together with [[Ivan Voyeykov]]) made himself a name in May 1606 by fatally shooting [[False Dmitry I]] (according to other accounts, it was a Muscovite merchant by the name of Mylnik or Mylnikov who had made the fatal shot). Thus, Voluyev’s participation in the impostor’s assassination brought him closer to the court of [[Vasili IV of Russia]]. Grigory Valuyev was often used as a voyevoda/messenger between the tsar and his cousin [[Mikhail Skopin-Shuisky]] during the latter’s [[De la Gardie Campaign|trip to Novgorod]] in 1609. At the order of Mikhail Skopin-Shuisky, Grigory Valuyev (together with [[Semyon Golovin]], Prince [[Yakov Baryatinsky]], and [[David Zherebtsov]]) had to prevent the [[Lithuania]]n forces from crossing the [[Zhabyn River]]. On September 1, 1609, Valuyev, Golovin, and a Swedish commander [[Krister Somme|marshal Kristiern Somme]] occupied [[Pereyaslavl-Zalessky]] and then forced the Polish army out of [[Alexandrov (town)|Alexandrovskaya Sloboda]].
On January 9, 1610, Mikhail Skopin-Shuisky sent Grigory Valuyev with 500 soldiers to assist in relieving the [[Siege of Troitse-Sergiyeva Lavra]], laid by Polish commanders [[Jan Piotr Sapieha]] and [[Aleksander Józef Lisowski]]. After Mikhail Skopin-Shuisky’s sudden death in April 1610, Valuyev was transferred under the command of [[Dmitry Shuisky]] and sent to defend the western borders from the army of [[Hetman]] [[Stanisław Żółkiewski]]. On May 11, 1610, Grigory Valuyev together with Swedish commanders [[Jacob De la Gardie]] and [[Evert Horn]] expelled the Polish army from [[Joseph-Volokolamsk Monastery]] and rescued [[Patriarch Filaret (Feodor Romanov)|Metropolitan Filaret of Rostov]] from [[Roman Ruzhinsky]] (commander of [[False Dmitry II]]’s army in [[Tushino]]). After that, Valuyev and Prince [[Fyodor Yeletsky]] were put in charge of a unit stationed in a village of [[Tsaryovo-Zaymishche]] and responsible for providing cover for the army of Dmitry Shuisky (located near [[Mozhaysk]]). Stanisław Żółkiewski [[siege of Tsaryovo-Zaymishche|besieged Tsaryovo-Zaymishche]] and then led the rest of his army towards Mozhaysk, defeating the Russians at the [[Battle of Klushino]]. The hetman then returned to Tsaryovo-Zaymishche and offered the besieged to surrender.
Grigory Valuyev and Fyodor Yeletsky decided to capitulate and swore allegiance to [[Władysław IV Vasa]] on the conditions specified earlier by a Russian voyevoda and statesman [[Mikhail Glebovich Saltykov]] during his negotiations with [[Sigismund III Vasa]] (those conditions were as follows: 1) release of all Russian prisoners, 2) in case Władysław takes control over [[Smolensk]], Sigismund must abandon the city without causing any destruction or violence, 3) there will be no [[Catholicism]] in Russia). Valuyev, Yeletsky and their men joined the Polish army and headed towards Moscow, asking the Muscovites in a written message to swear allegiance to the new Russian tsar Władysław. As the ensuing developments illustrated, the Poles had no intention to fulfill these conditions.
After the enthronement of [[Mikhail Romanov]] in the summer of 1613, Grigory Valuyev showed himself as his zealous servant. In 1614, he was ordered to remain in Moscow to defend the city against a possible attack by the [[Nogai Horde]]. In 1615, Valuyev served as voyevoda in [[Vologda]] and was sent back to Moscow that same year. In 1617, he and a boyar named [[Boris Lykov-Obolensky]] were dispatched to Mozhaysk to defend the city against Władysław’s army. In 1618, Valuyev participated in the defense of Moscow against Władysław’s army. In 1619-1620, he was a voyevoda in [[Yelets]]. In 1621, Valuyev was sent as a second voyevoda to [[Vyazma]] to join Prince [[Alexei Sitsky]]. In 1623, he was dispatched to [[Astrakhan]] to serve together with Prince [[Ivan Fyodorovich Khovansky]]. Grigory Valuyev was married to a certain Ulyana Stepanovna, from whom he had the only son named Ivan.

{{Infobox murderer |name= Lonnie David Franklin Jr. |image= |caption= |birth_date= {{birth date and age|1952|08|30}} |birth_place= [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] |alias= Grim Sleeper
Southside Slayer |sentence= [[Capital punishment|Death]] |victims= 10-25+ victims, 1 survivor (known) |country= [[United States]] |states= California |beginyear= 1985 |endyear= 2007 (known murders) |apprehended= 2010 |children= 2 }} '''Grim Sleeper''' is the nicknameChristine Pelisek, [http://www.laweekly.com/2008-08-28/news/grim-sleeper/. Grim Sleeper Returns: He's Murdering Angelenos, as Cops Hunt his DNA], ''LA Weekly'', August 28, 2008[http://news.sky.com/story/631629/grim-sleeper-serial-killer-hunted Grim Sleeper Serial Killer Hunted ], SkyNews Report for convicted [[serial killer]] '''Lonnie David Franklin Jr.''',{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/grim-sleeper-guilty-killings_us_572bb5e3e4b016f37895382f|title=Man Found Guilty For All 10 'Grim Sleeper' Killings Of Women|date=2016-05-05|website=The Huffington Post|access-date=2016-05-05}} responsible for at least ten murders and one attempted murder in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]]. The attacker was dubbed the "Grim Sleeper" because he appeared to have taken a 14-year break from his crimes, from 1988 to 2002.{{cite web |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/38133825/ns/us_news-crime_and_courts/ |title=Arrest in 'Grim Sleeper' killings of ten women, man |publisher=MSNBC |accessdate=2010-07-08}} In July 2010, Franklin was arrested as a suspect, and, after many delays, his trial began in February 2016. On May 5, 2016, the jury convicted him of killing nine women and one teenage girl.{{cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/05/us/grim-sleeper-trial-verdict/index.html|title=Jury convicts 'Grim Sleeper' of 10 murders|last=CNN|first=Scott Glover and Paul Vercammen|website=CNN|access-date=2016-05-05}}{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/trial-begins-alleged-grim-sleeper-serial-killer-lonnie/story?id=36974945|title=Trial Begins for Accused 'Grim Sleeper' Serial Killer|date=2016-02-17|publisher=ABC News|access-date=2016-05-05}} On June 6, 2016, the jury recommended the death sentence,{{cite web |url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-grim-sleeper-death-verdict-20160606-snap-story.html|title=Jurors vote for death sentence for 'Grim Sleeper' serial killer|last=Times|first=Los Angeles|website=latimes.com|access-date=2016-06-06}} and on August 10, 2016, Los Angeles Superior Court sentenced him to death for each of the ten victims named in the verdict.{{Cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-grim-sleeper-sentencing-20160810-snap-story.html|title=The 'Grim Sleeper' is sentenced to death for string of murders|last=Gerber|first=Marisa|last2=Queally|first2=James|date=10 August 2016|website=latimes.com|publisher=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2016-08-10}} ==Personal life== Franklin was born on August 30, 1952. He grew up in [[South Central Los Angeles]]. He married and had two children. He was given a [[general discharge]] from the [[United States Army]] on July 24, 1975.{{cite web |last= Pelisek |first= Christine |title=Accused Grim Sleeper Lonnie Franklin Jr. Is the Ringmaster of His Own Murder Trial |url=http://www.laweekly.com/news/accused-grim-sleeper-lonnie-franklin-jr-is-the-ringmaster-of-his-own-murder-trial-4504291 |publisher=LA Weekly |date= 14 March 2014 |accessdate=2016-06-06}}url= http://www.people.com/article/grim-sleeper-serial-killer-lonnie-franklin-sentenced ==Investigation== In the 1980s, following the deaths of several women in [[south Los Angeles, California]], community members formed the "Black Women Count" movement. The group pressured police into setting up a task force and into acknowledging the deaths as serial killings. The coalition launched a media campaign and set a monetary reward aiming to capture the killer. The joint [[Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department]]-[[Los Angeles Police Department|LAPD]] investigation determined that the crimes were committed by a single person labeled the "Southside Slayer". Their results were announced to the public on September 23, 1985.{{cn|date=December 2016}} According to investigators, evidence was found suggesting that several serial killers were murdering women in south Los Angeles. Louis Craine committed at least two of the "Southside Slayer" murders, and [[Michael Hughes (serial killer)|Michael Hughes]], [[Daniel Lee Siebert]], [[Chester Turner]], and Ivan Hill at least one each.{{cite web |title= Map: Serial Killers in South L.A. |work= Los Angeles Times |date= 3 August 2010 |url= http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-serialkillersmap-0804-i,0,515310.htmlstory |accessdate= }} A separate series of killings commenced with the murder of Debra Jackson and a different [[modus operandi|MO]] involving a firearm.{{cite web |last= Jones |first= Jack |title= Man Sought in Slayings of 10 L.A.-Area Prostitutes |work= Los Angeles Times |publisher= |date= 24 September 1985 |url= http://articles.latimes.com/1985-09-24/news/mn-18536_1 |accessdate= }} These became known, misleadingly, as the "Strawberry Murders." Sheriff's Detective Rickey Ross was wrongfully arrested due to a ballistics error. Two decades later, the perpetrator of these crimes was dubbed the "Grim Sleeper" due to the long period of apparent inactivity between murders.{{cite web |author=Jill Stewart |url=http://www.laweekly.com/2010-07-15/news/missing-the-grim-sleeper-by-a-hair/1 |title=Missing the Grim Sleeper by a Hair|work=LA Weekly |date=2010-07-15 |accessdate=2010-12-18}} In May 2007, the slaying of Janecia Peters, 25, was linked through [[DNA]] analysis to at least 11 unsolved murders in Los Angeles, the first of which occurred in 1985. This same year, in secrecy, the LAPD formed the "800 Task Force," composed of six detectives and overseen by the Robbery-Homicide Unit. After a four-month investigation, the ''[[LA Weekly]]'' [[investigative journalism|investigative reporter]] Christine Pelisek broke the news of the task force's existence, the linkage of Peters' killing to the earlier murders, and the silence of Mayor [[Antonio Villaraigosa]] and Police Chief [[William J. Bratton]] regarding the killer's existence. The mayor and police chief neither issued a press release nor warned the community. In some cases, ''LA Weekly'' was the first to inform the families that their daughters had long been confirmed as victims of a serial killer. In early September 2008, Los Angeles officials announced that they were offering a $500,000 reward to help catch the killer. On November 1, the case was featured on the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] program ''[[America's Most Wanted]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.amw.com/fugitives/brief.cfm?id=60381/ |title=Most Wanted fugitives website (defunct) |date= |work=[[America's Most Wanted]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121022040939/http://www.amw.com/ |archivedate=2012-10-22 |accessdate=2015-02-20}}{{full citation needed|date=July 2010}} On February 25, 2009, Police Chief Bratton addressed the press for the first time regarding the case, at which time the police formally gave the killer the "Grim Sleeper" nickname chosen by ''L.A. Weekly''. Bratton also released a 911 call from the 1980s in which a man reported seeing a body being dumped by the Grim Sleeper, giving a detailed description and license plate number of a van connected with the now-closed Cosmopolitan Church.{{cite web |last=Pelisek |first=Christine |url=http://blogs.laweekly.com/ladaily/1tape-may-hold-clue-to-identif/ |title=Tape May Hold Clue to Identifying Grim Sleeper Serial Killer – Los Angeles News – The Informer |publisher=Blogs.laweekly.com |date=2009-02-25 |accessdate=2010-07-08}} In March 2009, reporter Pelisek did an extensive interview with Enietra Washington, the sole survivor of the Grim Sleeper's attacks.{{cite web |author=Christine Pelisek |url=http://www.laweekly.com/2008-08-28/news/grim-sleeper/4 |title=Grim Sleeper Returns: He's Murdering Angelenos, as Cops Hunt his DNA|work=LA Weekly |date=2008-08-28 |accessdate=2010-07-08}}{{cite web |author=Christine Pelisek |url=http://www.laweekly.com/2009-03-12/news/grim-sleeper-39-s-sole-survivor/2 |title=Grim Sleeper's Sole Survivor|work=LA Weekly |date=2009-03-12 |accessdate=2010-07-08}} She described him as "a black man in his early 30s...He looked neat. Tidy. Kind of geeky. He wore a black polo shirt tucked into khaki trousers." She also described the interior and exterior of his vehicle.{{cite web |author=Christine Pelisek |url=http://www.laweekly.com/2009-03-12/news/grim-sleeper-39-s-sole-survivor/ |title=Grim Sleeper's Sole Survivor|work=LA Weekly |date=2009-03-12 |accessdate=2010-07-08}} ==Arrest== On July 7, 2010, the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' reported that an arrest had been made. District Attorney Steve Cooley identified the suspect as 57-year-old Lonnie David Franklin Jr. (born August 30, 1952), a mechanic who worked between 1981 and 1988 for the City of Los Angeles in the sanitation department and briefly for the police department. Franklin was identified for arrest, at least in part, on [[DNA profiling#DNA evidence as evidence in criminal trials|familial DNA analysis]].{{cite news |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2010/07/lapd-make-arrest-in-grim-sleeper-serial-killings.html |title=LAPD make arrest in Grim Sleeper serial killings |publisher=Latimesblogs.latimes.com |date= 2010-07-07|accessdate=2010-07-08}} Police had found no exact match between DNA found at the crime scenes and any of the profiles in California's DNA profile database, so they searched the database for stored profiles that demonstrated sufficient similarity to allow police to infer a familial relationship. They found similar DNA belonging to Franklin's son, Christopher, who had been convicted of a felony weapons charge. According to [[Los Angeles County District Attorney|Los Angeles District Attorney]] Steve Cooley, detectives then used a piece of discarded pizza with Franklin's DNA to make the link. One Los Angeles undercover police officer pretended to be a waiter at a restaurant where the suspect ate. He collected dishes, silverware, glasses, and pizza crusts to obtain DNA. The identification was used to arrest Franklin after his DNA was obtained and deemed a match. Saliva found on the victims established a DNA match linking Franklin to the deaths. Law enforcement missed an opportunity to catch Franklin because his [[DNA]] was never collected. In 2003, he was convicted of a felony and was serving three years of supervised probation. In 2004, voters passed [[California Proposition 69 (2004)|Proposition 69]], which requires that DNA must be collected from all felons and everyone arrested on some specified charges. It also requires the expansion of the DNA database. Authorities collected and sorted through thousands of DNA samples. While he was on probation, Franklin's DNA was supposed to be entered in the [[DNA database]]. In July 2005, Franklin was on unsupervised probation, but his DNA was not entered into the system. Probation officers did not collect DNA samples from people who were on unsupervised probation between November 2004 and August 2005. During that period, the probation department did not have the resources to collect samples. Officers did not collect samples until August 2005.{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/jul/15/local/la-me-grim-sleeper-dna-20100715|title=Authorities Missed A Chance to Catch Grim Sleeper Suspect|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=2010-07-15|accessdate=2010-07-23|first=Jack|last=Leonard}} Franklin has a criminal record dating back to 1989. He was convicted of two charges of stolen property, one charge of misdemeanor assault, and one charge of battery. He served time for one of the charges of stolen property.{{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Nightline/familys-dna-led-police-grim-sleeper-serial-killer/story?id=11116381&page=2|title=New Technique of Using Family's DNA Led Police to 'Grim Sleeper' Suspect|publisher=ABC News|date=2010-07-08|accessdate=2010-07-23}} He was charged with ten murders and one [[attempted murder]]. He was held without bail until he received a death sentence.{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/jul/16/local/la-me-0716-grim-sleeper-search-20100716|title=Police Collect Hundreds of Pieces of Evidence from Grim Sleeper Suspect's Home|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=2010-07-16|accessdate=2010-07-23|first1=Andrew|last1=Blankstein|first2=Joel|last2=Rubin}} He is not charged in the death of an 11th suspected victim, a black man, a crime for which DNA evidence was not found.{{cite news |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20100709/ap_on_re_us/us_grim_sleeper_killings_34#mwpphu-container|title=LA 'Grim Sleeper' Probe to Check Unsolved Killings|publisher=Yahoo! News|date=2010-07-09|accessdate=2010-07-23}} On December 16, 2010, the Los Angeles Police Department released 180 photos of women found in Franklin's home. Police officials released the images after unsuccessful attempts to identify the individuals, possibly additional victims. "These people are not suspects, we don't even know if they are victims, but we do know this: Lonnie Franklin's reign of terror in the city of Los Angeles, which spanned well over two decades, culminating with almost a dozen murder victims, certainly needs to be investigated further," said Chief [[Charlie Beck]] of the LAPD. In all, investigators found over 1,000 photos and several hundred hours of video in his home.{{cite news |last=Whitcomb |first=Dan |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE6BF6EU20101216 |title=L.A. police release photos of possible Grim Sleeper victims |publisher=Reuters |date= 2010-12-16|accessdate=2010-12-18}} The images show mainly black women of a wide age range, from teenagers to middle-aged and older, often nude. Police believe Franklin took many of the pictures, which show both conscious and unconscious individuals, dating back 30 years. The photos were released to the public in an effort to identify the women.{{cite news |last=Hayes |first=Kevin |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504083_162-20026038-504083.html |title="Grim Sleeper" Photos: LAPD Deluged with Calls - Crimesider |publisher=CBS News |accessdate=2010-12-18}}{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/TheLaw/grim-sleeper-serial-killer-victim-photos-released-los/story?id=12424559 |title=Five Women Tentatively Identified in 'Grim Sleeper' Cas - ABC News |publisher=Abcnews.go.com |accessdate=2010-12-18}} On November 3, 2011, Reuters reported that the police were considering Lonnie David Franklin as a suspect in six more slayings of additional female victims. The police were investigating two of the six as potential victims killed during a 14-year lapse between an initial spate of "Grim Sleeper" murders that ended in 1988 and several more that began in 2002. Of the remaining four victims, two bodies were discovered in the 1980s and two were reported missing in 2005 but the remains of the other two were never found, police said. Detectives said they linked Franklin to the six additional killings after reviewing hundreds of old case files and seeking the public's help in identifying a collection of 180 photographs of women and girls that were found in his possession.{{cite web |last= Kandel |first= Jason |title= Police tie "Grim Sleeper" suspect to six more killings |work= |publisher= Reuters |date= 3 November 2011 |url= http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/03/us-crime-grimsleeper-idUSTRE7A20L120111103 |accessdate= }}{{cite web |last= Rubin |first= Joel |title= Police link 6 more slayings to Grim Sleeper suspect |work= Los Angeles Times |publisher= |date= 29 October 2011 |url= http://articles.latimes.com/2011/oct/29/local/la-me-grim-sleeper-20111029 |accessdate= }}{{cite web |last= Olivia |first= Katrandjian |author2=Lauren Effron |author3=Lauren Sher |author4=Neal Karlinsky |title= Six More Deaths Linked to Grim Sleeper Serial Killer |work= abc NIGHTLINE |publisher= abc NEWS |date= 29 October 2011 |url= http://abcnews.go.com/US/deaths-linked-grim-sleeper-serial-killer/story?id=14842183#.TwMkn_KDtXU |accessdate= }} On May 5, 2016, after nearly three months of trial and a day and a half of jury deliberation, Lonnie David Franklin was convicted of 10 counts of murder and one count of attempted murder.{{cite web |url=http://abc7.com/news/lonnie-franklin-jr-found-guilty-in-grim-sleeper-case/1325243/|title=Lonnie Franklin Jr. found guilty in 'Grim Sleeper' case|website=ABC7 Los Angeles|access-date=2016-05-05}}{{cite web |url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-grim-sleeper-verdict-20160504-story.html|title=Guilty verdicts in Grim Sleeper serial killer case|last=Times|first=Los Angeles|website=latimes.com|access-date=2016-05-05}} On June 6, 2016, a Los Angeles County jury sentenced the serial killer to death, closing an important legal chapter in the grisly slayings that terrorized South L.A. for more than two decades.{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-grim-sleeper-death-verdict-20160606-snap-story.html|title=Jurors vote for death sentence for 'Grim Sleeper' serial killer|first=James Queally, Marisa|last=Gerber|publisher=}} ==Victims== The known killings began in 1985 in [[South Los Angeles]]. The "Grim Sleeper" apparently took a 14-year hiatus after his last known crime in 1988 and the murders that resumed in 2002 (leading to the epithet by which he is known), but this history may be only an accident of the evidence collected. The last confirmed slaying was in January 2007. All of his victims were found outdoors, often in alleys a short distance from downtown [[Los Angeles]].{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2010/07/07/arrest-la-grim-sleeper-killings/|title=Arrest Made in L.A. 'Grim Sleeper' Killings|publisher=FOX News|date=2010-07-07|accessdate=2010-07-23}} All but one of his victims were black women. One of his suspected victims was a black man. Many of his victims were [[prostitutes]].{{cite web |last=Native |first=Proud |url=http://blogs.abcnews.com/nightlinedailyline/2010/07/grim-sleeper-suspect-arrested-in-los-angeles.html |title='Grim Sleeper' Suspect Arrested in L.A. - Nightline's Daily Line |publisher=Blogs.abcnews.com |date=2010-07-07 |accessdate=2010-12-18}} One witness recalls that Franklin frequently brought prostitutes into his home. He shot all of his victims with a .25 caliber gun. Franklin took many [[photograph]]s of nude women and kept the records in his garage.{{cite news |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20100708/ap_on_re_us/us_grim_sleeper_killings_23|title=Accused LA Serial Killer Said to Visit Prostitutes |publisher=Yahoo! News|date=2010-07-08|accessdate=2010-07-23}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} The Grim Sleeper's victims are as follows:{{cite web |url=http://www.tiki-toki.com/timeline/entry/260246/Grim-Sleeper-Investigation-Timeline#vars!date=1985-11-02_13:12:56! |title='Grim Sleeper' Timeline |publisher=grimsleeper.wordpress.com |accessdate=2014-03-25}}[http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-grim-sleeper-victims-snap-htmlstory.html Hailey Branson-Potts, "Grim Sleeper Victims: Who They Were," ''Los Angeles Times,'' February 16, 2016] {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Number ! Name ! Sex ! Age ! Body found ! Neighborhood |- | 1 | {{sortname|Debra|Jackson|nolink=1}} | F | 29 | {{dts|1985|August|10}} | [[Vermont-Slauson, Los Angeles]] |- | 2 | {{sortname|Henrietta|Wright|nolink=1}} | F | 34 | {{dts|1986|August|12}} | [[Hyde Park, Los Angeles]] |- | 3 | {{sortname|Thomas|Steele|nolink=1}} ‡ | M | 36 | {{dts|1986|August|14}} | [[Harvard Park, Los Angeles]] |- | 4 | {{sortname|Barbara|Ware|nolink=1}} | F | 23 | {{dts|1987|January|10}} | [[Central-Alameda, Los Angeles]] |- | 5 | {{sortname|Bernita|Sparks|nolink=1}} | F | 26 | {{dts|1987|April|15}} | [[Gramercy Park, Los Angeles]] |- | 6 | {{sortname|Mary|Lowe|nolink=1}} | F | 26 | {{dts|1987|November|1}} | [[Gramercy Park, Los Angeles]] |- | 7 | {{sortname|Lachrica|Jefferson|nolink=1}} | F | 22 | {{dts|1988|January|30}} | [[Westmont, California|Westmont, Los Angeles County]] |- | 8 | {{sortname|Alice "Monique"|Alexander|nolink=1}} | F | 18 | {{dts|1988|September|11}} | [[Vermont Square, Los Angeles]] |- | 9 | {{sortname|Enietra "Margette"|Washington|nolink=1}}‡‡ | F | 30 | Survived | [[Gramercy Park, Los Angeles]] |- | 10 | {{sortname|Princess|Berthomieux|nolink=1}} | F | 15 | {{dts|2002|March|19}} | [[Inglewood, California]] |- | 11 | {{sortname|Valerie|McCorvey|nolink=1}} | F | 35 | {{dts|2003|July|11}} | [[Westmont, California|Westmont, Los Angeles County]] |- | 12 | {{sortname|Janecia|Peters|nolink=1}} | F | 25 | {{dts|2007|January|1}} | [[Gramercy Park, Los Angeles]] |} ‡ One of the Grim Sleeper's suspected victims, although there is no DNA evidence to support the accusation. Police said that the male victim, Thomas Steele, possibly was a friend of another victim or had discovered the killer's identity.
‡‡ Enietra "Margette" was told to use her middle name as her last name for her protection, but has since come forward as Enietra Margette Washington. Attacked on November 20, 1988, she is the only known survivor. ==Arrest and trial== On July 7, 2010, Lonnie David Franklin Jr., 57, was arrested. The [[Los Angeles County District Attorney]]'s Office charged him with ten counts of murder, one count of attempted murder, and special circumstance allegations of multiple murders in the case.{{cite news |last= Simon |first=Mallory |title= Police Suspect in Los Angeles Grim Sleeper case to be arraigned |work= [[CNN.com]] |date= 2010-07-08 |url= http://www.cnn.com/2010/CRIME/07/08/grim.sleeper.case/index.html?hpt=T2 |accessdate= 2010-07-08}}{{cite news |last= The Associated Press |title= Police make arrest in 'Grim Sleeper' killings |work= [[msnbc.com]] |date= 2010-07-07 |url= http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/38133825/ns/us_news-crime_and_courts/ |accessdate= 2010-07-07}} Franklin has been in jail since his arrest awaiting trial; the large volume of evidence in this case, some dating back thirty years, had caused a lengthy pretrial [[Discovery (law)|discovery]].[http://losangeles.cbslocal.com/2013/12/02/grim-sleepers-defense-attorney-asks-to-photograph-nearly-900-pieces-of-evidence/ Grim Sleeper's Defense Attorney Asks To Photograph Nearly 900 Pieces Of Evidence], CBS Los Angeles (December 2, 2013). The trial was delayed several times and opened on February 16, 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyherald.com/article/20150206/news/302069980|title=Judge sets June trial date in 'Grim Sleeper' serial killings|first=BRIAN|last=MELLEY|date=6 February 2015|publisher=}}[http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-trial-delayed-in-grim-sleeper-serial-killings-case-20150522-story.html Trial delayed in 'Grim Sleeper' serial killings case, Marisa Gerber, ''Los Angeles Times'' (22 May 2015)][http://losangeles.cbslocal.com/2015/08/17/judge-postpones-trial-date-in-grim-sleeper-killings/ Judge Postpones Trial Date In Grim Sleeper Killings], CBS Los Angeles (17 August 2015).[http://www.laweekly.com/news/grim-sleeper-trial-delayed-yet-again-as-antics-continue-5926244 Grim Sleeper Trial Delayed Yet Again as Antics Continue], LA Weekly (17 August 2015).[http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-grim-sleeper-trial-20150817-story.html Grim Sleeper serial killings: Repeatedly delayed trial is set for Oct. 14], Los Angeles Times (17 August 2015).[http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-grim-sleeper-serial-killings-case-delayed-20150918-story.html 'Grim Sleeper' serial killings trial delayed again], Los Angeles Times (18 September 2015).[http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-grim-sleeper-serial-killer-trial-20160216-story.html Grim Sleeper serial killer trial begins, years after slayings terrorized South L.A.], Los Angeles Times (16 February 2016)[https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/feb/16/grim-sleeper-serial-killer-murder-trial-south-los-angeles-california 'Day of reckoning is here': Grim Sleeper murder trial begins in Los Angeles], The Guardian (17 February 2016) Closing arguments began May 2, 2016[http://losangeles.cbslocal.com/2016/05/02/closing-arguments-grim-sleeper-trial/?e=o8Tn-Ny*OAG9Ww Closing Arguments Begin In 'Grim Sleeper' Trial], CBS Los Angeles (2 May 2016) and the jury began deliberating May 4, 2016.[http://losangeles.cbslocal.com/2016/05/04/jury-begins-deliberating-case-of-accused-grim-sleeper-killer/ Jury Begins Deliberating Case Of Accused 'Grim Sleeper' Killer], CBS Los Angeles (4 May 2016). The jury convicted Franklin on all counts on May 5, 2016.[http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/05/us/grim-sleeper-trial-verdict/index.html Los Angeles jury convicts 'Grim Sleeper' of 10 murders] CNN (5 May 2016) On June 6, 2016, the jury recommended that Franklin should be sentenced to death.[http://abc7.com/news/decision-reached-in-penalty-phase-for-grim-sleeper/1373724/ 'Grim Sleeper', convicted serial killer Lonnie Franklin Jr., sentenced to death] ABC7 Los Angeles (6 June 2016) On August 10 the Superior Court sentenced Franklin on each count, naming the individual victims. ==Film== In 2014, British filmmaker [[Nick Broomfield]] created a documentary film about this serial killer, ''Tales of the Grim Sleeper."Overlooked by authorities in America, a British filmmaker tackles the Grim Sleeper", ''Toronto Star'', 25 April 2014, WD5. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== *Brittny Mejia, [http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-grim-sleeper-defense-backtracks-expert-witness-20151109-story.html Grim Sleeper: Defense Backtracks on Expert Witness,"] Brittny Mejia, ''Los Angeles Times,'' November 9, 2015 *Christine Pelisek, [http://www.laweekly.com/informer/2008/09/02/la-weekly-catches-grief-over-serial-killer-nickname LA Weekly Catches Grief Over Serial Killer Nickname], ''LA Weekly,'' September 2, 2008 *Joel Rubin and Richard Winton, [http://articles.latimes.com/2008/aug/29/local/me-killer29 Police on the Hunt for Serial Killer] Los Angeles Times,'' August 29, 2008 ==External links== *[http://www.lapdonline.org/grimsleeper Los Angeles Police Department "Grim Sleeper" page]{{mdashb}}features photographs of unidenified potential victims *[http://www.cnn.com/SPECIALS/2009/news/grim.sleeper/index.html] CNN Special Report;
