{{Infobox character|series=|name=Guy Montag|image=[[File:Guy_Montag.jpg|225px]]|caption=|first=''[[Fahrenheit 451]]''|last=|creator=[[Ray Bradbury]]|portrayer=[[Oskar Werner]]|lbl1=|data1=|family=Mildred (wife)}}'''Guy Montag''' is the protagonist in [[Ray Bradbury]]'s [[dystopia]]n 1953 novel ''[[Fahrenheit 451]]''. He is depicted living in a futuristic town where he works as a "fireman" whose job is to burn books.
==Role in plot== At the opening of the novel, he is happy in his work destroying books and never wonders about his role as a tool of [[thought suppression]]. Several events cause him to question his existence: *First, he meets [[Clarisse McClellan]], a 17 year-old while walking home from work. His talks with her are thought-provoking and assuage Montag's loneliness. Her death spurs him into becoming a radical. *Second, he discovers his [[Mildred Montag|wife]], who prefers watching "The Family" her favorite program on television or the parlor walls, and radio or "seashell earbuds" to human interaction, has overdosed on sleeping pills. The callous behavior of the paramedics makes him feel very [[Social alienation|alienated]], while his wife's emptiness disturbs and angers him. *Third, he has a call to go to a house owned by an old woman who hid away a library of books. Rather than be led out of the house before it is burned, she decides to set the fire herself, and burns alive with her books. *Fourth, he remembers a chance meeting he had one year previously with an old man in the park, who is later identified as [[Faber (character)|an English professor]]. Montag, who has secretly been hiding books in his own house, eventually makes contact with this man, named Faber. Over the course of the novel, Montag becomes increasingly disillusioned with the [[hedonism|hedonistic]], [[anti-intellectualism|anti-intellectual]] society around him. Bradbury emphasizes that the U.S. government, in burning books, is merely expressing the will of a people whose short attention spans, indifference, and hedonism have gradually eroded any semblance of [[intellectualism]] from public life. Schools no longer teach the humanities, children are casually violent, and adults are constantly distracted by "seashells" (small audio devices resembling [[earbud]]s) and insipid [[television]] programs displayed on wall-sized screens. Authors and readers are regarded as pretentious and dangerous to the well-being of society. He meets many characters that change his outlook on life such as Clarisse and Faber.
After an incident where Montag tries to read a poem to his wife's friends when they are visiting, his wife denounces their house as book-possessing. Montag's fire chief, [[Captain Beatty|Beatty]], tries to persuade him that books are evil, and urges him to return to the unthinking fireman mentality, but Montag refuses.
After the firehouse receives an alert, Beatty drives the fire truck to the location, which is Montag's house. Beatty forces Montag to set fire to his own house. After Montag is finished, Beatty confronts Montag and discovers the device he uses to communicate with Faber. After Beatty vows to track down who was on the other line, Montag turns the fire hose on Beatty and burns him to death.
He flees through the city streets to Faber's house, with another firehouse's mechanical hound and television network helicopters in hot pursuit. When he arrives at Faber's home, the old man tells Montag of vagabond book-lovers in the countryside. Montag then escapes to a local river, floats downstream and meets a group of older men who, to Montag's astonishment, have memorized entire books, preserving them orally until the law against books is overturned. The war begins. Montag watches helplessly as jet bombers fly overhead and attack the city with [[nuclear weapon]]s.
==In other media== Montag's fate is expanded on in the semi-canonical [[Fahrenheit 451 (video game)|1984 video game ''Fahrenheit 451'']], which acts as a sequel to the novel. In the game, Montag has continued to evade and resist the Firemen for over five years after the end of the novel and is sent on a mission to break into [[New York Library]] and transmit its microcassette archive to the Underground. He succeeds and reunites with Clarisse (who is alive in this version) during the process; however the Firemen storm the building and immolate them both.
==Historical notes== *Montag is portrayed by [[Oskar Werner]] in the 1966 [[Fahrenheit 451 (1966 film)|film version]]. *Bradbury notes that he found, after the book was published, that Montag is the name of a paper company, making him the counterpart to [[Faber (Fahrenheit 451)|Faber]], which is also the name of [[Faber-Castell|a pencil manufacturer]].<ref>Bradbury, Ray. Afterword. Fahrenheit 451: The 50th Anniversary Edition. By Ray Bradbury. New York: Ballantine Books, 1987. 173. Print.</ref>

{{Use Canadian English|date=June 2014}} '''Guy Paul Morin''' is a [[Canadians|Canadian]] who was wrongly convicted of the October 1984 [[rape]] and murder of his nine-year-old next-door neighbour, Christine Jessop of [[Queensville, Ontario|Queensville]], north of [[Toronto|Toronto, Ontario]]. [[DNA]] testing led to a subsequent overturning of this verdict. As of 2014, no one else has been charged with Jessop's murder.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|title = For Janet Jessop, October is a time to mourn murdered daughter Christine all over again|date = 15 August 2012|url = http://www.thestar.com/news/crime/2012/08/15/for_janet_jessop_october_is_a_time_to_mourn_murdered_daughter_christine_all_over_again.html|last = Rush|first = Curtis}}</ref>
== Murder of Christine Jessop == On 3 October 1984, Jessop was dropped off at her home from her school bus with both of her parents out.<ref name=":0" /> She was last seen by the owner of a nearby convenience store where she had gone to buy bubble gum. Her body was discovered on 31 December, nearly three months later. She had been sexually assaulted and murdered.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url = http://www.cbc.ca/archives/categories/society/crime-justice/cold-cases-unsolved-crimes-in-canada/christine-jessop-queensville-ont-1984.html|title = Cold Cases: Christine Jessop, Queensville, Ont. (1984)|accessdate = 6 February 2014|website = CBC Digital Archives}}</ref>
== Trials == Morin was arrested for Jessop's murder in April 1985.<ref name=":1" /> He was later acquitted at his first trial in 1986.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=OxgiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_KUFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5114,2939925|title=Appeal planned|date=6 March 1986|work=Montreal Gazette|page=B–1|accessdate=16 August 2010}}</ref> The [[Crown attorney|Crown]] exercised its right to appeal the [[verdict]] on the grounds that the trial judge made a fundamental error prejudicing the Crown's right to a fair trial.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-9YyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=pu8FAAAAIBAJ&pg=3062,2335594|title=Crown to appeal Morin's acquittal|date=6 March 1986|work=Ottawa Citizen|page=A–12|accessdate=16 August 2010}}</ref> In 1987 the [[List of Canadian courts of appeal|Court of Appeal]] ordered a new trial.<ref name="King">{{Cite web|url=http://www.nacdl.org/public.nsf/championarticles/19980808?opendocument|title=The Ordeal of Guy Paul Morin: Canada Copes With Systemic Injustice|last=King|first=Jack|date=August 1988|work=Champion Magazine|publisher=National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers|accessdate=16 August 2010|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5s2AJbWDF|archivedate=16 August 2010}}</ref> The retrial was delayed until 1992 by Morin's own appeals based on the Crown's non-disclosure of [[exculpatory evidence]] and by other issues, including the [[Double jeopardy#Canada|double jeopardy]] rule.<ref name="King" />
Morin was convicted at his second trial and was sentenced to [[life imprisonment]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.citytv.com/toronto/citynews/news/local/article/26005--canadian-cases-of-wrongful-conviction|title=Canadian Cases Of Wrongful Conviction|first=31 January 2007|work=CityNews|publisher=Rogers Broadcasting|accessdate=16 August 2010|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5s2BTxojR|archivedate=16 August 2010}}</ref> Unlike others convicted of murdering children after sexually abusing them, he was kept in the general population throughout his time in prison.<ref name=Nolan>{{Cite news|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/access/509274431.html?dids=509274431:509274431&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Oct+28%2C+1997&author=Dan+Nolan&pub=The+Spectator&desc=Morin+feared+for+his+life%3A+Jailers+rejected+isolation&pqatl=google|title=Morin feared for his life: Jailers rejected isolation|last=Nolan|first=Dan|date=28 October 1997|work=The Spectator|accessdate=16 August 2010|location=Hamilton, Ontario}}</ref> Up until his release, he was held at [[Kingston Penitentiary]].<ref name="Nolan" />
== Acquittal and aftermath == Improvements in [[DNA]] testing led to a test in 1995 which excluded Morin as the murderer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/11/world/queensville-journal-jailed-in-killing-he-s-guilty-only-of-being-a-misfit.html|title=Queensville Journal; Jailed in Killing, He's Guilty Only of Being a Misfit|last=Farnsworth|first=Clyde H.|date=11 April 1995|work=The New York Times|page=4|accessdate=16 August 2010|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5s2C5DQ15|archivedate=16 August 2010}}</ref> Morin's appeal of his conviction was [[Appeal#How an appeal is processed|allowed]] (i.e., the conviction was reversed), and a [[directed verdict]] of acquittal entered in the appeal.<ref name="King" />
An inquiry culminating in the [[Kaufman Report]] into Morin's case also uncovered evidence of police and prosecutorial misconduct, and of misrepresentation of forensic evidence by the [[Ontario Centre of Forensic Sciences]].<ref name="King" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/story/1998/04/09/morin980409c.html|title=Morin inquiry slams investigation|date=13 November 1998|work=[[CBC.ca]]|accessdate=16 August 2010|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5s2CWwlgM|archivedate=16 August 2010}}</ref> Morin received $1.25 million in compensation from the Ontario government.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/guy-paul-morin-case/|website=The Canadian Encyclopedia|publisher=Historica Canada|accessdate=26 February 2016}}</ref>
Christine Jessop’s murderer is still unknown.

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2014}} '''Guy Turcotte''', a canadian cardiologist murdered his two children in [[Prévost, Quebec|Prévost]], Quebec on February 21, 2009. He stabbed his 5-year-old son 27 times and his 3-year-old daughter 19 times as they slept in their bedrooms.<ref name="Superior court">{{cite web|title=R. c. Turcotte|url=http://www.jugements.qc.ca/php/decision.php?liste=74892544&doc=F3D1D8AD0E4FECAFCCF546E1881B7FBF5A62D8A02CD197602343CB2212393557&page=2|work=Société québécoise d'information juridique (SOQUIJ)|publisher=Société québécoise d'information juridique (SOQUIJ)|accessdate=March 3, 2014|author=Cour Supérieure|page=para:1|language=French}}</ref>
== Background == Dr. Guy Turcotte, born April 21, 1972,<ref name=Anonymous>{{cite journal|title=Father charged in children's deaths; Custody battle believed behind two killings|journal=Ottawa citizen|date=Feb 25, 2009 |pages=A.4.|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/241246083?accountid=14701|accessdate=March 3, 2014 |issn=0839-3222}}</ref><ref name="Montgomery 1">{{cite journal|last=Montgomery|first=Sue|title=Not criminally responsible verdicts three times higher here than B.C.; Facebook page protesting outcome of Guy Turcotte case draws 17,500 'fans'|journal=The Gazette |date=8 July 2011 |pages=A.9. |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/875695263?accountid=14701|accessdate=March 3, 2014 |issn=0384-1294}}</ref> worked with his wife Dr. Isabelle Gaston at Hotel-Dieu de Saint-Jerome as a cardiologist.<ref name=Anonymous /> He met and began a relationship with Gaston in [[Québec City]] in 1999. They moved in together in 2000, but their relationship became hostile to the point of domestic violence on both parts. Due to this violence, Turcotte moved out but reconciled with Gaston shortly after promising to work on their relationship. Following their reconciliation Turcotte proposed to Gaston at Mount Washington, New Hampshire; Gaston accepted his proposal. Gilles Turcotte (Guy Turcotte’s brother) said he "was attentive to his children and nieces and nephews… When Guy is playing with the children, we can see he is having as much fun as them…"<ref name="Katherine Wilton">{{cite news|last=Wilton|first=Katherine|title=Tearful Turcotte tells court of love for wife; Adored his children, murder trial hears |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/866986947|accessdate=March 1, 2014 |newspaper=The Gazette|date=May 10, 2011}}</ref>
In mid-January 2009, shortly before Gaston and Turcotte were planning to leave for a trip to Mexico with their children, Turcotte learned that his wife was having an affair with their personal trainer and friend Martin Huot. Huot’s girlfriend, Patricia Giroux, is the one who notified Turcotte of the affair and also provided proof by showing emails between Huot and Gaston. This angered Turcotte, and he felt betrayed. Although he didn't cancel the trip, Turcotte and Gaston decided to separate. Two days after coming home from their trip, Turcotte left the family residence. Gaston and the children stayed in the house, and both parents agreed to share custody.<ref name="Sue Montgomery 2">{{cite news|last=Montgomery|first=Sue|title=Turcotte says he felt betrayed; 'I lost my wife'; Killer describes six-year marriage|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/867000788|accessdate=March 2, 2014|newspaper=The Gazette|date=May 11, 2011 |location=Montreal, Quebec}}</ref><ref name="Cour d'appel">{{cite web |title=R. c. Turcotte Cour d'appel|url=http://www.jugements.qc.ca/php/decision.php?liste=74892544&doc=C42C1DA264592C5AE66B3A236E050F5EE9A67B192226B7CFC58E86277E645766&page=1|work=Société québécoise d'information juridique (SOQUIJ)|accessdate=March 3, 2014|author=Société québécoise d'information juridique (SOQUIJ)|language=French}}</ref>
During the separation, conversations between Turcotte and Gaston were often spiteful. On February 8, 2009, Turcotte found out that "the children had been to the Carnaval de Québec with their mother and Huot. The Carnaval reportedly had special meaning to him since he had lived in Quebec City for many years." Turcotte testified that "[a] hammer to the head would have hurt less… I could not accept that Martin spent time with my children...as if I was being replaced". The next day, a former neighbour told Turcotte that the day he left, Huot had spent the night with his family and had been staying there almost every night for the previous two weeks. Turcotte said during his testimony that the information "made him flip". On February 10, 2009, he went to his family's residence to fetch his son's sweater and found Huot in the kitchen. Turcotte said, "You stole my wife. You betrayed me, you were my friend" and punched Huot in the face before leaving the house.<ref name="Cour d'appel" />
On February 20, 2009, Turcotte drove by his old house, and Gaston ordered him to leave, telling him, "you are going to stop controlling my life...now, if I want to, I can change the children's names... I can get custody, I can move anywhere in Quebec". Turcotte was terrified of losing his children.<ref name="Cour d'appel" /> That day, while he was at work, colleagues noted "no outward signs" of distress.<ref name=Anonymous /> He had exchanged emails with Gaston and also picked up his children from daycare and school. He telephoned Gaston, who told him that she had changed the locks on the house and had consulted a lawyer. He was deeply hurt and took this as an "attack". He replied that if she wanted war, she was going to get it. That night, Turcotte felt dejected and began to cry. After putting the children to bed, he read dated emails from Gaston which further hurt and disheartened him. He wanted to end his life and searched the Internet for techniques to commit suicide.<ref name="Cour d'appel" />
== The murders == "On the morning of February 21, 2009, two police officers followed up on a call placed to 911 after the respondent had expressed suicidal thoughts to his mother. When they entered the respondent's home, the officers discovered the inert bodies of two children, a boy and a girl."<ref name="Cour d'appel" /> "Turcotte was under his bed, covered in vomit and blood. He told police he'd drunk windshield wiper fluid and wanted to die".<ref name="Sue Montomery 3">{{cite news|last=Montgomery|first=Sue|title=Doctor on trial for slaying children feared losing them; Separation 'tore me apart,' he tells court |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/866459918|accessdate=March 3, 2014 |newspaper=The Ottawa Citizen|date=May 12, 2011}}</ref>
In his testimony Turcotte recalled disordered scenes of the event: "He is standing in his son's room. He has a knife in his hands and stabs his son. His son cries out "no" and moves away. He realizes that he is hurting him. He panics and [translation] 'stabs him more'. He has a similar memory with respect to his daughter. He sees himself in the bathroom. He drinks windshield washer fluid. He has blood on his hands. He has hurt his children and looks for the knife to [translation] 'stab himself in the heart', but cannot find it".<ref name="Cour d'appel" />
==First trial== Turcotte portrayed himself and Gaston as professionals dealing with the stress of raising children and dealing with life.<ref name="Sue Montomery 3" /> He was charged with two counts of first-degree murder for the deaths of his two children. The trial began on April 12, 2011, and on July 5, the jury rendered a verdict of [[Mental disorder defence|not criminally responsible due to mental disorder]] (adjustment disorder with anxiety and depressive moods).<ref name="Superior court" /><ref name=FoundGuilty1/> The prosecution successfully appealed the verdict on grounds that the trial judge (the Honourable Mr. Justice Marc David, of the Superior Court, District of Terrebonne) had erred in law, mainly with respect to the issue of self-induced methanol intoxication in conjunction with a mental disorder.<ref name="Cour d'appel" />
==Psychiatric treatment and second trial== In 2012, Turcotte said that he was better than he was before the brutal stabbings in February 2009; he felt less shame, less guilt, had more self-esteem, and was ready to be released. Testifying before a mental health review board to determine whether to keep Turcotte another year at the [[Philippe Pinel Institute|Pinel Psychiatric Institute]] or release him to the care of his family, Turcotte said he was not a danger to anyone.<ref name="Sue Montgomery 4">{{cite news|last=Montgomery|first=Sue|title=Turcotte is 'a changed man,' ready for release, review board told|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/916124984 |accessdate=March 4, 2014 |newspaper=The Gazette|date=Jan 13, 2012}}</ref> Turcotte's lawyer, Pierre Poupart, announced in 2014 that he wanted to go to the [[Supreme Court of Canada]] in an attempt to challenge the appeals court ruling.{{clarify|date=July 2015|reason=What appeals court ruling? Was the appeal by the prosecution successful? What did the appeals court say, and when did it say it?}} [[Quebec Superior Court]] Justice Marc David, who presided over the first trial, postponed the date-setting until April 4, 2014 and said any new trial would not take place before March 2015. After spending 46 months in psychiatric care before being deemed fit for release from a mental institution, Turcotte remained behind bars awaiting trial.<ref name="Pierre Saint-Arnaud">{{cite news|last=Saint-Arnaud|first=Pierre|title=Guy Turcotte, Quebec Doctor Who Killed Kids, May Take Case To Supreme Court|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2014/01/10/guy-turcotte-doctor-killed-kids_n_4576037.html|accessdate=March 4, 2014|newspaper=The Huffington Post|date=Jan 10, 2014|agency=The Canadian Press}}</ref> On September 12, 2014, he was released on a $100,000 bail, and a new trial was scheduled for September 2015.<ref>{{cite news|title=Family angered as former Quebec doctor who killed kids granted bail|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/family-angered-as-former-quebec-doctor-who-killed-kids-granted-bail-1.2003998|accessdate=September 12, 2014|newspaper=CTV News|date=Sep 12, 2014|agency=The Canadian Press}}</ref>
In December 2015, Turcotte was found guilty of second-degree murder of his two children.<ref name=FoundGuilty1>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/guy-turcotte-trial-verdict-1.3330322|title=Guy Turcotte found guilty of 2nd-degree murder in deaths of his 2 children|language=English|date=December 6, 2015|publisher=CBC News}}</ref> On Friday, January 15, 2016, he was sentenced to life in prison, with 17 years before he can be eligible for parole.
==Movie== In 2014, Canadian director [[Chloe Bellande]] released a seventeen-minute short-film entitled ''Will of Fortune'', which was inspired by the murder trials of Turcotte and a woman, [[Susan Wright (murderer)|Susan Wright]], who had stabbed her husband nearly 200 times and buried his body in their back yard in [[Houston, Texas|Houston]], Texas. The film premiered at the [[Cannes Film Festival]] in May 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tvrs.ca/actualites/des-paysages-et-realisateurs-longueuillois-a-cannes |title=Des paysages et réalisateurs longueuillois…. à Cannes! |language=French |date=May 22, 2014 |publisher=TVRS |author=Gabrielle Lauzier-Hudon}}</ref>

[[Image:Robin shoots with sir Guy by Louis Rhead 1912.png|right|thumb|"Robin Shoots with Sir Guy" by [[Louis Rhead]]. Illustration to ''Bold Robin Hood and His Outlaw Band: Their Famous Exploits in Sherwood Forest'']] '''Sir Guy of Gisbourne''' (also spelled '''Gisburne''', '''Gisborne''', '''Gysborne''', or '''Gisborn''') is a character from the [[Robin Hood]] legends of [[English folklore]]. He first appears in "Robin Hood and Guy of Gisborne" ([[Child Ballads|Child Ballad]] 118),<ref>{{cite book|last=Gray|first=Douglas|editor=Stephen Thomas Knight|title=Robin Hood: An Anthology of Scholarship and Criticism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=69bYyY9xiKYC|year=1999|publisher=Boydell & Brewer Ltd|isbn=9780859915250|page=21|chapter=The Robin Hood Poems}}</ref> where he is a hired killer who attempts to kill Robin Hood but is killed by him. In later depictions, he has become a romantic rival to Robin Hood for [[Maid Marian]]'s love.
==Textual background== The Child ballad "Robin Hood and Guy of Gisborne" dates from 1650 but is much older than that,<ref>{{cite book|last=Knight|first=Stephen Thomas|title=Robin Hood: A Mythic Biography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dPtpkU1WSbcC&pg=PA153|year=2003|publisher=Cornell UP|isbn=9780801438851 | page=14}}</ref> judging from the similarities with the 1475 play, a fragment of which is preserved in the library of [[Trinity College, Cambridge]].<ref name=queer>{{cite journal|last1=Clark|first1=Robert L. A.|last2=Sponsler |first2=Claire |year=1997|title=Queer Play: The Cultural Work of Crossdressing in Medieval Drama|journal=[[New Literary History]]|volume=28|issue=2|pages=319–44|jstor=20057418 |doi=10.1353/nlh.1997.0017}}</ref>
==Summary of the Child ballad== Robin Hood and [[Little John]] walk through the forest. Robin speaks of a bad dream he had, of two men attacking him. While talking, they spot a distant stranger leaning on a tree. Little John tells Robin to wait while he approaches the stranger, but Robin objects as if accused of cowardice, telling John he'd like to break his head. John marches off in a huff, and is promptly captured by the Sheriff of Nottingham and tied to a tree, to be hanged. Meanwhile, Robin goes up to the stranger, Guy of Gisborne, who is clad in a horsehide robe.
Guy's outfit is described thus:
:''A sword and a dagger he wore by his side,'' : ''Of manye a man the bane;'' :''And he was clad in his capull-hyde'' [capull-hyde = horse-hide] : ''Topp and tayll and mayne'' : [''...''] :''‘I dwell by dale and downe,’ quoth hee,'' : ''‘And Robin to take I’me sworne;'' :''And when I am callèd by my right name'' : ''I am Guy of good Gisborne.’''<ref>{{cite book|last=Holt|first=J. C.|title=Robin Hood|year=1982|publisher=Thames & Hudson|isbn=0-500-27541-6 | pages=30–31}}</ref>
Guy is a hired killer seeking Robin Hood. They have a shooting contest, and Robin wins with ease. Robin identifies himself (as "Robin Hood of [[Barnsdale]]", in [[South Yorkshire]]) to the suspicious Guy, and the two fight. When Robin trips, Guy stabs him, but (after a brief prayer to Mary) Robin kills him with his sword. He dons the distinctive horsehide, cuts off Guy's head, sticks it on the tip of his bow and slashes the face, rendering it unrecognisable. He then blows Guy's horn to signal victory to the Sheriff. Disguised as Guy, and carrying what he passes off as Robin Hood's head, Robin goes to rescue Little John. He convinces the sheriff to be allowed to kill Little John, but instead cuts him loose with an "Irish knife".<ref>[[Sgian-dubh]]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://irisharchaeology.ie/2013/03/the-waterford-knife/|title=The Waterford Knife - Irish Archaeology|author=|date=|work=irisharchaeology.ie|accessdate=27 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://wayback.archive.org/web/20051028201029/http://www.knives.com/ireland_iron_age.html|title=Iron Age Ireland|first=|last=Daithi|date=|work=archive.org|accessdate=27 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wulflund.com/weapons/knives/scian-skean-irish-dirk-dagger.html/|title=SCIAN - Skean, Irish dirk - dagger|first=Drakkaria &|last=Wuflund|date=|work=wulflund.com|accessdate=27 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Hilton|first=R. H.|year=1958|title=The Origins of Robin Hood|journal=[[Past & Present (journal)|Past & Present]]|volume=14|pages=30–44|jstor=650091|doi=10.1093/past/14.1.30}}</ref> John then takes a bow and shoots the Sheriff through the heart.<ref>{{cite book|last=Knight|first=Stephen Thomas|title=Robin Hood: A Mythic Biography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dPtpkU1WSbcC&pg=PA153|year=2003|publisher=Cornell UP|isbn=9780801438851 | pages=15–16}}</ref>
==Guy of Gisbourne in popular culture== Although he has made many appearances in 19th and 20th century variants of the Robin Hood legends, Guy's only constant is villainy, but a frequently occurring theme is the "love triangle story" involving Robin, Marian, and Guy, a theme adopted from 19th-century theatrical adaptations.<ref name=knight153>{{cite book|last=Knight|first=Stephen Thomas|title=Robin Hood: A Mythic Biography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dPtpkU1WSbcC&pg=PA153|year=2003|publisher=Cornell UP|isbn=9780801438851 | page=153}}</ref>
===Fiction=== In [[Howard Pyle]]'s influential novel the ''[[Merry Adventures of Robin Hood]]'' (published in 1883), he is shown as a crude, coarse outlaw, known for his cruelty and murderous habits.<ref name=knight153/>
In [[Simon Hawke]]'s 1984 novel ''The Ivanhoe Gambit'', Sir Guy is the Sheriff of Nottingham and married to Marian, who runs off to join the Merry Men after three failed attempts to murder him.
In [[Stephen R. Lawhead]]'s 2006 novel ''Hood'' ([[King Raven Trilogy]]), Sir Guy, a knight-soldier, is the chief henchman of Abbott Hugo de Rainault.
In [[J Tullos Henning]]'s 2014 "The Wode" series, Guy, born Gamelyn, was a childhood friend and eventual lover to Rob before becoming a Templar and returning as Guy de Gisbourne.
===Film=== In the 1912 version of ''[[Robin Hood (1912 film)|Robin Hood]]'', he is determined to marry Marian and captures Robin Hood; he ties him to a tree, but by the end of the movie the roles are reversed.<ref name=knight153/>
In the [[Douglas Fairbanks]]-dominated silent movie ''[[Robin Hood (1922 film)|Robin Hood]]'' and the highly rated 1938 [[Errol Flynn]] film ''[[The Adventures of Robin Hood (film)|The Adventures of Robin Hood]]'', he is a nobleman, played by [[Paul Dickey]] and [[Basil Rathbone]], respectively. In these two versions, Guy is Prince John's chief supporter, and a far more prominent and dangerous man than the [[Sheriff of Nottingham]]. Prince John proposes Guy to [[Maid Marian]] as a prospective husband. Henceforth, Guy often appears as a bitter rival to Robin for [[Maid Marian]]'s affections.<ref>Allen W. Wright, [http://www.boldoutlaw.com/robbeg/robbeg4.html#gg "A Beginner's Guide to Robin Hood"].</ref> In the 1938 film, Robin engages Guy in a duel to the death, one of the most famous sword fights in cinema history, whilst in the 1922 film, Robin takes him on without a sword and kills him with his bare hands.
The role of Guy of Gisbourne has also been interpreted on film by [[Tom Baker]] (''[[The Zany Adventures of Robin Hood]]'', 1984), and [[Michael Wincott]] (in the movie ''[[Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves]]'') where he is said to be the Sheriff's cousin.
In the 2010 movie [[Robin Hood (2010 film)|''Robin Hood'']] directed by [[Ridley Scott]], actor [[Mark Strong]] mentions in promotional interviews that his character, Sir Godfrey, is based upon Guy of Gisbourne.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/movies/news/a135178/strong-joins-ridley-scotts-nottingham.html|title=Strong joins Ridley Scott's 'Nottingham'|last=Reynolds|first=Simon|date=10 November 2008|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=22 November 2013}}</ref>
===Television=== Gisbourne has been portrayed by [[Robert Addie]] (in the British [[television series]] ''[[Robin of Sherwood]]'', 1984-6) and, in the [[Robin Hood (1991 TV film)|1991 TV movie]], [[Jürgen Prochnow]] plays "Sir Miles Folcanet," a character with much in common with modern versions of Guy.
He was portrayed by [[Clive Revill]] in the ''[[Star Trek: The Next Generation]]'' episode ''Qpid'' in its fourth season. [[Q (Star Trek)|Q]] sends the crew of the [[USS Enterprise (NCC-1701-D)|USS Enterprise]] to a Robin Hood scenario of his creation where they must save the life of [[Jean-Luc Picard|Captain Picard's]] occasional paramour, [[List of Star Trek characters (T-Z)#Vash|Vash]], who must either marry Sir Guy or be executed.
In the 1990s [[CBBC]] comedy show ''[[Maid Marian and her Merry Men]]'', Guy—played by [[Ramsay Gilderdale]]—is the nephew of King John, and is portrayed in the series as an overgrown [[mother's boy]]. He is foolish to the point of being delusional, believing himself to have a friend from outer space named "Plop Bop". He dresses occasionally as a [[The Nutcracker|sugar-plum fairy]] or more usually as a court [[jester]], and is generally held in contempt by the heroes and villains alike.
In the BBC's 2006 [[Robin Hood (2006 TV series)|''Robin Hood'']], Guy of Gisborne is the third main character in series 1 and 2, and the second main character in series 3. He is portrayed much more seriously by [[Richard Armitage (actor)|Richard Armitage]], and is the Sheriff of Nottingham's second-in-command. He is originally depicted as a dark character, and is shown as an active enforcer of the Sheriff's cruelty, but at the same time, he is in love with [[Maid Marian|Marian]], showing conflicted attempts to redeem himself in her eyes.

{{about|the serial killer|the politician|Gwen Graham}} {{BLP sources|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox serial killer | name=Gwen Graham & Katherine Wood | image=Gwen Graham and Cathy Woods (mugshots).jpg | image_size=150px | caption=Mugshots of Gwen Graham (top) and Cathy Wood (bottom) | birthname= | alias=The Lethal Lovers | birth_date={{Birth date and age|1963|08|06}} (Graham)
{{Birth date and age|1962|03|07}} (Wood) | birth_place= | death_date= | cause= | victims=5 | country=[[United States]] | states=[[Michigan]] | beginyear= January 1987 | endyear= February 1987 | apprehended= December 1989 | penalty=[[Life imprisonment]] (Graham)
20 – 40 years imprisonment (Wood) }} '''Gwendolyn Graham''' (born August 6, 1963) and '''Cathy Wood''' (born March 7, 1962) are [[United States|American]] [[serial killers]] convicted of killing five elderly women in [[Walker, Michigan]], a suburb of [[Grand Rapids, Michigan|Grand Rapids]], in the 1980s. They committed their crimes in the Alpine Manor [[nursing home]], where they both worked as [[Unlicensed assistive personnel|nurse's aides]]. ==Crimes== The two women met at the Alpine Manor nursing home shortly after Graham had moved to Michigan from [[Texas]]. They quickly became friends, and then lovers, in 1986. Two years later they both were facing murder charges for allegedly smothering five elderly patients as part of a "love bond".{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-10-11/news/mn-356_1_lesbian-lover|title=Nation : Lesbian Sentenced in Murders|last=services|first=From Times wire|date=1989-10-11|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035|access-date=2016-09-17}} The details of the murders came almost entirely from accounts to criminal justice authorities by Wood, whose murder charges were reduced by a plea agreement so she could testify against Graham in Graham's trial for first-degree murder. However, Wood's accounts and her self-portrayal as Graham's pawn were later brought into serious question by award-winning journalist [[Lowell Cauffiel]] in his 1992 true crime book, ''Forever and Five Days''. According to Wood's account, in January 1987, Graham entered the room of a woman who had [[Alzheimer's disease]] and smothered her with a wash cloth as Wood acted as her lookout. The woman was too incapacitated to fight back, and thus became the pair's first victim. The woman's death appeared to be natural, so an [[autopsy]] wasn't performed. Wood claimed Graham murdered the patient to "relieve her tension." Each felt that the secret of the murder would prevent the other partner from leaving, thus cementing their bond. Over the next few months, Graham murdered four more Alpine Manor patients, Wood alleged. Many of the victims, whose ages ranged from 65 to 97, were incapacitated and suffered from Alzheimer's disease. Wood testified that the couple turned the selection of victims into a game, first trying to choose their victims by their initials to spell M-U-R-D-E. {{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DwNVbOcTncwC&q=Graham#v=snippet&q=Graham&f=false|title=The Encyclopedia of Serial Killers|last=Newton|first=Michael|date=2006-02-01|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=9780816069873|language=en}} But when that became difficult, they began counting each murder as a "day," as in the phrase, "I will love you for forever and a day." A poem by Wood to Graham, and introduced in the trial, concluded, "You'll be mine forever and five days." Wood also testified that Graham took souvenirs from the victims, keeping them to relive the deaths. However, no such souvenirs were ever discovered by police. Wood also portrayed Graham as being sexually, physically and emotionally dominant in their relationship. The couple eventually broke up when Graham began dating another female nursing aide who also worked at Alpine Manor. Graham then moved to Texas with the woman and began work in a hospital taking care of infants. The murder investigation began in 1988 after Wood’s ex-husband, whom she had told about the murders, went to the police. Detectives for the Walker Police Department extensively questioned Cathy Wood in a series of interviews. She incrementally leaked out her version of the homicides, portraying Graham as the mastermind and hands-on killer. The investigation led to the exhumation of two nursing home victims who had not been cremated. But when medical examination failed to reveal physical evidence of homicide, not entirely unusual in a smothering case, the county medical examiner nevertheless ruled the deaths homicides, basing it on the interviews Wood had given to the police. Warrants were issued for the arrest of Wood and Graham. On December 4-5, 1988, Graham and Wood were arrested and charged with two murders. Wood was apprehended in Walker; Graham in [[Tyler, Texas]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/12/06/us/2-held-in-deaths-at-nursing-home.html|title=2 HELD IN DEATHS AT NURSING HOME|last=Times|first=Ap, Special To The New York|date=1988-12-06|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-09-17}} During the trial, Wood [[Plea bargain|plea-bargained]] her way to a reduced [[Sentence (law)|sentence]], claiming that it was Graham who planned and carried out the killings while she served as a lookout or distracted supervisors. Graham maintained her innocence, testifying that the alleged murders were part of an elaborate "mind game" by Wood. Despite the lack of physical evidence, the jury ultimately was swayed by the testimony of Graham's new girlfriend, who revealed that Graham had confessed to five killings. On November 3, 1989, Graham was found guilty of five counts of murder and one count of [[conspiracy (crime)|conspiracy]] to commit murder, and the court gave her five [[life sentence]]s.{{cite web|url=http://mdocweb.state.mi.us/OTIS2/otis2profile.aspx?mdocNumber=206096 |title=Michigan Offender Tracking Information System |publisher=Mdocweb.state.mi.us |date=2012-11-03 |accessdate=2014-06-29}} Graham is housed in the [[Women's Huron Valley Correctional Facility]] in [[Pittsfield Charter Township, Michigan]]. Wood was charged with one count of second-degree murder and one count of conspiracy to commit second-degree murder. She was sentenced to 20 years on each count and has been eligible for parole since March 2, 2005.{{cite web|url=http://mdocweb.state.mi.us/OTIS2/otis2profile.aspx?mdocNumber=204315 |title=Michigan Offender Tracking Information System |publisher=Mdocweb.state.mi.us |date=2012-11-21 |accessdate=2014-06-29}} Wood is currently incarcerated in the minimum security [[Federal Correctional Institution, Tallahassee]] in [[Florida]]; she is expected to be released on June 6, 2021.{{cite web|url=http://www.bop.gov/iloc2/InmateFinderServlet?Transaction=NameSearch&needingMoreList=false&FirstName=CATHERINE&Middle=&LastName=Wood&Race=U&Sex=F&Age=49&x=77&y=17 |title=Federal Bureau of Prisons Inmate Locator |publisher=Bop.gov |date= |accessdate=2014-06-29}} However, as [[Lowell Cauffiel]] documents in his nonfiction book, friends, coworkers, family members and others who knew Graham and Wood told an entirely different story than the one Wood spun as the key witness in Graham's trial. They described Wood as both a coercive and seductive [[pathological liar]] who delighted in wreaking havoc in the lives of others. ''Forever and Five Days'' presents evidence that Wood planned the first murder after she found Graham with another woman. She involved Graham as an insurance policy to keep her from ever leaving her. When Graham left her anyway after the series of alleged killings, Wood was willing to put herself in legal jeopardy by disclosing to police to exact her revenge. The book portrays Wood as a [[psychopathy|psychopathic]] criminal mastermind who manipulated the prosecutor and the jury to punish Graham. Psychological testing also revealed Graham could be easily manipulated, suffered from [[borderline personality disorder]] and lacked the sophistication to plan the series of killings, let alone adequately defend herself in her trial. Wood, the book also reveals, later told inmates two other versions of events: The first, that she had made the entire story up to put Graham away for life for leaving her for another woman.The second, that she had done all the killing, but framed Graham, also for revenge. Several of the families sued the owners of Alpine Manor for hiring "dangerous and unbalanced employees". Alpine Manor has since gone out of business, but the building now houses a nursing home called "Sanctuary at Saint Mary's". == Media == The case was the basis of the 1992 [[True crime (genre)|true crime]] novel ''Forever and Five Days'' by [[Lowell Cauffiel]]. Graham and Wood were featured in two episodes of the TV series ''The Serial Killers'' in which they were interviewed about their relationship and crimes. They were also featured on an episode of ''[[Snapped: Killer Couples]]''. The television series ''[[American Horror Story]]'' tells a highly fictionalized version of their story in its sixth season, ''[[American Horror Story: Roanoke|Roanoke]]''. The duo are depicted as sisters Miranda and Bridget Jane. ==References== {{Reflist}} == Resources == *Buhk, T.T. and Cohle, S.D. (2008). Skeletons in the closet. New York: Prometheus Books. *Cauffiel, Lowell. ''Forever And Five Days: The Chilling True Story of Love, Betrayal and Serial Murder in Grand Rapids, Michigan''. Pinnacle, 1997. ISBN 0-7860-0469-X *"Woman Sentenced In Patients' Deaths" (Nov 3, 1989). ''Worcester Telegram & Gazette.'' ==External links== * [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=950DE7DE173FF930A35752C1A96F948260 New York Times: Ex-Nursing Home Aide Gets Life Term in 5 Patient Killings] * [http://www.crimezzz.net/serialkillers/G/GRAHAM_gwendolyn_WOOD.php Gwendolyn Graham and Cathy Woods] by Elisabeth Wetsch * [http://www.serialkillerstv.com/wood_graham.html The Serial Killers - Catherine May Wood and Gwendolyn Graham; The Lethal Lovers] * [http://www.state.mi.us/mdoc/asp/otis2profile.asp?mdocNumber=206096] {{DEFAULTSORT:Graham, Gwendolyn and Wood, Cathy}} [[Category:American female serial killers]] [[Category:Criminal duos]] [[Category:Lesbians]] [[Category:LGBT people from Michigan]] [[Category:Violence against women]] [[Category:1987 murders in the United States]] [[Category:20th-century American criminals]] [[Category:Health care professionals convicted of murdering patients]] [[Category:People from Grand Rapids, Michigan]] [[Category:People from Tyler, Texas]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:1963 births]]

{{Infobox character | name = Giuseppe Colombano "Gyp" Rosetti | series = [[Boardwalk Empire]] | image = Gyp Rosetti.jpg | caption = Promo image of Gyp Rosetti from season 3 of Boardwalk Empire. | first = "Resolution" | last = "Margate Sands" | creator = [[Terence Winter]] | portrayer = [[Bobby Cannavale]] | occupation = [[Caporegime|Capo]] for the Morello crime family }}
''' Giuseppe Colombano "Gyp" Rosetti''' is a character in ''[[Boardwalk Empire]]'', portrayed by [[Bobby Cannavale]]. Rosetti is a [[New York City]] gangster who works for [[Joe Masseria]] (Ivo Nandi). Hot-headed and easily offended, he is the primary antagonist of season three.
==Fictional biography== Rosetti was born in [[Sperlinga]], a small Italian commune in [[Sicily]]. He grew up in poverty, living in a hut carved into a cave. His father was a brick layer who died when he was 50.<ref name="thepony">{{Cite episode|title=The Pony|episodelink=Boardwalk Empire (season 3)#ep8|series=Boardwalk Empire|serieslink=Boardwalk Empire|network=HBO|airdate=November 4, 2012|season=3|number=8}}</ref> Rosetti eventually emigrated to the United States and began working for Italian mob boss Joe Masseria. He runs brothels, [[speakeasy|speakeasies]] and illegal gambling dens in southern [[Manhattan]].<ref name="Resolution">{{Cite episode|title=Resolution|episodelink=Boardwalk Empire (season 3)#ep1|series=Boardwalk Empire|serieslink=Boardwalk Empire|network=HBO|airdate=September 16, 2012|season=3|number=1}}</ref> He lives in an apartment with his wife, two daughters and mother-in-law. Although Rosetti regularly kills people over slight insults, he does not retaliate when his wife and mother-in-law openly mock him.<ref name="sundaybest">{{Cite episode|title=Sunday Best|episodelink=Boardwalk Empire (season 3)#ep7|series=Boardwalk Empire|serieslink=Boardwalk Empire|network=HBO|airdate=October 28, 2012|season=3|number=7}}</ref> He is also depicted as having [[BDSM|sadomasochistic]] sexual tastes; he has one of his lovers choke him with a belt while he masturbates,<ref name="youdbesurprised">{{Cite episode|title=You'd Be Surprised|episodelink=Boardwalk Empire (season 3)#ep5|series=Boardwalk Empire|serieslink=Boardwalk Empire|network=HBO|airdate=October 14, 2012|season=3|number=5}}</ref> and has another insult him as a form of foreplay.<ref name="margatesands">{{Cite episode|title=Margate Sands|episodelink=Boardwalk Empire (season 3)#ep12|series=Boardwalk Empire|serieslink=Boardwalk Empire|network=HBO|airdate=December 2, 2012|season=3|number=12}}</ref> ===Season 3=== In the first scene of season three, Rosetti beats a mechanic to death with a tire iron for making an off-handed comment about Rosetti not knowing what [[3-In-One Oil]] is. He travels to [[Atlantic City]] on New Year's Eve (December 31, 1922) in order to purchase a large quantity of bootlegged liquor from Nucky. In order to simplify his operations and keep the law at bay, Nucky decides to sell alcohol exclusively to [[Arnold Rothstein]] ([[Michael Stuhlbarg]]). Rosetti, anticipating a 50% price markup if he were to purchase from Rothstein, curses Nucky and leaves for New York City.<ref name="Resolution"></ref> He then takes over the small town of Tabor Heights and blockades Nucky's shipment heading to Rothstein in New York. Since Tabor Heights sits on the only road suitable for winter travel between Atlantic City and New York and is the last spot to fill up on gas on the way, Nucky has no way to deliver his alcohol.<ref>{{Cite episode|title=Spaghetti and Coffee|episodelink=Boardwalk Empire (season 3)#ep2|series=Boardwalk Empire|serieslink=Boardwalk Empire|network=HBO|airdate=September 23, 2012|season=3|number=2}}</ref> Nucky eventually makes a truce with Rosetti, selling him alcohol, and Rosetti leaves Tabor Heights. However, Rosetti changes his mind when he perceives Nucky's departing words, "Bone For Tuna" — a mispronunciation of "buona fortuna", [[Italian language|Italian]] for "good luck" — as an insult.<ref>{{Cite episode|title=Bone for Tuna|episodelink=Boardwalk Empire (season 3)#ep3|series=Boardwalk Empire|serieslink=Boardwalk Empire|network=HBO|airdate=September 30, 2012|season=3|number=3}}</ref> This escalates to Rosetti's men ambushing a convoy and killing 11 of Nucky's men.<ref>{{Cite episode|title=Blue Bell Boy|episodelink=Boardwalk Empire (season 3)#ep4|series=Boardwalk Empire|serieslink=Boardwalk Empire|network=HBO|airdate=October 7, 2012|season=3|number=4}}</ref> Rothstein responds by sending [[Bugsy Siegel|Benjamin Siegel]] ([[Michael Zegen]]) to kill Rosetti. Although Siegel fails to kill Rosetti, he does kill four of Rosetti's men and a waitress Rosetti had been having sex with, which causes Rosetti to leave Tabor Heights and return to New York.<ref name="youdbesurprised"></ref>
On Easter Sunday, Rosetti's second-in-command Tonino Sandrelli (Chris Caldovino) informs him of all the territory they lost in New York because of their long absence. After dinner, Rosetti goes to church, where he chastises God for the life he was given. He then beats up a priest and steals the church donations. Masseria is upset with Rosetti's long absence and gives the order to kill him. Rosetti tells Masseria that his own losses are nothing compared to all that Masseria can lose from Nucky and Rothstein partnering together. Rosetti is able to convince Masseria to spare his life and provide him with additional men to kill both Nucky and Rothstein and take over Atlantic City.<ref name="sundaybest"></ref>
Rosetti is able to start his own illegal alcohol import business and take over the rackets of Atlantic City. He makes a move to kill Nucky, Rothstein and [[Lucky Luciano|Charlie Luciano]] ([[Vincent Piazza]]); he bombs Nucky's favorite [[supper club]], but all three men survive.<ref name="thepony"></ref> A gang war soon erupts between Nucky and Rosetti, killing dozens of men on both sides, including Nucky's top enforcer Owen Sleater ([[Charlie Cox]]).<ref>{{Cite episode|title=A Man, A Plan...|episodelink=Boardwalk Empire (season 3)#ep10|series=Boardwalk Empire|serieslink=Boardwalk Empire|network=HBO|airdate=November 18, 2012|season=3|number=10}}</ref> Rosetti and his men then take up residence in Gillian Darmody's ([[Gretchen Mol]]) brothel, planning to eventually take it over.<ref name="twoimposters">{{Cite episode|title=Two Imposters|episodelink=Boardwalk Empire (season 3)#ep11|series=Boardwalk Empire|serieslink=Boardwalk Empire|network=HBO|airdate=November 25, 2012|season=3|number=11}}</ref> Rosetti's men soon come after Nucky himself, but he escapes and seeks protection from Northside leader Chalky White ([[Michael K. Williams]]). Rosetti tries to persuade White to surrender Nucky, but White denies knowing his whereabouts. White agrees to support Nucky and is able to fight back against Rosetti with [[Al Capone]]'s ([[Stephen Graham (actor)|Stephen Graham]]) support.<ref name="twoimposters"></ref>
That night, Rosetti is about to have sex with Gillian, who tries to inject him with [[heroin]] so she can render him helpless and kill him. He realizes what she is doing just in time, however, and overpowers her, injecting her during the struggle. Moments later, Masseria's men head back to New York; Nucky and Rothstein had struck a deal with Masseria to withdraw his support from Rosetti. However, men working for White's and Capone's gangs ambush and kill Masseria's men as they leave town. [[Richard Harrow]] ([[Jack Huston]]) shows up at the brothel to rescue Gillian's grandson Tommy, and kills most of Rosetti's men in the process. Rosetti and two of his men escape Harrow's attempt, but Rosetti's luck runs out when, while stopped at a beach, Tonino stabs Rosetti in the back, then again in the chest, killing him. Tonino then takes Rosetti's body back to New York City.<ref name="margatesands"></ref>
==Reception== The role earned Cannavale the [[Primetime Emmy Award]] for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series|Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series]] in 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://variety.com/2013/tv/news/bobby-cannavale-supporting-actor-drama-emmy-win-1200660577/ |title=Emmys: Bobby Cannavale Loves the ‘Hustle’ |work=Variety |first=Cynthia |last=Littleton |date=September 22, 2013 |accessdate=November 23, 2013}}</ref> He was also nominated along with the rest of the cast for the [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a Drama Series]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sagawards.org/media-pr/press-releases/nominations-announced-19th-annual-screen-actors-guild-awards%C2%AE |title=Nominations Announced for the 19th Annual Screen Actors Guild Awards® |publisher=Screen Actors Guild |date=December 12, 2012 |accessdate=November 23, 2013}}</ref> Rosetti was named "Best TV Villain" of 2012 by [[IGN]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/wikis/best-of-2012/Best_TV_Villain |title=Best TV Villain |publisher=IGN |accessdate=January 1, 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.hbo.com/boardwalk-empire/cast-and-crew/gyp-rosetti#/boardwalk-empire/cast-and-crew/gyp-rosetti/bio/gyp-rosetti.html Gyp Rosetti] character bio at HBO.com

{{Infobox serial killer | name=San Mateo slasher | birthname= | alias= The San Mateo Slasher | birth_date= | birth_place= | death_date= | cause= | victims=5+ | country=United States | states=[[California]] | beginyear=1976 | endyear=1976 | apprehended=Unapprehended | locations = San Mateo County | targets = Young females | fatalities = 5+ | weapons = Knives | wanted_since = {{start date and age|January 8, 1976}} | wanted_by = FBI, local police }} The '''Gypsy Hill killings''' are a group of five unsolved [[homicide]]s of young women and girls in [[San Mateo County, California]], during early 1976. The killer became known in the media as "the San Mateo slasher."<ref>{{cite news|title=1976 Nevada murder linked to California serial killer|url=http://wireupdate.com/1976-nevada-murder-linked-to-california-serial-killer.html|accessdate=9 March 2014|newspaper=WireUpdate|date=8 March 2014}}</ref>
==Killings==
On January 8, 1976, the body of 18-year-old Veronica Cascio was discovered in a creek on the grounds of the Sharp Park Golf Course in [[Pacifica, California|Pacifica]]. She had been stabbed 30 times.<ref>{{cite news|title=2 Slain in Pacifica, San Mateo|accessdate=9 March 2014|newspaper=[[San Mateo Times]]|date=January 9, 1976|url=http://newspaperarchive.com/us/california/san-mateo/san-mateo-times/1976/01-09/|page=1}}</ref> A transient was arrested but was released for lack of evidence.<ref>{{cite news|title=Man Freed In Slaying|accessdate=9 March 2014|newspaper=San Mateo Times|date=January 16, 1976|url=http://newspaperarchive.com/us/california/san-mateo/san-mateo-times/1976/01-16/|page=1}}</ref>
A few weeks later, 14-year-old Tatiana Blackwell was reported missing after leaving her home in Pacifica to run an errand. A body, later identified as hers, was discovered off Sharp Park Road in the Gypsy Hills section of the city on June 6.<ref>{{cite news|title=Youths Find Body In Pacifica Hills|accessdate=9 March 2014|newspaper=San Mateo Times|date=June 7, 1976|url=|page=1}}</ref> She had also been stabbed multiple times.
Paula Baxter, 17 years old, went missing on February 2, leaving her mired car behind. Her nude body was found on February 4 in [[Millbrae, California|Millbrae]] behind the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints on Ludeman Lane. She had been stabbed 4 times, sexually assaulted, and hit on the head with a piece of concrete. Her killing was forensically linked to Cascio's.<ref>{{cite news|last=Sullivan|first=Rick|title=Two Stabbing Slayings Still Remain Unsolved|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1914092/two_stabbing_slayings/|accessdate=9 March 2014|newspaper=San Mateo Times|date=19 March 1976|pages=1, 8}}</ref>
On April 1, 19-year-old Denise Lampe of [[Broadmoor, California|Broadmoor]] was found dead after a search in the parking lot of the [[Serramonte Center]]. She had been stabbed 20 times.<ref>{{cite news|title=Brutal DC Slaying; Police Seek Clues|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1914080/brutal_dc_slaying/|accessdate=9 March 2014|newspaper=San Mateo Times|date=April 2, 1976|page=1}}</ref>
Carol Booth, 26, was reported missing by her husband on March 15, and was discovered in a shallow grave near [[Colma Creek]] on Grand Avenue in [[South San Francisco]] on May 6.<ref>{{cite news|last=LaPierre|first=Frank|title=Killer Loose: 4 Murders In 4 Months|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1914103/killer_loose/|accessdate=9 March 2014|newspaper=San Mateo Times|date=May 6, 1976|pages=1, 18}}</ref>
==Victims== The five victims were:<ref>{{cite news|last=Ho|first=Vivian|title=San Mateo County 1976 slayings linked to old Reno murder|url=http://www.sfgate.com/crime/article/San-Mateo-County-1976-slayings-linked-to-old-Reno-5295170.php|accessdate=9 March 2014|newspaper=[[SFGate.com]]|date=7 March 2014}}</ref> *Veronica “Ronnie” Cascio *Tatiana Marie "Tanya" Blackwell *Paula Louise Baxter *Carol Lee Booth *Denise Lampe
==Possible victims== ;Michelle Mitchell<ref>{{cite news|title=Feds link Reno murder to unsolved 1976 'Gypsy Hill Killings'|url=http://www.ktvu.com/news/news/crime-law/feds-link-reno-murder-unsolved-1976-gypsy-hill-kil/nd678/|accessdate=9 March 2014|newspaper=KUTV|date=6 March 2014}}</ref>
Mitchell, 19, was last seen alive in [[Reno, Nevada]], on February 24, 1976, when her [[Volkswagen Beetle]] broke down at the intersection of 9th Street and Evans Avenue. Witnesses reported seeing someone help push her vehicle into the parking lot across from the [[University of Nevada, Reno|UNR]] agricultural building on Evans Street.<ref>{{cite news|last=Ivie|first=Erin|title=Gypsy Hill victims exhibited 'startling' similarities|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/san-mateo-county-times/ci_25291485/gypsy-hill-victims-exhibited-startling-similarities|accessdate=9 March 2014|newspaper=Mercury News|date=6 March 2014}}</ref>
Her body was discovered that evening in a garage on East 9th Street with her hands bound and her throat slashed. Three years later, Cathy Woods, a mental patient at the [[Louisiana State University Medical Center]], confessed to murdering a woman named Michelle. She was charged and convicted of murdering Michelle Mitchell.<ref name=RGJ>{{cite news|last=Marcus|first=Emerson|title=Authorities reopen '76 case of UNR student slaying (with video)|url=http://www.rgj.com/article/20140306/NEWS01/303060048/1976-Reno-slaying-University-Nevada-student-re-opened?nclick_check=1|accessdate=9 March 2014|newspaper=[[Reno Gazette-Journal]]|date=6 March 2014}}</ref>
;Idell M. Friedman<ref name="SF76">{{cite news|title=Help Asked In Probe Of Slaying|work=SF Chronicle|date=March 19, 1976}}</ref>
Friedman, 21, an employee of an import firm, was found assaulted and stabbed to death with an 8-inch-knife in her apartment at 116 Fairmount Street in [[San Francisco]]. She was murdered on March 17, 1976, only two days after Gypsy Hill victim Carol Lee Booth was reported missing.
Friedman's nude body was lying on the kitchen floor of her ransacked apartment. She was found by a co-worker who became concerned when Friedman did not show up for work.<ref name="SF76"/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Murphy|first1=Dave|title=Murders still haunt him because he has no proof|work=San Mateo Times|date=May 8, 1986|page=A6}}</ref>
==Investigation and arrest== Investigators connected some of the homicides to each other. All of the slain women were young brunettes, and most had experienced car trouble prior to being murdered. All of the bodies were found in [[Woodland|wooded areas]].
A lack of witnesses and forensic evidence stalled the investigations.
In March 2014, the FBI established a task force to re-examine the murders, after new [[DNA profiling|DNA]] evidence cast doubt on the conviction of Cathy Woods, now 64,<ref name=RGJ/> for Mitchell's murder.<ref>{{cite news|title=FBI launches task force for "Gypsy Hill Murders"|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/mar/6/fbi-launches-task-force-for-gypsy-hill-murders/|accessdate=9 March 2014|newspaper=Washington Times|date=6 March 2014}}</ref> The DNA taken from a cigarette butt found at the Mitchell crime scene matched DNA taken from semen found at related crime scenes in San Mateo, California. This DNA was that of a man and therefore might exonerate Woods.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2748457/Judge-orders-new-trial-1976-Reno-killing.html|title=Cathy Woods, found guilty of 1976 murder, gets new trial with new DNA links|work=Mail Online|accessdate=12 September 2014|author= Ashley Collman|date=9 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Moye|first=David|title=Crime Scene DNA No Match For Woman Convicted Of 1976 Murder|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/03/07/cathy-woods_n_4922104.html|accessdate=9 March 2014|newspaper=Huffington Post|date=7 March 2014}}</ref>
On September 8, 2014, the FBI named Rodney Halbower as a person of interest in the Gypsy Hill murders.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/san-mateo-county-times/ci_26493681/peninsula-person-interest-named-gypsy-hill-cold-case|title=Gypsy Hill murders: Person of interest named in killings of Peninsula women|author= Erin Ivie|date=8 September 2014|work=Mercury News}}</ref> Woods was released from prison on September 11 pending a new trial to take place on July 13, 2015.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/woman-released-1976-reno-murder-case-220949893.html|title=Woman released in 1976 Reno murder case|date=11 September 2014|work=Yahoo News|accessdate=12 September 2014}}</ref>
On January 22, 2015, Halbower was charged with two of the murders (Paula Baxter and Veronica Cascio). DNA evidence linked him to both.<ref>{{cite news|title=New Suspect Arrested, Charged in 1976 'Gypsy Hill' Murders|url=http://www.ktvn.com/story/27915011/new-suspect-arrested-charged-in-1976-gypsy-hill-murders|accessdate=22 January 2015|newspaper=KTVN Channel 2 News|date=22 January 2015}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2012}} {{Infobox officeholder | name =Gábor Vajna | image =VajnaGabor.jpg | order =[[Minister of the Interior of Hungary|Minister of the Interior]] | term_start =16 October 1944 | term_end =28 March 1945 | president = | predecessor =[[Péter Schell]] | successor =[[Ferenc Erdei]] | birth_date ={{Birth date|df=yes|1891|11|04}} | birth_place =[[Târgu Secuiesc|Kézdivásárhely]], [[Kingdom of Hungary]], [[Austria-Hungary]] | death_date={{Death date and age|1946|03|12|1891|11|04|df=y}} | death_place=[[Budapest]], [[Hungary]] | profession =[[politician]] | party =[[Arrow Cross Party]] |}} {{eastern name order|Vajna Gábor}} '''Gábor Vajna''' (4 November 1891 – 12 March 1946) was a [[Hungary|Hungarian]] politician, who served as [[List of Interior Ministers of Hungary|Minister of the Interior]] from 1944 to 1945.
==Early life== Vajna was born into a Transylvanian Calvinist family in [[Kézdivásárhely]] (today [[Târgu Secuiesc]], [[Romania]]), then part of the [[Kingdom of Hungary]] on 4 November 1891. He participated in [[World War I]] as an officer in the 29th Feldjäger Battalion of the [[Austro-Hungarian Army]] and has received many honors during his forty-three months of military service. Following the war, Vajna took service in the Hungarian Embassy at [[Vienna]], and later worked for the Ministry of Defence. He retired from the [[Royal Hungarian Army]] as a Major in 1924. After that he was appointed director of the gunpowder factory in [[Balatonfűzfő]]. When his far-right sympathy is revealed, Vajna was dismissed from that position.
==Political career== [[File:Arrow Cross Party.jpg|left|thumb|Ministers of the [[Government of National Unity (Hungary)|Arrow Cross Party government]]. Gábor Vajna is in the third from left of the upper row.]]
Vajna was a confidant of Prime Minister [[Ferenc Szálasi]], the Hungarian fascist party leader and founder of the extreme right "[[Party of National Will]]", which later became the [[Arrow Cross Party]]. Vajna was elected Member of Parliament from the regional list of [[Veszprém County (former)|Veszprém County]] during the [[Hungarian parliamentary election, 1939|1939 parliamentary election]]. After the [[Operation Margarethe|German occupation of Hungary]] in March 1944, he maintained a good relationship between the Hungarian authorities and the arriving [[Gestapo]] and [[Schutzstaffel]] officials. He helped to overcoming the resistance fighters and prevent sabotage activities. Following the [[Operation Panzerfaust|Arrow Cross Party's coup]], Vajna took office as Interior Minister in October 1944 and served until March 1945.<ref>Bölöny, József – Hubai, László: ''Magyarország kormányai 1848–2004'' [Cabinets of Hungary 1848–2004], Akadémiai Kiadó, Budapest, 2004 (5th edition). p. 218.</ref>
While responsible for internal affairs, Vajna took a number of actions against Hungarian Jews. In cooperation with requests from German officials such as SS officer [[Edmund Veesenmayer]], Vajna moved quickly to deport Jews in areas under Hungarian control to the [[Third Reich]], where they were used as slaves and many were ultimately killed. As many as 76,000 Jews were delivered into Nazi hands through the end of 1944.{{Citation needed|date=December 2014}} During his ministership, the [[Budapest Ghetto]] was established on 29 November 1944 which lasted for less than three months.<ref>Decree On the Establishment of the Budapest Ghetto at the [https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Holocaust/budapestghetto.html Jewish Virtual Library].</ref>
Following the [[Siege of Budapest|fall of Budapest]], Vajna attempted to escape to [[Western Europe]] but was captured by units of the [[United States Army]] along with other members of the government. He was later tried in Budapest by a so-called people's tribunal and sentenced to death for war crimes, crimes against humanity and treason. He was hanged in 1946 in Budapest on the same day as Ferenc Szálasi, [[Károly Beregfy]] and [[József Gera]].

{{no footnotes|date=March 2011}} [[File:Nuremberg Trials retouched.jpg|thumb|right|[[Göring]] (first row, far left) at the [[Nuremberg Trials]]]] In the [[Nuremberg Trials]] there was a document referred to as the '''"Green Folder"''' of ''Reichsmarschall'' [[Hermann Göring]]. This was the master policy directive for the economic exploitation of the conquered Soviet Union. The implications of this document were the death by starvation of millions of Slavic people, something that partially came to pass in the [[Holocaust]], the neglect of Soviet soldiers captured by the Nazis which led to huge mortality rates, and the general expropriation of food in the occupied areas of the Soviet Union. It is also referred to as Document of the Soviet Prosecution, Exhibit USSR 10.
==Background== The philosophy espoused by [[Adolf Hitler]] in his book ''[[Mein Kampf]]'' argues for the expansion of the [[Germanic peoples|Germans]] into eastern lands held by [[Slavic peoples|the Slavs]], referring to these lands as ''[[Lebensraum]]''.
==Plan Oldenburg== Plan "Oldenburg" (Göring's "Green Folder") was the code-name of the economic subsection of the planned attack of the USSR.
Following the approval of Hitler of the [[Operation Barbarossa]] plan, the Führer instructed ''Reichsmarschall'' Göring to develop a plan for the future exploitation of conquered territory in the East. Under Göring's leadership, a plan known as '''Oldenburg''' was created to include the seizing for the service of the Reich all stocks of raw materials and large industrial enterprises in the territory between the [[Vistula]] and the [[Urals]]. According to this plan the most valuable manufacturing equipment was to be sent to the Reich and that which was not sent to Germany would be destroyed. The European part of the Soviet Union would be economically decentralized and be turned into an agricultural appendage of Germany.
The original plan was approved at a secret meeting on March 1, 1941 (protocol 1317-PS). Over the next two months the plan was fleshed out in detail and finally adopted on April 29, 1941 (protocol secret meeting 1157-PS). A headquarters was formed to coordinate the "Oldenburg" plan.
According to the plan, the territory to be occupied in the Soviet Union would be divided into five economic Inspectorates, three of them attached to [[Army Group North]] ([[Leningrad]]), [[Army Group Center]] ([[Moscow]]), and [[Army Group South]] ([[Kiev]]), one for the [[Caucasus]] ([[Baku]]), and one held in reserve, with 23 economic commandants, as well as 12 offices.
On May 8, 1941 the "Common instructions to all Reich commissioners in the occupied eastern territories" was adopted, based on this plan (documents 1029-PS, 1030-PS).
==Hunger Plan== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-J02034, Herbert Backe.jpg|thumb|[[Herbert Backe]]]] A separate committee was formed to organize the collection of food in the occupied territories, as per [[Herbert Backe]]'s [[Hunger Plan]]. It was tasked with ensuring that by 1942, the German armed forces would be fully nourished by the resources of the USSR, without taking into account the needs of the Soviet population.
In accordance with the order of the Supreme Command Chief of Staff of the Wehrmacht [[Wilhelm Keitel]] (dated June 16, 1941), the main economic challenge for the territories seized from the Soviet Union, was described as "an immediate and full exploitation of the occupied areas in favor of the war economy of Germany, particularly in the areas of food and oil".
''Reichsmarschall'' Göring, directly supervising the "Oldenburg" headquarters, wrote:
:In the East, I intend to loot and pillage effectively. All that may be suitable for the Germans in the East, should be extracted and brought to Germany immediately.
Shortly after the beginning of the German campaign against the Soviet Union, on July 15, 1941, he wrote in his "Green Folder":
:Use of the occupied territories should be made primarily in the food and oil sectors of economy. Get to Germany as much food and oil as possible - that is the main economic goal of the campaign.
Initially, the German military leadership believed that during the war, it would not be necessary to rebuild the Soviet Union's industry or to use its natural wealth, and that a policy of seizing only finished products and raw materials in warehouses would be sufficient.
Subsequently they made an accounting of industry and mines to ensure their safety and to establish civil administration of captured territories.
When the expected rapid end of the war did not materialize and Germany had suffered great losses in manpower, equipment and weapons, the existing stocks began to be depleted quickly. The German leadership urgently started to develop a plan for the economic use of the occupied territories, during the war itself. Thus German leadership had to abandon the implementation of the plan '''Oldenburg''', recognizing its unsuitability.
After the war ended, the activities of '''Staff Oldenburg''' were the subject of consideration and condemnation at the Nuremberg Tribunal.
==See also== * [[A-A line]] * [[Operation Barbarossa]] * [[Reichskommissariat]] — particularly [[Reichskommissariat#Former Soviet territories|the areas]] within and adjacent to ''[[Lebensraum]]'' territory * [[World War II]]
==References== * Nuremberg Trial document - http://www.nizkor.org/hweb/imt/tgmwc/tgmwc-07/tgmwc-07-65-05.shtml * Nuremberg Trial document - http://www.nizkor.org/hweb/imt/nca/nca-02/nca-02-16-responsibility-01-05.html * Orders signed by Göring - http://www.snyderstreasures.com/pages/documents.htm#mansfeld

{{Infobox mass murderer | name = Günter Hermann Ewen | image = Günter Hermann Ewen.png | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Günter Hermann Ewen | occupation = Paver | birth_date = 1962 | birth_place = [[Dillingen, Saarland|Dillingen]], [[Germany]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1999|05|18|1962||}} | death_place = [[Strassen, Luxembourg]] | cause = Suicide | date = May 16, 1999 | time = 4:40 a.m. – 5:40 a.m. | targets = | locations = [[Dillingen, Saarland|Dillingen]], [[Germany]]
[[Sierck-les-Bains]], [[France]] | fatalities = 5 | injuries = 11 | weapons = * [[CZ 75]] [[Pistol]] ([[9×19mm Parabellum|9mm]]) * [[Smith & Wesson]] [[revolver]] ([[.357 Magnum]]) }} '''Günter Hermann Ewen''' (1962 – May 18, 1999) was a German mass murderer who killed four people and wounded at least nine others in [[Dillingen, Saarland|Dillingen]], [[Germany]] on May 16, 1999, before escaping to [[Sierck-les-Bains]], [[France]], where he killed another person, and wounded two more. Hunted by German and French police, he eventually committed suicide in a hotel in [[Strassen, Luxembourg]] on May 18.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/345529.stm Manhunt for border killer], ''[[BBC]]'' (May 17, 1999)[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/347118.stm Cross-border murder suspect found dead], ''[[BBC]]'' (May 18, 1999)[http://www.independent.co.uk/news/briton-among-the-dead-as-disco-gunman-kills-five-1094204.html Briton among the dead as disco gunman kills five], ''[[The Independent]]'' (May 17, 1999)[http://www.liberation.fr/societe/0101282113-la-chasse-a-l-assassin-fait-trembler-la-moselle-tueur-de-cinq-personnes-ce-week-end-il-court-toujours La chasse à l'assassin fait trembler la Moselle], ''[[Libération]]'' (May 18, 1999) ==Life== Ewen was born in Dillingen in 1962, being the youngest and only boy among five siblings, and suffered from [[asthma]] from childhood. He showed little interest at school, had to repeat two grades and left [[Hauptschule]] after grade seven,Der verdächtige Ewen wurde vom kleinen Ganoven zum Schwerverbrecher, ''[[Saarbrücker Zeitung]]'' (May 18, 1999) whereupon he started an apprenticeship as a paver, which he quit after two years due to his ailment. Up to the age of 30 he lived with his parents and mostly worked odd jobs to earn money. According to conflicting reports Ewen began to consume alcohol excessively either at the age of twelveVom Voyeur zum Serien-Mörder, ''[[Saarbrücker Zeitung]]'' (May 22, 1999) or eighteen, animated by one of his sisters' boyfriends, whom he admired for his rather wasteful lifestyle. As a youth he was arrested for theft, fraud, and battery, and starting in 1982 he was caught numerous times while driving under the influence of alcohol, which resulted in a three-month prison term when he was 26. Since 1990 he was arrested for acts of voyeurism and exhibitionism, and in February 1991 he was fined after masturbating in front of women at a tennis club. Six months later Ewen, in drunk condition, twice broke into a home for mentally disabled women and sexually molested them in their beds. One hour after the second such incident he raped a woman in her home.[http://www.focus.de/politik/deutschland/verbrechen-tag-der-abrechnung_aid_176962.html Tag der Abrechnung], ''[[Focus (German magazine)|Focus]]'' (21/1999) In February 1993 Ewen was convicted for rape and sexual assault in three cases, and sentenced to a prison term of five years and six months. A psychologist found him to be a [[narcissist]], who, in his infantile egocentrism, ruthlessly tried to satisfy his own needs, especially when under the influence of alcohol. In prison he was in therapy concerning his sex offences and was eventually released in October 1996, after serving two third of his sentence. Out of prison Ewen started his own business, but in August 1998 he was accused by his friend Robert Fisne of six counts of burglary, whereupon he was again arrested. He remained in [[Remand (detention)|remand]] until January 1999, when he was acquitted, since no incriminating evidence could be found and the testimony of Fisne, the only witness in the case, was vague and contradictory. Even though he left prison cleared of these accusations, the arrest turned out to be devastating to Ewen's personal life, as during this time his business went bankrupt, he lost his home, his girlfriend left him and he had accumulated [[Deutsche Mark|DM]] 60,000 in debt, while the DM 3,000 granted as compensation for his wrongful imprisonment were barely enough to pay his attorney. Ewen eventually found shelter at the home of his sister and brother-in-law in [[Beckingen]] where he lived up to the day of the shooting and helped renovating the building.Fieberhafte Jagd nach dem Dillinger Mörder, ''[[Saarbrücker Zeitung]]'' (May 18, 1999)'Der beschte Bua', ''[[Stern (magazine)|Stern]]'' (May 27, 1999) ===Victims=== *Roland Dekow, 42, manager of "Xanadu"-discothèque[http://www.independent.ie/world-news/killing-spree-gunman-evades-police-hunt-408902.html Killing spree gunman evades police hunt], ''[[Irish Independent]]'' (May 18, 1999) *Unknown, 40, doorman at "Xanadu"-discothèque *Robert Fisne, 37 *Shonnette Maxine Fisne, 41, wife of Robert FisneKiller may have sought revenge against theft case witness, ''[[The Times]]'' (May 18, 1999) *Étienne Kuster, 39 ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ewen, Gunther Hermann}} [[Category:German mass murderers]] [[Category:Suicides by firearm in Luxembourg]] [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:1999 deaths]] [[Category:Mass murder in 1999]] [[Category:German spree killers]] [[Category:People from Saarlouis (district)]] [[Category:Murder–suicides]] [[Category:Criminals who committed suicide]] [[Category:Male suicides]]
